story:
Who Are We

We are a group of first year students from the faculty of education at Sakon Nakhon Rajabhat University in North East Thailand. As part of our education, we have been given the chance to work on, and address an issue that we are personally passionate about. 

As a group, we quickly agreed to place our focus, and energy on environmental and global warming issues. The main reasons for our choice was based on our daily observations of the lack of recycling and overuse of plastic bags among our fellow students. 

Moreover, our university are currently undergoing great expansion, which great for us and our academic opportunities, however in this process trees has to come down. We therefore wish to take an active role in replanting more trees.  

Combating environmental and global warming issues might seem like a big, and impossible task for a group of first year student from a university in the north east of Thailand. However, we believe that this is our strength. As university students, we have the potential to easily expose our efforts to more than 12.000 students. 

We believe, that we through our events, presentations and social media efforts have a great opportunity to change the way many of our fellow student are thinking about recycle, overuse of plastic bags, and the importance of preserving and replanting trees. Thus creating a community of change agents for a cleaner and better environment for all of us to live in. 


    

The Impact - Why Us!! 

The future environment depends on the way we act and behave today, and we believe that it is our responsibility, to ensure that we leave a cleaner and better environment for the next generation!! 

We strongly believe, that big change can come from committed and passionate small steps.We believe, that by starting small, and focusing on a few focus areas we can steady and continuously grow bigger, and expand our efforts to other universities and schools in Thailand. 

Our first three focus areas are therefore. 

  1. Increase the recycling of plastic bottles, and utilize revenue of this recycling to implement our efforts in other areas and universities.

  2. Increase the use of cloth-bags when shopping.

  3. Plant trees around campus, and in the near by forest, to advocate and raise awareness of the importance of replanting and preserving trees and forest areas. 

We Need Your Help to Succeed!!

For us to initiate our project, we are asking for your help to raise $750. Should we success in raising this amount, it will be used as followed:  

  • $300 will go to 3 special made plastic bottle cages. 

These cages will have information about our project, and the importance of taking responsibility in ensuring a cleaner environment. They will be strategically placed on campus, so that our cause and believes will reach as many students as possible. The revenue will as mentioned be used to increase our efforts in other areas, schools and universities.

  • $350 will be spent on purchasing cloth bags with our logo.

By given out free cloths bags at all our events, it is our aim to raise awareness about the overuse of plastic bags, and its impacts on the environment. These cloths bags will our logo (see below) so that those who use them will continue to spread awareness about our cause.

                                

  • $100 will be spent on creating informational materials about what we are doing and why it is important that we take responsibility.

These materials will be given along with the cloth bags at our presentation, community clean-ups, tree planting events and cage revealing. All information flyers will be printed on recycled paper to create awareness that recycling goes beyond just plastic bottles, and the use of cloth bags, and that it a choice and a state of mind everybody can live by if they wish to. 

Should we not be able to reach the financial goal we are aiming for, our priority will be as followed:

      1.   Steel cages  

      2.   Informational Materials

      3.   Cloth bags.

This priority should not been seen as we believe less in power of informational materials and cloth bags, but that the steel cages will provide us with a revenue that can potentially support our other objectives.

Risks & Challenges!!

Besides not raising enough funds to initiate this project, we foresee a minimum of risks and challenges. However, we are very aware of the fact, that this is a project, that will need our continuous attention to succeed. Some of the challenges we might experience is:

• Lack of interest and participation at our events and recycling efforts.

• Participants lose interest in or forget about our efforts.

• Finding volunteers for community cleanups.

However, when that is said, we believe that we are ready should these or other challenges arise. As a group, we are ready to commit the need time and attention to all challenges that might arise. 

You Help Means The World To Us!!

Thank you for taking the time to read about our project. We hope, that you have decided to support us in our efforts to increase environmental responsibility, so that we can leave a cleaner environment for the generations to come. 

Besides supporting us financially, you can also help us tremendously by sharing this campaign on your various social media sites, so that the information about our efforts reaches as many as possible.


                                                 Thank you – Khop Khun mâak!!

story:
The Issue

For years, I’ve seen the lack of winter rains in New Mexico, followed by intense spring winds that whipped across the state, drying up the forests, so that by June, the inevitable forest fires began. Hundreds of thousands of acres of forests have been destroyed. It saddened me to the point that I knew that I MUST do something about it, that’s why the film is being made.

The film does not just portray the drought in New Mexico. That is already painfully obvious. The point of the film is to show that positive solutions are within our grasp, that people DO HAVE A CHOICE about their impact on the environment.

The solutions we're showing are practical and can be done by everyone.

This narrative is about hope, about leading the way to a positive future for our children and grandchildren. 


The Importance of the Project

What’s happening here in New Mexico is a microcosm of what will be happening globally, and what is also happening in other parts of the Southwest.

The solutions are not just regional, but can be applied globally, that’s why the film has a universal appeal: it’s a set of solutions that can be applied to other regions as well.

The Project

The film is a feature documentary, 56 minutes in length. A book will follow in the fall with more in-depth look at the issues and solutions covered in the film.

The Contributors

The film is an incredible collaboration of experts from both scientific and spiritual fields, writers, musicians, and other filmmakers.


Appearing in the film:

*David Holmgren, co-originator of the permaculture concept

*Scott Pittman, Permaculture Institute of Santa Fe and Costa Rica

*Dr. Roger Nelson, director of Global Conscious Project

*Heath Haussasmen, writer for New Mexico in Depth

*Anne Meloy, soil scientist

*Peter “Owl” McCabe, permaculture consultant

*Be Sargent, Work in Beauty (permaculture)

*Johnny “Nailman” Alston, musician

*Linda Sue Boos, singer

*Martin Spence, writer, composer, singer and musican

*Virgil Smith, historian

*Brother Alberto Pilarca, Benedictine Monk

*Julie von Erffa, Doctor of Oriental Medicine

*Al Sanchez, New Mexico resident

Why Should I Support Your Project?

Aside from the rewards that we are offering to show our thanks (and there’s something given at every level of support), there’s also many more reasons to support this project:

*You want to see a climate change film that gives positive solutions.

*You want to know more about the positive solutions so that you can share them in your community.

*You love an inspiring documentary.

*You believe change is possible.

What Else Can I Do Help This Project?

Besides your contributions (and huge thanks for that!) please share this campaign on social media or through emails, or just by talking about it to others. We believe that each time positive energy is shared with others, it makes an impact on the world. Truly, thank you.

What the Funds Will be Used For

The production part of the film has been personally funded by the filmmaker, letting you know that she personally contributed to this effort both physically, emotionally and financially.

Thousands of miles have been traveled around the state, documenting rivers, lakes, and forests, as well as talking to the people who live in New Mexico. Scientists have been interviewed from many fields. The film is near completion, so will be available very soon. The funds will be used for post-production costs such as DVD production and marketing so that the film can get out to as many people as possible.

The filmmaker will be personally involved in traveling around the state showing the film and talking about the solutions presented.

Background on the Filmmaker


Cheryl Gorder has been an award-winning book writer on social issues for many years, including an environmental title: Green Earth Resource Guide. She is mainly known for her work promoting homeschooling in the early years of the movement, appearing on hundreds of radio shows and TV, including an appearance on CNN. Cheryl Gorder is the recipient of a Benjamin Franklin Award from Publishers Marketing Association and runner-up for Small Press Publisher of the Year. She was listed on the Wall of Tolerance (2005) awarded by the National Campaign for Tolerance and was acknowledged by the Century Society (2005-2006) awarded for helping Native American Children. She is the writer of 14 published books and publisher of 200+ titles, all of which were dedicated to positive social change.

Education:

Lehigh University MBA (Graduate School of Business) 

South Dakota State University BA (Liberal Arts) 

Santa Fe Community College (Film Production & Media Arts)
story_txt:
The Issue
For years, I’ve seen the lack of
winter rains in New Mexico, followed by intense spring winds that whipped
across the state, drying up the forests, so that by June, the inevitable forest
fires began. Hundreds of thousands of acres of forests have been destroyed. It
saddened me to the point that I knew that I MUST do something about it, that’s
why the film is being made.
The film does not just portray the
drought in New Mexico. That is already painfully obvious. The point of the film
is to show that positive solutions are within our grasp, that people DO HAVE A
CHOICE about their impact on the environment.
The solutions we're showing are
practical and can be done by everyone.
This narrative is about hope, about
leading the way to a positive future for our children and grandchildren.  
The Importance of the Project
What’s happening here in New Mexico
is a microcosm of what will be happening globally, and what is also happening
in other parts of the Southwest. 
The solutions are not just regional,
but can be applied globally, that’s why the film has a universal appeal: it’s a
set of solutions that can be applied to other regions as well.
The Project
The film is a feature documentary, 56
minutes in length. A book will follow in the fall with more in-depth look at
the issues and solutions covered in the film.
The Contributors
The film is an incredible
collaboration of experts from both scientific and spiritual fields, writers,
musicians, and other filmmakers.
Appearing in the film:
*David Holmgren, co-originator of the
permaculture concept
*Scott Pittman, Permaculture
Institute of Santa Fe and Costa Rica
*Dr. Roger Nelson, director of Global
Conscious Project
*Heath Haussasmen, writer for New
Mexico in Depth
*Anne Meloy, soil scientist
*Peter “Owl” McCabe, permaculture
consultant
*Be Sargent, Work in
Beauty (permaculture)
*Johnny “Nailman” Alston, musician
*Linda Sue Boos, singer
*Martin Spence, writer, composer,
singer and musican
*Virgil Smith, historian
*Brother Alberto Pilarca, Benedictine
Monk*Julie von Erffa, Doctor of Oriental Medicine*Al Sanchez, New Mexico resident
Why Should I Support Your Project?
Aside from the rewards that we are
offering to show our thanks (and there’s something given at every level of
support), there’s also many more reasons to support this project:
*You want to see a climate change
film that gives positive solutions.
*You want to know more about the
positive solutions so that you can share them in your community.
*You love an inspiring documentary.
*You believe change is possible.
What Else Can I Do Help This Project?
Besides your contributions (and huge
thanks for that!) please share this campaign on social media or through emails,
or just by talking about it to others. We believe that each time positive
energy is shared with others, it makes an impact on the world. Truly, thank
you.
What the Funds Will be Used For
The production part of the film has
been personally funded by the filmmaker, letting you know that she personally
contributed to this effort both physically, emotionally and financially.
Thousands of miles have been traveled
around the state, documenting rivers, lakes, and forests, as well as talking to
the people who live in New Mexico. Scientists have been interviewed from many
fields. The film is near completion, so will be available very soon. The funds will be used for
post-production costs such as DVD production and marketing so that the film can
get out to as many people as possible.
The filmmaker will be personally
involved in traveling around the state showing the film and talking about the
solutions presented.

Gorder is the recipient of a Benjamin Franklin Award from Publishers Marketing
Association and runner-up for Small Press Publisher of the Year. She was listed

and was acknowledged by the Century Society (2005-2006) awarded for helping
Native American Children. She is the writer of 14 published books
and publisher of 200+ titles, all of which were dedicated to positive social
change.

story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT

2 years ago we presented the prototyp of the RUBBER CAT necklace for the first time at a fair. Now we are proud to present you the final product. The rubber-like pendants are miniatures of our iconic lamp shade designs. The small wireframe models are produced in Belgium by using a selective laser sintering method. The models are printed layer by layer by a laser that draws thin lines in a rubber-like granular powder, which melts and bonds it together in order to form a thin layer of the model. After a layer is printed, a new layer of fresh powder is spread over the surface. Layer by layer the pendant grows. The chain is a synthetic string. The customers are invited to thread the chain through the wireframe model however they like – DIY. Specially for this kick-off sale we are proud to present you also a  Special Edition designed by Kati Jerabek and filled with selected faceted stones .


WHAT YOU GET

RUBBER CAT SMALL

Pendant: 19.4x21.1x20.8mm / 0.76x0.83x0.82inch
Rubber-like material / Made in Belgium
Production method: 3D print / laser sintering
Chain: 70cm / 35inch / syntethic string
Packaging: 3D printed box

30,- Euro


RUBBER CAT MEDIUM

Pendant: 25.6x27.7x27.4mm / 1.01x1.09x1.08inch

Rubber-like material / Made in Belgium
Production method: 3D print / laser sintering
Chain: 80cm / 35inch / syntethic string
Packaging: 3D printed box

40,- Euro


RUBBER CAT LARGE

Pendant: 33.7x36.6x36.1mm / 1.33x1.44x1.42inch
Rubber-like material / Made in Belgium
Production method: 3D print / laser sintering
Chain: 80cm / 35inch / syntethic string
Packaging: 3D printed box

50,- Euro


Special Edition RUBBER CAT SMALL by  Kati Jerabek

Pendant: 19.4x21.1x20.8mm / 0.76x0.83x0.82inch
Rubber-like material / Made in Belgium
Production method: 3D print / laser sintering
filled with selected faceted stones such as:
agate stone, citrine, malachite, berg crystal, rose quartz,...
Chain: 45-90cm / 17-35inch / syntethic string
Packaging: 3D printed box

55,- Euro


Special Edition RUBBER CAT MEDIUM by  Kati Jerabek

Pendant: 25.6x27.7x27.4mm / 1.01x1.09x1.08inch

Rubber-like material / Made in Belgium
Production method: 3D print / laser sintering
filled with selected faceted stones such as:
agate stone, citrine, malachite, berg crystal, rose quartz,...
Chain: 45-90cm / 17-35inch / syntethic string
Packaging: 3D printed box

65,- Euro


Special Edition RUBBER CAT LARGE by  Kati Jerabek

Pendant: 33.7x36.6x36.1mm / 1.33x1.44x1.42inch
Rubber-like material / Made in Belgium
Production method: 3D print / laser sintering
filled with selected faceted stones such as:
agate stone, citrine, malachite, berg crystal, rose quartz,...
Chain: 45-90cm / 17-35inch / syntethic string
Packaging: 3D printed box

75,- Euro


WHO WE ARE

MOSTLIKELY

MOSTLIKELY combines architecture, computer graphics, design and sound. Their outstanding projects vary from buildings to art-installations as well as from videos to music productions, whereas boundaries between branches are most likely free flowing. The Viennese agency is run by the five partners Wolfgang List, Kurt Mühlbauer, Maik Perfahl, Mark Neuner and Robert Schwarz.

The sub branch MOSTLIKELY DESIGN was founded 2012 by Maik Perfahl and Wolfgang List of MOSTLIKELY. The goal of MOSTLIKELY DESIGN is to offer affordable products that are produced by ourselfs or within the European Union.

mostlikely.at

mostlikelyshop.com

facebook.com/mostlikelydesign


KATI JERABEK

Kati Jerabek is a product designer with a passion for creating little precious things.
Living and studying in different places such as Lima, London, Milan and Vienna has sharpened her senses for color and material.
Working in the jewelry and bag business have trained her in different ways of production.
In her designs she brings them all together.


RISKS

No risks! The design and the prototypes are finished. We are looking for people who are interested in our products. We only produce on demand. Production of your order will take approximatly 2 weeks.


FAQs

How much is shipping?

Austria: shipping for free
European Union: 5,- Euros
Rest of the world: 10,- Euros

story:
Short Summary

Black Howla Ecolution, a fusion of revolution and the saving of our environment. 

Come be part of something special! Whether you are one of our former guests, a future guest, or someone who who has a love for and dedication to our beautiful, natural world.

The Black Howla Ecolution is a work in progress, dedicated to increasing our awareness of our relationship to the world around us by providing a setting where we can reconnect to our nature and the nature that nurtures us.

The cornerstone of the project is, over the last several years, Shane has developed a connection to a small troop of howler monkeys that live in the area. They are totally wild and free, in their natural state, but when he calls, they will (often) come and interact and share a small bit of their world with us.

The work in progress is to create a place where others can come and share in that and other wonderful experiences. In a setting where the mental and emotional pollution that bombards us in the world today is minimized so that our true feelings and connections can manifest. 

Over the last 10 years, we have been able to establish a solid foundation, developing an international reputation and many loyal followers. Now is the time to expand this project so we can have a greater impact on the local community as well as the world around us. Your participation will provide a tremendous boost, and allow us to extend our reach to many more individuals.

Specific projects and goals include:

  1. Develop a small sustainable and ecofriendly community where people with similar goals and aspirations can come and share some time and experience our surroundings free (or at least with less) of the clutter that bombards us on a daily basis.

  2. Create an interactive center where we can learn to appreciate the cultural and historic foundations we spring from.

  3. Create a totally organic farm that produces most of the food consumed in the community, to demonstrate sustainable farming practices, and teach them to the surrounding community.

  4. Create and stimulate economic development in the area where there is currently very little opportunity, to liberate the community from the day to day, hand to mouth pressures of being able to feed their families.


What We Need & What You Get

Specific projects that will be accomplished as we are able to raise funds with your help:

  • Continue to expand and preserve the habitat for black howler monkeys.

  • Build a series of small cabanas and camping facilities where people can come and spend time learning about our relationship to and responsibility for Mother Earth.

  • Develop a sustainable organic garden to provide all the food for our sanctuary project, and serve as a demonstration model for local people on how to provide healthy and sustainable food supply.

  • Create a eco-cultural learning center and museum for teaching the cultural heritage of Belize

  • Develop micro enterprises where we help community members develop markets for local products that now often go to waste, such as cashew, mango, blackberry, cohune nuts, etc, to better utilize local resourses and provide stable economic support to their families.

The project will go forward, whether we are able to raise a little or a lot with your support. Obviously, the more we can raise, the faster and more wide ranging will be the impact of the project, but rest assured that every cent donated will go toward achieving the goals as outlined above.

Check out the perks we offer as a way you can participate in this "Ecolution".

The Impact

Due to hunting and habitat destruction, the howler monkey has become an endangered species. However, due to our efforts and those of many others, the trend has been reversed, and the monkeys are now gaining ground in the fight for survival. One of our primary projects is habitat preservation and the continuation of that trend.

Unfortunately, poverty often leads to practices that are not environmentely friendly, because of the necessity of providing for families. In an area where unemployment is often over 50% and under employment is almost universal, one of our major focuses is to promote the development of micro enterprises where local community members can develop markets for products that often go to waste, such as cashews, mango, blackberry, cohune nuts, etc. to better utilize local resources and provide stable economic support to their families, This can reduce the need for environmentally destructive practices such as clearing of rain forest, hunting of endangered species, etc. 

We currently provide stable employment for 10 members of the community, and that will multiply many times as the project progresses.

In addition, it will allow for people who have never had an opportunity for success to develop real careers, support their families, and contribute to the development of the community.

Risks & Challenges

Change always invites resistance. "We've always done it this way!", "What makes you think your way is better?"

But with a 10 year track record of building from the ground up, often without much outside support, and occasionally with resistance, we feel uniquely positioned for success and ready, with support from like minded people like you, to expand and make a real impact.   

The project will move forward. The speed at which it does will depend to a large degree on the amount of support we get from friends and neighbors who see and embrace our vision.

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you can contribute to this project will aid in its success. No donation is too small. But whether you can donate now or not, you can also help by spreading the word to friends, neighbors, and anyone who cares about nature, Mother Earth, our relationship to our surrounding. Spread the word to anyone who will listen. 

We wish you peace and success in your endevors. May your life be blessed.

story:
SustainEarth is a small team of social entrepreneurs that just want to do our part to stop climate change while helping our underprivileged rural population. We've been working on this project since 2013 when we identified the drastic rural energy issues that our country faces.  

With this campaign we wish to raise awareness of clean cooking problems on a global level, and to provide sustainable solutions to the communities that face them.

THE PROBLEM

3 billion people around the planet cook their meals over an open flame or on a crude stove every day by burning wood, crop waste, and animal dung. That’s nearly half the population of the world, Over 166 million in India alone. These ways of cooking harm the environment as well as the people forced to use them. Deforestation, CO2 and methane emissions are caused by the use of firewood and animal waste – destroying the atmosphere and creating respiratory problems in the users.

This issue has been around as long as cooking has. Then in the 1960’s, Biogas came along as potential salvation – it failed.

WHAT HAPPENED?

Back in the 1960’s millions of Biogas units were installed in India, but quickly lost favor with the local people because the units did not function properly. They were complicated, broken easily, and were not maintained by the installers.

SO WHAT DO WE DO?

SustainEarth uses innovative Biogas technology to provide affordable, clean cooking gas to rural communities.

By rebranding the now-notorious Biogas product as Gau Gas and implementing new materials, new processes, and new technology SustainEarth will solve the problems faced by the last generation of Biogas users and perhaps change some minds about the usefulness of Biogas.

OUR TECHNOLOGY 

The Gau Gas digester is a low-cost hybrid flow biodigester that efficiently converts animal waste into clean, carbon-free cooking gas. By implementing our new SMART GauGas grid we can keep track of the productivity of each unit, ensuring that they are also functioning optimally. 


DOES BIOGAS ACTUALLY WORK?

Biogas is great. It’s an old idea that had great potential: turn a plentiful organic waste, in this case cow dung, into clean, convenient, reliable, and affordable cooking gas; eliminating a source of atmosphere pollution and deforestation in the process. Through recent developments we’ve managed to harness and take advantage of this potential, while improving upon the less-than-satisfactory aspects that turned many people away from it.



The units are easier to install, more reliable, easier to maintain. Advancements in technology now allow us to track the yield of units from our headquarters. We’ve established an efficient support system to ensure that all of our units are functioning at their best. If not, we fix them!




Biogas is asking for a second chance, and we see the worth in giving it one.

WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION CAN DO

We understand that climate change is a big, intimidating issue. You may be concerned that a small contribution won't help the problem. 

Fear not! Every single contribution will help. A dollar here, a dollar there, the quarters in your couch cushion, the pennies under your floor mat; it adds up! Here's the impact of only $100 with us:



With $250 we can afford an entire unit. Check out what kind of impact that has:


And if we reach our goal? 

Now, that's world-changing!

But we have a way to make it go even further.

PAY IT FORWARD

We're also in the process of developing a Pay-it-Forward system that will allow us to provide a Gau Gas unit to a farmer at no up-front cost to him, and to have that unit pay for the next farmer's unit. 

Here's how that works:

Donations from generous people like you go towards buying a Gau Gas unit for a local dairy farmer at no cost to him. The unit produces enough cooking gas for 3-4 hours of cooking a day, plenty for an average household. The unit also produces 10 kilograms of fertilizer a day which we sell to nearby agricultural farmers. Over time the dairy farmer will pay off the unit in small increments, while the funds collected from the fertilizer go to buy the next dairy farmer his own Gau Gas unit – creating a chain reaction of sustainable development. 'Self-sustaining sustainability,' if you will.


WHO DO WE HELP?

25 million households of rural India own cattle that produce enough manure to supplement all of their cooking gas needs.

With this campaign we will support a network of 50 dairy farmers in the district of Chittoor - the second highest milk producing district in India. This single campaign could help an entire community thrive, and perhaps beneficially impact the entire rural economy of India.  


These people are dairy farmers and agricultural workers with families to support and communities that rely on them. The installation of our Gau Gas units in these types of homes benefit entire communities and changes people’s lives.


SUSTAINEARTH IN THE MEDIA

will solve the problems faced by the last generation of Biogas users and
perhaps change some minds about the usefulness of Biogas.OUR TECHNOLOGY The Gau Gas digester is a low-cost hybrid flow biodigester that efficiently converts animal waste into clean, carbon-free cooking gas. By implementing our new SMART GauGas grid we can keep track of the productivity of each unit, ensuring that they are also functioning optimally. DOES BIOGAS ACTUALLY WORK?
Biogas is great. It’s an old idea that had great potential:
turn a plentiful organic waste, in this case cow dung, into clean, convenient,
reliable, and affordable cooking gas; eliminating a source of atmosphere
pollution and deforestation in the process. Through recent developments we’ve
managed to harness and take advantage of this potential, while improving upon
the less-than-satisfactory aspects that turned many people away from it. 
The units are easier to install, more reliable, easier to
maintain. Advancements in technology now allow us to track the yield of units
from our headquarters. We’ve established an efficient support system to ensure
that all of our units are functioning at their best. If not, we fix them!
Biogas is asking for a second chance, and we see the worth
in giving it one.WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION CAN DOWe understand that climate change is a big, intimidating issue. You may be concerned that a small contribution won't help the problem. Fear not! Every single contribution will help. A dollar here, a dollar there, the quarters in your couch cushion, the pennies under your floor mat; it adds up! Here's the impact of only $100 with us:With $250 we can afford an entire unit. Check out what kind of impact that has:And if we reach our goal? Now, that's world-changing!
But we have a way to make it go even further.

PAY IT FORWARD
We're also in the process of developing a Pay-it-Forward system that will allow us to provide a Gau Gas unit to a farmer at no up-front cost to him, and to have that unit pay for the next farmer's unit. 
Here's how that works:
Donations from generous people like you go towards buying a
Gau Gas unit for a local dairy farmer at no cost to him. The unit produces
enough cooking gas for 3-4 hours of cooking a day, plenty for an average
household. The unit also produces 10 kilograms of fertilizer a day which we
sell to nearby agricultural farmers. Over time the dairy farmer will pay off
the unit in small increments, while the funds collected from the fertilizer go
to buy the next dairy farmer his own Gau Gas unit – creating a chain reaction
of sustainable development. 'Self-sustaining sustainability,' if you will.



WHO DO WE HELP?
25 million households of
rural India own cattle that produce enough manure to supplement all of their
cooking gas needs.
With this campaign we will support a network of 50 dairy farmers in the district of Chittoor - the second highest milk producing district in India. This single campaign could help an entire community thrive, and perhaps beneficially impact the entire rural economy of India.  





These people are dairy farmers and agricultural workers with
families to support and communities that rely on them. The installation of our
Gau Gas units in these types of homes benefit entire communities and changes
people’s lives.

SUSTAINEARTH IN THE MEDIA

story:
Short Summary

Climate change is possibly the most critical issue facing this and the next generations. We are asking for your support to make it better understood and we are using comics as the venue for this.

So if you are interested in supporting an education project on climate change, THIS project is for you!

What We Need & What You Get

The objective is to help the next generation understand climate change. We will create a free downloable comic as part of the Comics Uniting Nations initiative (www.comicsunitingnations.org/) .

Comics Uniting Nations is a monumental partnership between a group of innovative nonprofits, working in close coordination with the United Nations Millennium Campaign and the United Nations Post-2015 Development Planning Team to make the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) accessible to the citizens of the world through comics. One of the SDGs is on climate change.

This Indiegogo project is supporting the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals in particular this comic is focused on Santa Claus taking on Climate Change. It is based on a story that was written for the BBC in 2009 http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8426269.stm )

The first Uniting Nations Comic ‘Chakra the Invincible’ was created by the great Stan Lee, Shared Devarajan and Gotham Chopra and can be read here www.yumpu.com/en/document/fullscreen/54544593/chakraun-comic-final-web

This comic will be written by Felix Dodds ( www.felixdodds.net/) and Michael Strauss, and the art by UK Marvel and 2000 AD comic artist John Charles (www.2000ad.org/?zone=covers&page=artist&choice=johnc&Comic=2000ad) .

We need to raise $30,000 to get this comic produced. The expenses are largely for the cost of hiring an artist, letterer, colorist, editor and final story writer to produce the comic and the expenses associated with putting the comic into digital format. 

We will launch the comic at a major United Nations climate event in the next year.

You can support us by making a contribution on the right-hand side by Credit Card/Debit Card.

In addition, you can redeem perks for your support such as:

• $30 – The comic in advance in.pdf format.

• $30 – A personal “thank-you” which will be in the comic

• $75 – Green Christmas printed comic in .pdf format, signed by the artist or authors. Only 100 copies available! 

• $75 –  T-shirt with Santa Claus and Elves. Only 100 available!

• $100 – Limited Edition poster (18x24). Only 100 available!

• $100 – *Special Edition* Elves for a Sustainable Planet T-shirt. Only 100 available!

• $500 – Banner advertisement on the back page– get an advertisement (PG rated) in the back of the comic book! (Limited to 6 Sponsors for the page)

•  $750 – Limited Edition page drawing prints , signed by cartoon artist  5 copies per page available  

•  $1000 – 30-minute Skype/Meeting chat room with author Felix Dodds and artist John Charles  + signed and printed comic + .pdf comic + personal thank-you card

• $1000 – Have you ever wanted to be in a comic? Make an appearance in the comic book as a character (for this issue only). Only four spaces available!

• $1200 – a half page advertisement!

• $2000 – a full page advertisement!

*Make sure you provide your correct mailing address and e-mail to receive these perks*

Production

The comic will be produced primarily after the campaign is over, so the comic will be sent to you a few months after the 45 days are up.

However, we will give you teasers, sketches, and tidbits on our Facebook page so you can learn more about the backstory in anticipation of the comic's release.

YOUR Impact

Help us to make climate change more understandable to the next generation. This is a positive and fun and we hope will with your help have a viral impact.

PUBLIC RELEASE:

We will be releasing the comic for you to download for free (whatever we can find that will allow us to post it for free)…but those who paid to get the comic e-mailed or printed will receive it FIRST and will receive the comic about a month AHEAD of everyone else.

SO, with that in mind, don’t be shy about donating at the $5 or $8 levels because EVERY dollar counts to making the comic come into existence.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't have pocket change to spare, you can still help us get the message out by sharing our campaign and sharing our videos on YouTube.

Use the indiegogo.com share tools to let others know and visit our pages here:

FACEBOOK: 

TWITTER: #greenchristmas  

ALSO! Please make sure you give us your proper address for whatever perk you redeem. If you have any questions, please direct them to Felix Dodds at fdodds27@gmail.com.

story:
The Recycle Your Electrons App

Hi, my name's Tim Worstall. I'm known, if I'm known at all, as a journalist (Forbes, The Register, most UK papers at one time or another) writing on matters economic, tech, environmental. I'm usually an as dry as dust free marketeer but this project here is nothing to do with politics.
What we want to do is test how well people have absorbed the idea that it's better if we recycle everything. To do this we're going to create an app that claims to help in recycling something that just isn't nor cannot be recycled. The electrons in the current in a smartphone. The more people who download the free app the more we know that message, recycle everything! has been driven home.
This project is a reasonably serious piece of social science. We're going to do this in different languages and countries, we already have available stated preferences for recycling in different countries (through Pew Research, various European attitude surveys and so on). This will allow us to test revealed preference (by downloading) as against stated preference (what people tell pollsters) and economists like that sort of thing. Because they're pretty sure that what people do (revealed pref) is a better guide to what people really think than what people say (stated pref). That latter is easy enough to influence through social pressure and even social expectation. 
It's also clearly at least on the edge of being a practical joke. Given that the average life span of an electron is somewhere past the heat death of the universe they're not something that need recycling. Some tiny fraction do indeed meet an untimely death as a result of the positron emission form of radioactive decay from the trace amounts of uranium and or thorium in the metals the phone is made from but it's a trivial amount. So, err, har har, people will be downloading an app that doesn't really do anything.
We might also describe it as performance art: anyone who looks at this page will know that the app doesn't in fact recycle what cannot be recycled. But how many people will do that and how many will be taken in by any claims made? 
All of the above means we're not going to charge for the app of course.
What We Need
We need to do several things. We need to write an app of course but that, at this level, is simply trivial. Not something we would trouble your pocketbooks for. The core of the actual app will be simply the monitoring of the current flowing through the phone. A simple calculation then tells us how many electrons that is and we can flash up a little info box saying "x squillions of electrons have not been destroyed in the operation of your phone". We're not going to say that the app has recycled them, that would be untrue. Only that it has been monitoring this process, which will be true.
We also need to make the app actually do something. Apps that do nothing at all are rather frowned upon these days. So, we'll dig the open source version of a messaging app out of one of the vaults, put a skin on it and so the app will indeed do something. This is again trivial and we don't need to call on your resources to do it.
There will be one version of this messaging app without the claims about electron recycling and one with. It will be the differential take up of these otherwise two identical apps which will tell us the most.
What we do need help with is translation. Not so much of the app itself, as there's such source available in most languages even all. It's translating the skin and most importantly, the publicity material. We can work for free on our little joke, performance art project, but we can't start asking translators to give up their bread and butter for our social science project. Well, we could, but we wouldn't get all that far we think.
So that's what we're looking for. There's some 20-25 languages worth targeting just here in Europe and even if it's just a few hundred $ per language that pretty soon adds up. That's why we're asking for the $7,000 we are (in the video I mention a slightly larger sum, that's because obviously we are also paying for some of this, plus doing the near trivial programming ourselves). Pretty much all of that is about translation, with a bit going to set up Cloud space, URL and so on, as and when people start using or testing it for sending messages. If anyone starts doing that in any volume of course then we've got to find more cash and fast, but that's not quite what we think will happen.
It's also not what we're really trying to test: we want to see the difference between just another messaging app and just another messaging app that claims to monitor how well electrons are being recycled. How much have people absorbed the idea that recycling of everything is a great idea? 
What can we give you in return for your support? Our thanks, obviously, a copy of the program itself of course, but as that's going to be free on release that's not hugely, amazingly, valuable. I had though of offering copies of my books until it was pointed out that people would probably want fewer of my books the more money they donated. 
So what we can offer is anything up to $10 is our thanks and a copy, $10 to $50 to be listed in the small print as a supporter of the project and anything above $50 as a sponsor in larger type.
Plus, of course, everyone will get a copy of those results from the experiment. Are there variations in take up across countries, how do those vary against stated propensities to recycle? 
If we're short of the total amount then we'll simply do less translation and do it in fewer countries. If we go over then we'll simply do more, both of marketing in each language, and expanding the languages.
As to what the impact on the wider world is, well, that's all rather in the eye of the beholder. We do think it's interesting to try and test revealed as against expressed preferences. The difference between what people say and what they do. And there's no doubt that we are all being, repeatedly, told that recycling is a good thing, whatever it is that we're recycling. So do people actually act that way? How important this is to you will obviously depend upon your view of social science results.
Or, alternatively, you might just cackle with glee at the idea of finding out how many people think it important to monitor the recycling of electrons.
The people donating their programming time to this have done everything from the Swiss parking meter system to image processing applications for DoD. Delivering the code isn't going to be a problem in the slightest. I as a tech and business journalist can do the PR material in English (and American, two slightly different languages), the piece we need to outsource is the translations. We know how to do and or manage all of those processes.

Risks

There are risks in everything: one of my old teachers used to say that we cannot guarantee anything, as Concorde might fall on our heads. That slightly went out of favour as an expression when one did actually fall on the head of that poor lady cleaning a Paris hotel room. But the point holds, some risks cannot be managed. The more normal risks, that we run away with a money pot and buy fast women, slow horses and drink, the rest of it we just waste, are best managed by the fact that I do have a public profile, one that would not be enhanced by doing just that. And I make a good living from that reputation: it's worth more to me that the amount this program is likely to raise. That I am at least a semi-public figure is the protection there.

Want To Help But Not Spend?

At this point the traditional appeal. If this isn't something you want to donate to that's fine. But you could spread the word about the project if you like. Mobilise the social network.
The other way any who have fluency in any non-English derivative could help is in translating text into that language that you have and we do not. In the first iteration of the experiment it would be of the order of two pages of text as the needed amount for any language, as long as our source already supports it.

story:
Summary 

Protecting the environment is a key policy objective for us at Limitless Fuels. This biodiesel production facility will be a perfect demonstration of how technology can be used to turn waste into an environment-friendly fuel. Biodiesel is an effective alternative to fossil fuel. It delivers similar energy performance and can be used in standard diesel engines without the need for any modifications. We hope that this project will encourage even wider acceptance and use of biodiesel in South Africa as this will not only help meet our energy needs, it will also reduce greenhouse gas emissions. 

How This Idea Was Born

My name is Alexander and my dream is to build the first commercial Biodiesel processing plant in the West Coast of South Africa. It all started when my father started distributing bulk cooking oil and occasionally collected the used oil and disposed of it appropriately. While visiting him I noticed a stockpile of about 3000 liters due to be disposed and thought to myself it's a pity all this oil will be going to waste. A few days later I started doing research into the Biodiesel process and soon it consumed me as the idea of renewable energy picked up momentum. I compiled a business plan and started approaching investors.  Because Biodiesel is in it's infancy in South Africa my idea was met with excitement and some doubt. I proceeded to build a small make shift processor and produced my first batch of Biodiesel, I started by sending samples for laboratory analysis and received feedback that I produced nearly perfect Biodiesel according to the South African National Standards. With that information in hand and some persistence the owner of the local fishing company pledged 50% of the funds required to build a Biodiesel processing plant capable of producing 40000 Liters per month.
 I need to generate another $29,782 to be able to build my Biodiesel plant. 


My Ambition Projected 


Cost Breakdown

Biodiesel Plant                                                $24,450
Supplies                                                            $5,000
Truck with 5000L Diesel Tank                  $14,891
Overheads for 6 months                             $10,330
Total                                                                   $59,564

3D Render of Biodiesel Plant 


Help Fuel My Dream

Help me build this Plant, this plant will be the first Biodiesel Plant in the West Coast of South Africa and will have a massive impact not only in the local aquaculture and farming industry but also within the community where job loses are linked to fluctuating fuel prices and a lower consistent fuel price will give companies the confidence to employ additional people. 


Advantages of Biodiesel

  • It costs less than regular diesel
  • It contains no or little sulphur
  • It has a higher Cetane rating that improves the efficiency of compression ignition
  • NO engine modifications are necessary to use biodiesel on any diesel engine
  • It is non-flammable, non-hazardous, non-toxic & environmentally friendly
  • It has a flash point greater than 120°C while fossil diesel is approx. 70°C
  • Users can switch between biodiesel and regular diesel as they wish
  • It has superior cleaning properties over all other regular diesel
  • It provides much better engine lubrication than regular diesel
  • It produces 75% less exhaust smoke emissions
  • It produces 80% less carbon dioxide emissions
  • It is made from new or used cooking oil
  • It extends engine life by up to 200%
  • It is safe to store and handle
  • It is a renewable fuel
  • It is a “green” fuel

Potential Clientele

The Port of Saldanha will be undergoing major refurbishments and upgrades in the near future to accommodate larger / more vessels. This will create a huge demand for diesel, it will benefit these companies greatly to opt for Biodiesel  as this will reduce their carbon emissions. The premises I'm currently vetting is situated less than 1km away from the port.  

We will also be able to cater for the local fishing industry which on it's own will create a demand for our total monthly fuel production.


Risks & Challenges

I've been fortunate to have a Business Planner / Analyst  on board during the planning / design / build / trade stages of this business at no additional cost to Limitless Fuels to mitigate possible risk and improve efficiency. 


Closing Statement 

I've decided to keep this as brief as possible, if you have any queries please don't hesitate to contact me on the below e-mail address.
e: alexander@limitlessgroup.co.za

Please share this Campaign on as many platforms as you can as well as the Indiegogo share tools.


Interested in the Biodiesel making process? 

Discovery How it's Made Biodiesel
story_txt:
Summary 
Protecting the environment is a key policy objective for us
at Limitless Fuels. This biodiesel production facility will be a perfect demonstration
of how technology can be used to turn waste into an environment-friendly fuel. Biodiesel is an effective alternative
to fossil fuel. It delivers similar energy performance and can be used in
standard diesel engines without the need for any modifications. We hope that
this project will encourage even wider acceptance and use of biodiesel in South
Africa as this will not only help meet our energy needs, it will also reduce
greenhouse gas emissions. 
How This Idea Was Born
My name is Alexander and my dream is to build the first commercial Biodiesel processing plant in the West Coast of South Africa. It all started when my father started distributing bulk cooking oil and occasionally collected the used oil and disposed of it appropriately. While visiting him I noticed a stockpile of about 3000 liters due to be disposed and thought to myself it's a pity all this oil will be going to waste. A few days later I started doing research into the Biodiesel process and soon it consumed me as the idea of renewable energy picked up momentum. I compiled a business plan and started approaching investors.  Because Biodiesel is in it's infancy in South Africa my idea was met with excitement and some doubt. I proceeded to build a small make shift processor and produced my first batch of Biodiesel, I started by sending samples for laboratory analysis and received feedback that I produced nearly perfect Biodiesel according to the South African National Standards. With that information in hand and some persistence the owner of the local fishing company pledged 50% of the funds required to build a Biodiesel processing plant capable of producing 40000 Liters per month.
 I need to generate another $29,782 to be able to build my Biodiesel plant. 

My Ambition Projected 




Cost Breakdown
Biodiesel Plant                                                $24,450
Supplies                                                            $5,000
Truck with 5000L Diesel Tank                  $14,891
Overheads for 6 months                             $10,330
Total                                                                   $59,564

3D Render of Biodiesel Plant 




Help Fuel My Dream

Help me build this Plant, this plant will be the first Biodiesel Plant in the West Coast of South Africa and will have a massive impact not only in the local aquaculture and farming industry but also within the community where job loses are linked to fluctuating fuel prices and a lower consistent fuel price will give companies the confidence to employ additional people. 

    
Advantages of Biodiesel



It costs
less than regular diesel
It contains
no or little sulphur
It has a
higher Cetane rating that improves the efficiency of compression ignition
NO engine
modifications are necessary to use biodiesel on any diesel engine
It is
non-flammable, non-hazardous, non-toxic & environmentally friendly
It has a
flash point greater than 120°C while fossil diesel is approx. 70°C
Users can
switch between biodiesel and regular diesel as they wish
It has
superior cleaning properties over all other regular diesel
It provides
much better engine lubrication than regular diesel
It produces
75% less exhaust smoke emissions
It produces
80% less carbon dioxide emissions
It is made
from new or used cooking oil
It extends
engine life by up to 200%
It is safe
to store and handle
It is a
renewable fuel
It is a
“green” fuel


Potential Clientele

The Port of Saldanha will be undergoing major refurbishments and upgrades in the near future to accommodate larger / more vessels. This will create a huge demand for diesel, it will benefit these companies greatly to opt for Biodiesel  as this will reduce their carbon emissions. The premises I'm currently vetting is situated less than 1km away from the port.  

We will also be able to cater for the local fishing industry which on it's own will create a demand for our total monthly fuel production.

Risks & Challenges

 I've been fortunate to have a Business Planner / Analyst  on board during the planning / design / build / trade stages of this business at no additional cost to Limitless Fuels to mitigate possible risk and improve efficiency. 
    
Closing Statement 
I've decided to keep this as brief as possible, if you have any queries please don't hesitate to contact me on the below e-mail address.
e: alexander@limitlessgroup.co.za

Please share this Campaign on as many platforms as you can as well as the Indiegogo share tools.

Discovery How it's Made Biodiesel

story:
It’s true. The grasslands may not seem like the world’s hottest eco destination. They’re not as colorful as the rainforests or coral reefs. But you don’t have to visit the grasslands to understand the power these ecosystems hold. Like the power to reverse climate change. The power to prevent floods, fire, drought, famine, and violence. And even the power to end world poverty. But through mismanagement, the world’s grasslands are transforming into sandy wastelands.

The Savory Institute is at the forefront of the fight to save the grasslands. But we can’t do it without you.

Since our founding in 2009, we have been working tirelessly to restore the natural cycles of the grasslands. The engine driving this restorative process? Grazing animals like cattle, sheep, and goats, properly managed. These animals till and fertilize the earth. Their manure combines with decomposing vegetation to build soil, preventing erosion and flooding. Grass flourishes, removing more carbon from the atmosphere. And land managers can raise more nutrient-dense food to feed the world.
 

All of this is made possible via a revolutionary process called Holistic Management, which empowers managers to make wise decisions about their land. How do we spread the word about this process? Physical spaces called Savory Hubs, located in key areas around the world.

These hubs are built and run by local innovators and entrepreneurs on the cutting edge of land management. They’re an invaluable resource for other managers in the region — a reservoir of information, training, demonstration, and fresh thinking around regenerative and profitable management. We support these hubs by giving them the tools and resources to help land managers succeed.
 

Each Savory Hub impacts 10 million hectares (24 million acres) of land. By 2025, we’ll have everything in place to impact 1 one billion hectares — the critical mass needed to start reversing climate change. But big changes take small steps. Our goal is to see the creation of 10 new Savory Hubs each year. Your donations will help make the next generation of hubs a reality. Together, we can reverse climate change, end global hunger, and save the grasslands from turning into wastelands. 


The Problem

Currently, the intergovernmental efforts centered on climate change focus solely on reducing emissions from burning fossil fuels. While this absolutely MUST happen, it does nothing to address the legacy load of greenhouse gases already in our atmosphere. Without a way to remove the existing carbon dioxide and other warming agents from the atmosphere, our planet is doomed. We’re currently seeing the effects with massive storms, floods and droughts. Those effects are only going to get worse.
  

The Solution

You may have seen our founder, Allan Savory, in his TED Talk which has become one of the top 100 most viewed TED talks of all time with nearly 3.5 million views on the TED site alone.

Some of the world’s wealthiest philanthropists and brightest minds have sought to develop carbon capture technology that pulls carbon out of the air and either puts it to use in manufacturing or stores it away safely. While some technologies along these lines have been explored, the reality is that none of them can begin to address the problem on a global scale, and all are likely to be accompanied by unintended consequences.

The solution must be biological. We must look to natural processes recognizing that all life is made up of carbon that cycles between Earth and its atmosphere. Utilizing the power of sunlight, through the process of photosynthesis, plants remove carbon dioxide (CO2) from our atmosphere and with water (H2O) from the soil, form complex carbohydrates (sugars) - the carbon comes from the CO2 and the hydrogen from the H2O to form those carbohydrates. What’s left over is oxygen which is released back into the atmosphere. And low-and-behold we and all the other mammals on this planet are hooked on the stuff. So with the current overload of CO2 in the atmosphere, and our need to breathe, we want as much photosynthesis to happen as possible.


 Watch the Full Episode Here

Why Grasslands?

Although all plants photosynthesize, no vegetation type beats grasses, which cover a greater area of the earth’s landmass than any other. And if that wasn’t enough, unlike forests, grasslands store most of the carbon they sequester from the atmosphere deep under the soil surface as organic matter, which actually increases fertility and enhances soil life in countless ways. That is why the great grain growing regions of the world are former grasslands, not forests. 

Grasslands are the most important ecosystem for human civilization. When healthy, they purify the air, absorb and filter water and allow it to infiltrate back into underground reservoirs, they support immeasurable wildlife and biodiversity, and they build the deepest most fertile soils on the planet. 

Grasslands are also home to more than 1 billion people who depend on them for their food and livelihoods.


What is Holistic Planned Grazing?

Surprisingly though, grasses need to be grazed to thrive. At first it may sound counter-intuitive, but in areas of the world that receive intermittent rainfall and humidity, nature employs grazers to assist in biological decay. Grazers carry healthy colonies of microbes in their rumen. These microbes have a symbiotic relationship with their herbivorous hosts in that they are able to digest the grass for the animals in exchange for a warm, moist, dark place to thrive, kind of like a microbial womb.

In the past, large wild herds of herbivores such as caribou, buffalo, or wildebeest occupied the grasslands - grazing, defecating, stomping and salivating as they moved across them. Over time, most wild herds disappeared and were replaced by humans and their small numbers of sedentary livestock. Without the timely stomping and excrement of large numbers of animals, and the subsequent period of recovery when animals moved on, the cycle of biological decay in these grasslands was interrupted and the once-rich soils and thriving prairies began to degrade. Many of the grass plants were left ungrazed. Their dried-off leaves blocked sunlight from reaching the growth buds at their bases and they started to die. Much of the soil surface was left unbroken and unfertilized, making it difficult for new grass seedlings to establish.

But we all have been taught that grazing animals, particularly domestic livestock, can do great damage to landscapes. We’ve seen it from our cars as we zoom down the highway and the denuded countryside hums by. The difference is that domestic livestock are usually scattered, rather than bunched in herds, and remain in one place. At times they are rotated among pastures, but their rotations move too quickly or too slowly to match the needs of the plants, soils, and other life forms. Worse yet, Confined Animal Feeding Operations (CAFOs) move all the animals to one place, transport feed too them and haul away their wastes. These industrial animal factories are prone to disease and are a source of air and water pollution that adversely affects the communities neighboring them.


Grasslands need to be properly grazed and grazing animals need to be on the grasslands. To mimic nature the animals need to be bunched and moving to provide the plants enough time to fully recover between grazings. Nature does this by using predator pressure to keep the grazing animals constantly traveling and impacting new areas of land. Domestic livestock need humans with smart and comprehensive, holistic plans and great execution.

So Holistic Planned Grazing is much more than rotational grazing and grass-finishing livestock. It means land managers are planning for a whole lot of considerations, including the desired outcomes for their land, livestock, wildlife, and business, as well as their family’s quality of life. They plan the movement of the livestock as much as a year in advance, and re-plan on-goingly as they test their progress toward the achievement of those desired outcomes - day in and day out.

A recent study conducted in Australia demonstrated a 400% increase in permanent soil carbon on land under Holistic Planned Grazing, relative to the neighboring land managed conventionally.


Increased Water Supply

On degraded or exposed land, water evaporates or runs off instead of soaking into the soil where it is available for plants and living organisms and recharges water tables. This runoff and evaporation leads to the increasing frequency and severity of floods and droughts – even if there has been no change in rainfall in a specific region.
 

Holistic Planned Grazing helps cover the soil surface, a crucial first step in stopping degradation. Reduction of bare ground improves the effectiveness of the available rainfall by minimizing evaporation and runoff.  Productivity increases, and with it organic matter in the soil, which in turn increases its ability to hold water, reducing the risk of floods and droughts. Case studies have shown a 40% increase in water holding capacity on land under Holistic Planned Grazing compared to adjacent land that had no grazing on it.

 

Food Security and Poverty

In the world’s vast grasslands, livestock production is the primary source of food production. Healthier land can support more livestock, and more livestock, means more wealth. When managed holistically in conjunction with livestock, case studies have shown a 4x increase in profitability* as a result of better soil and land health.

Properly managed livestock can be incorporated into cropping systems as well. Prior to planting, a concentrated herd moves through a cropfield, the hooves breaking up the soil surface and trampling down crop residues to cover the soil, and dung and urine fertilizing it. This treatment promotes good germination, enhances water infiltration, decreases evaporation, and eliminates the need for additional fertilizers, plowing or ripping. Communal farmers using the technique in Africa have increased maize yields by over 350% with no additional inputs.
 

Holistic planned grazing is successful because it is cost-effective, highly scalable and nature-based.  It is sustainable because it increases wealth and quality-of-life for landowners without compromising the long-term viability of the resource base.


Healthy Soil

The Savory Institute focuses its work on grasslands for all the reasons outlined above. We believe grasslands provide the greatest hope for ensuring our climate remains conducive to human life.

For the sake of humanity’s future, our species must come together and recognize soil as the only scalable and suitable vessel for the excess carbon in our atmosphere. Healthy soil is a living dynamic ecosystem and it is the foundation of life on Earth. It is the basis for a sustainable and productive agriculture.

In the air carbon in the form of carbon dioxide is a liability, heating our planet to dangerous levels. In the soil it is a source of fertility, holding onto water, and supporting more life. For these reasons we have started a multi-partner initiative called Soil for Climate, and have launched the #SoilManifesto in conjunction with the COP21 climate talks in Paris. Our aim is to unite Team Humanity in demanding that our governments begin looking at grassland soils as the ultimate carbon sink, and a crucial part of the solution to climate change.


The Challenge

To achieve lasting success and reverse our world’s current trajectory towards impending doom, Savory Institute recognizes that we must have united global action. For years the holistic management movement, including organizations before ours, trained individuals and equipped them with the tools to change their own lives and land. But these individuals did not have the resources or the support network to unite across continents and truly become a movement. Six years ago when the Savory Institute was formed, its sole task was to develop strategies and tools to orchestrate a truly global movement. It is the only way to effectively change the existing paradigm about grassland soils and livestock’s role in keeping them healthy.


What is a Hub

To create the level of change necessary to start moving our planet toward global-scale soil regeneration and thriving grasslands, we realized we needed to cultivate a worldwide network of teams of entrepreneurial people working within their own cultural context.

Each node or Hub, as we call them, could act as a change-agent offering Holistic Management trainings, one-on-one consulting, and on-going contextually relevant implementation support. They would also provide local managers with the tools needed to properly measure the health of the land and track its progress. They would become the representatives in their region of our organization as well as a much larger movement that their local and state governments could access. They would also play the role of entrepreneurial incubators, and project managers, developing enterprises in both established and emerging markets that provide triple-bottom-line returns for land managers in their area.

Over the last 6 years, our BHAG (Big Hairy Audacious Goal) - our Hub dream - has become a reality. We now have close to 40 partners that have become Savory Network Hubs or are in the process of being accredited. They include individuals, non-profits, for-profits, NGOs, and cooperatives - there is no one type of organization.  Each Hub goes through a year-long on-boarding process. During this time they get facilitation training on how to be good trainers and influencers in their community. The get the most up to date training in Holistic Management, plus training in business management and marketing, including one-on-one coaching as they develop their business plans. We also connect Hubs through a communications platform that enables the network as a whole to sharpen and enhance each Hub’s skills.

Armed with the Savory Institute’s curriculum and state of the art data management tools, each Hub makes its own plan on how to impact its region and to be financially sustainable in providing local solutions to land degradation, food and water security, and community empowerment. 

Each Hub has a holistically managed demonstration site, where all aspects of Holistic Management, including Holistic Planned Grazing, are embraced. These sites serve as a training venue and learning laboratory, but also as a center of action, research and excellence. They give local people of all skill levels a place to gather and commune with the land, learn the holistic planning processes at their own pace, and expand their knowledge and skills in a safe environment with no risk to their own livelihood.


Join Us in Creating a Future of Hope

With your gift you’ll be helping us empower pastoralists, ranchers and farmers around the globe through the establishment of Hubs to assist them in their efforts. You’ll help us reach even further into some of the world’s most remote regions, to help bring the most refined tools and curriculum to the 500 million family farmers feeding the majority of the world’s population.

In the hustle and bustle of everyday life it’s easy to forget the environment we depend on. But we ask you to please consider helping us save the grasslands in your year-end giving.

The time is now. There is nothing more important for the sake of humanity than reversing climate change and desertification and the solution is so simple. We don’t need to develop new technology, or vast infrastructure, or pool the world’s resources, or amass inconceivable treasuries.  We simply need to reach land managers and show them how they can modify the use of the tools and resources they have now.

Over the last few decades, Allan Savory and the Savory Institute have had success on every habitable continent and positively impacted over 50 million hectares already. Just since 2013 when we launched our Hub strategy, over 10 million hectares have been positively influenced. With our burgeoning network of thriving Hubs that number is now growing exponentially! 

Join us in restoring the health of the grasslands, regenerating soils, and reversing climate change.

 

Perks

Check out these awesome swag items listed in the perks for donating:
BRAND NEW Posters Celebrating the Grasslands:

BRAND NEW Savory Institute T-shirts:

Recommended Reading

            >


Special Thanks

We want to give a special thanks to the following people:
Free Range Studios for producing the video bumper and visual graphics
Gabe Golden and Golden Productions for producing our video
TED for their production of the infographic series
Peter Byck and Carbon Nation for allowing us to feature their clip Soil Carbon Cowboys
Seth Itzkan for allowing us to use some of his footage

non-profits, for-profits, NGOs, and cooperatives - there is no one type of organization.
 Each Hub goes through a year-long on-boarding process. During this time
they get facilitation training on how to be good trainers and influencers in
their community. The get the most up to date training in Holistic Management,
plus training in business management and marketing, including one-on-one
coaching as they develop their business plans. We also connect Hubs through a
communications platform that enables the network as a whole to sharpen and
enhance each Hub’s skills. 


Armed with
the Savory Institute’s curriculum and state of the art data management tools,
each Hub makes its own plan on how to impact its region and to be financially
sustainable in providing local solutions to land degradation, food and water
security, and community empowerment. 






Each Hub has a holistically managed demonstration site, where all aspects of Holistic Management, including Holistic Planned Grazing, are embraced. These sites serve as a training venue and learning laboratory, but also as a center of action, research and excellence. They give local people of all skill levels a place to gather and commune with the land, learn the holistic planning processes at their own pace, and expand their knowledge and skills in a safe environment with no risk to their own livelihood.

Join Us
in Creating a Future of Hope


With your
gift you’ll be helping us empower pastoralists, ranchers and
farmers around the globe through the establishment of Hubs to assist them in
their efforts. You’ll help us reach even further into some of the world’s most
remote regions, to help bring the most refined tools and curriculum to the 500
million family farmers feeding the majority of the world’s population. 
In the
hustle and bustle of everyday life it’s easy to forget the environment we
depend on. But we ask you to please consider helping us save the grasslands in
your year-end giving. 


The time is
now. There is nothing more important for the sake of humanity than reversing
climate change and desertification and the solution is so simple. We don’t need
to develop new technology, or vast infrastructure, or pool the world’s
resources, or amass inconceivable treasuries.  We simply need to reach
land managers and show them how they can modify the use of the tools and
resources they have now. 

Over the
last few decades, Allan Savory and the Savory Institute have had success on
every habitable continent and positively impacted over 50 million hectares
already. Just since 2013 when we launched our Hub strategy, over 10 million
hectares have been positively influenced. With our burgeoning network of
thriving Hubs that number is now growing exponentially! 

Join us in restoring the health of the
grasslands, regenerating soils, and reversing climate change.




 
Perks
Check out these awesome swag items listed in the perks for donating:
BRAND NEW Posters Celebrating the Grasslands:

BRAND NEW Savory Institute T-shirts:

Recommended Reading

            >


Special Thanks
We want to give a special thanks to the following people:
Free Range Studios for producing the video bumper and visual graphicsGabe Golden and Golden Productions for producing our videoTED for their production of the infographic seriesPeter Byck and Carbon Nation for allowing us to feature their clip Soil Carbon CowboysSeth Itzkan for allowing us to use some of his footage

story:
About the Camp

The Next Generation Climate Justice Action Camp (NGCJAC) is a seven day action camp to empower youth around the state of Oregon and northern California by providing age-appropriate training and mentoring. The workshops, trainings, and activities will provide a group of approximately 30-40 young activists with the tools and underlying information that they need in order to properly engage in systemic climate justice organizing with a cross-movement emphasis. Teens will come together to form alliances, learn from experienced mentors and frontline organizers, and gain skills in a dedicated setting.

The accelerating climate disaster is intensifying the need for unified action and diverse partnerships more than ever before. Our present generation must be ready to confront this global crisis that connects the environment, economy, energy and social justice. Unfortunately, most public school classrooms or books do not offer the appropriate lessons on constitutional rights, liberties and organizing as community members. Without these lessons, our young generation is missing an important foundation on which to base their participation in society. Removing the knowledge barrier is a crucial step in order to plant the seed for successful and healthy activism.


We need your support

Over 90% of the teens who attend the camp receive a full or partial scholarship, so we rely on the support of people like you to fund the camp. We focus of giving opportunities to undeserved communities, so the majority of the teens who attend the camp come from a low-income community and can't afford the cost of a traditional summer camp.

Not only do we provide the camp at little to no cost for most of the teens, but we also cover the transportation costs of getting to camp.

Your donation will help cover:

  • Van rentals for transportation
  • Food for the camp
  • Scholarships for teens
  • Space rental
  • And all the little costs associated with organizing a camp
Your donation we help make it easier to get more teens to the action camp and empower them with the skills to take action on climate change!
