story:
Short Summary

The founding members of this program are Joe Parrilli and Brad Avery.  Joe is a seasoned veteran of the high tech and energy industries.  Brad is a Grammy award winning, world renowned musician and an original member of the rock band Third Day. We found a way to reduce the risk of Crude Oil Train Accidents that put the Safety of Citizens and the surrounding Environment in Jeopardy.

Oil & Gas production has been rapidly expanding in the United States over the last 10 years. The introduction of fracking methods and various other new technologies have enabled crude oil production to sky-rocket.  This sudden ramp-up in production means more crude oil must be transported to the refineries over existing infrastructure – primarily through rail car and trucking transportation channels. As the volume of crude oil transported over rail cars increases, the number of rail car accidents also increase proportionally making the amount of crude oil gallons spilled a frightening dilemma with catastrophic results. 

There are approximately 150,000 DOT 111 tank cars currently in operation today. These tank cars have proven to be a weak link in the crude oil transportation process.  Intense regulatory pressure has been mounting to have these tank cars modified and ultimately replaced. Currently more than one million barrels of oil are transported by train across the United States every day. The volume of oil shipped by rail has increased 50-fold in just 5 years. Even though the Oil & Gas industry is currently in decline, most experts expect a recovery that will cause a rapid surge of production and transport in the next 12 to 24 months. This sudden surge will overwhelm the rail car transport system and we will experience a very aggressive “hockey-stick” increase in devastating rail car accidents. 

On May 1st, 2015, the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) and the Department of Transportation (DOT) issued a final ruling. This final ruling was intended to reduce the consequences and, in some instances, to reduce the probability of accidents involving trains transporting large quantities of flammable liquids.  While intentions to create a safer rail transportation vessel are founded in this design, a previous flaw remains.  A breach in this tank STILL risks the entire payload as well as endangers the communities and environments nearby! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $40,000.00 to cover the COST to PATENT the Honeycomb Cargo design.
  • We developed a revolutionary design that will significantly decrease the risk of oil train explosions.
  • This funding will support the long and grueling patent process that will enable prototype construction and 3rd party testing to meet stringent regulations for transport of hazmat and other volatile organic compounds. 
  • We will apply all funds to the continuation of our campaign to save the communities and the environment along the railways that will be impacted by oil train rail car disasters.

The Impact

One of the downsides of the recent increase in oil production has been the devastating rail car crashes that have plagued the United States, Canada and other countries around the world. These rail car accidents have caused significant damage to the environment and to the health and safety of the surrounding communities. In some instances, loss of life has been reported. 

While it’s obvious that these accidents are getting the attention of the Railroad Industry and the U.S. Department of Transportation – many critics believe the rules and regulations that have just been finalized on May 1st 2015 will prove to be insufficient.

Some feel that simply strengthening the rail cars with re-enforced steel is equivalent to placing a band aid on a deep wound. 

The single entity DOT 111, 1232 and DOT 117 tank cars all have a common inherent design flaw.  And while strengthening the hull and hatches may seem like a good idea on the surface, these changes actually exacerbate the problem and ensure that the design flaw remains on the rail system even longer and puts even more communities and our environment at even greater risk.

Risks & Challenges

  • This innovative solution will face many obstacles and will require adoption by the railroad and oil industries as well as the U.S. DOT.
  • We have approached the U.S. DOT, several U.S. Senators and some of the more vocal local governments along the rail ways asking for their support and guidance.
  • We are also engaging the rail car manufacturers and the oil & gas exploration & production companies to show them our design and how much money they will save by deploying this solution. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute, please send a note to your state's U.S. Senator(s) asking for their support.
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word!

Saving the environment and protecting lives isn't easy but together we can do it! Thank you very much for your help!!  We can't make this happen without you!!!
story_txt:
Short Summary The founding members of this program are Joe Parrilli and Brad Avery.  Joe is a seasoned veteran of the high tech and energy industries.  Brad is a Grammy award winning, world renowned musician and an original member of the rock band Third Day. We found a way to reduce the risk of Crude Oil Train Accidents
that put the Safety of Citizens and the surrounding Environment in Jeopardy.
Oil & Gas production has been rapidly expanding in the United
  States over the last 10 years. The introduction
of fracking methods and various other new technologies have enabled crude oil
production to sky-rocket.  This sudden
ramp-up in production means more crude oil must be transported to the
refineries over existing infrastructure – primarily through rail car and
trucking transportation channels. As the volume of crude oil transported over
rail cars increases, the number of rail car accidents also increase
proportionally making the amount of crude oil gallons spilled a frightening
dilemma with catastrophic results. 
There are approximately 150,000 DOT 111 tank cars currently
in operation today. These tank cars have proven to be a weak link in the crude
oil transportation process.  Intense
regulatory pressure has been mounting to have these tank cars modified and
ultimately replaced. Currently more than one million barrels
of oil are transported by train across the United States every day. The volume of oil shipped by rail has increased 50-fold
in just 5 years. Even though the Oil & Gas industry is
currently in decline, most experts expect a recovery that will cause a rapid
surge of production and transport in the next 12 to 24 months. This sudden
surge will overwhelm the rail car transport system and we will experience a
very aggressive “hockey-stick” increase in devastating rail car accidents. 

On May 1st, 2015,
the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) and the
Department of Transportation (DOT) issued a final ruling. This final ruling was
intended to reduce the consequences and, in some instances, to reduce the
probability of accidents involving trains transporting large quantities of
flammable liquids.  While intentions to create a safer rail transportation
vessel are founded in this design, a previous flaw remains.  A
breach in this tank STILL risks the entire payload as well as endangers the
communities and environments nearby!    What We Need & What You Get


We need $40,000.00 to cover the COST to PATENT the Honeycomb Cargo design.
We developed a revolutionary design that will significantly decrease the risk of oil train explosions.
This funding will support the long and grueling patent process that will enable prototype construction and 3rd party testing to meet stringent regulations for transport of hazmat and other volatile organic compounds.  We will apply all funds to the continuation of our campaign to save the communities and the environment along the railways that will be impacted by oil train rail car disasters.    The Impact 
One of the downsides of the recent increase in oil
production has been the devastating rail car crashes that have plagued the United
  States, Canada
and other countries around the world. These rail car accidents have caused
significant damage to the environment and to the health and safety of the
surrounding communities. In some instances, loss of life has been
reported.  
While it’s obvious that these accidents are getting the
attention of the Railroad Industry and the U.S. Department of Transportation –
many critics believe the rules and regulations that have just been finalized on
May 1st 2015 will prove to
be insufficient.
Some feel that simply strengthening the rail cars with
re-enforced steel is equivalent to placing a band aid on a deep wound.  
The single entity DOT 111, 1232 and DOT 117 tank cars all
have a common inherent design flaw.  And
while strengthening the hull and hatches may seem like a good idea on the
surface, these changes actually exacerbate the problem and ensure that the
design flaw remains on the rail system even longer and puts even more
communities and our environment at even greater risk.   Risks & Challenges

This innovative solution will face many obstacles and will require adoption by the railroad and oil industries as well as the U.S. DOT. We have approached the U.S. DOT, several U.S. Senators and some of the more vocal local governments along the rail ways asking for their support and guidance.
We are also engaging the rail car manufacturers and the oil & gas exploration & production companies to show them our design and how much money they will save by deploying this solution.     Other Ways You Can Help 
If you can't contribute, please send a note to your state's U.S. Senator(s) asking for their support. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word!   Saving the environment and protecting lives isn't easy but together we can do it! Thank you very much for your help!!  We can't make this happen without you!!!

story:
My Background


Hello, everyone. My name is Aleksi Baznekian F. L. S. I am a fellow of The Linnean Society of London, and  I am an American-Armenian biologist/botanist with an AA degree in biological sciences form Glendale Community College (cum laude), and a BA degree in biology (magna cum laude) from California State University, Northridge. After graduation, I received a grant and designed a new herbarium (Joseph Keefe Herbarium) for Glendale Community College (above right image; photo by Bryce Luna). See the link below for more info:

http://elvaq.com/features/2013/11/06/aleksi-baznekian-alumni-designs-and-curates-the-joseph-keefe-herbarium/

Currently, I am exclusively curating a Eucalyptus collection at the UCLA Herbarium. In addition, I am writing an identification guide/manual (e-book) that will facilitates identification of native, naturalized and some cultivated eudicot flora found in Los Angeles County. On the side, I publish articles about botanical phenomenon that I encounter in the field. Two of these articles can be accessed by clicking on the links below:

https://peerj.com/preprints/252/

https://peerj.com/preprints/450/


My Campaign


While studying plants in Malibu, CA, I came across a plane/sycamore tree (genus Platanus) that appears to be morphologically (mainly the leaves; above left image; photo by Aleksi Baznekian) different from our native species, P. racemosa. The individual is located in an untouched natural area near Zuma Canyon. Street planted London plane trees (P. x hispanica) were observed in the vicinity, but they are of the 3-lobed leaf cultivars. Recent molecular work has established that, at least in North CA, there is gene flow between P. x hispanica and P. racemosa (Lang, 2011). This article can be reached by accessing the link below:

Lang, Kylene R. "Microsatellite development in Plantanus for documenting gene flow among species." MS thesis. California State University, Chico, 2011. Open Access Theses and Dissertations, Web. Accessed 20 May 2015. http://oatd.org/oatd/record?record=handle\%3A10211.4\%2F272

Leaf morphology and infructescence numbers rule out the individual from being P. occidentalis (rarely cultivated in CA). It also rules out a pure P. x hispanica (since this species has been reported to have 2-3 infructescences). This individual has 5 infructescences per inflorescence. This leaves three possibilities: this individual may be P. orientalis (this species is not usually cultivated in CA, but it is found in arboreta and birds often feed on their fruits, and defecate them in natural areas), a hybrid between P. x hispanica and P. racemosa, or an unreported variety of P. racemosa. There is a fourth and rare possibility that this individual is P. x hispanica 'Columbia,' which has distinct 5-lobed leaves, but like the other cultivars of P. x hispanica, this cultivar is reported to have 2-3 infructescences, which is not the case with the observed unknown individual. See the link below for a herbarium voucher of this cultivar:

http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/herbarium/specimens/zoom/imagezoom_html5.asp?folder=191&image=191081a1#ImageTop

My first question is that what is the parentage of this individual? My second questions is that if this individual is P. orientalis, or a pure species of P. x hispanica, is their gene flow between itself and near by P. racemosa individuals?

         Your contributions will go towards answering these questions. I will gather specimen samples, send them to the required laboratories, gather and interpret the data and ultimately make conclusions accordingly. In addition, and more importantly, your funds will support a university graduate, such as I, with a BA degree, to have the opportunity to carryout such a research! It is truly sad that these days, not only do university graduates work for minimum wage, but they also work menial jobs, where they NEVER get the chance to apply their knowledge, explore, discover and write, and eventually add their findings to the existing body of knowledge in their own respective fields. Even worse is the fact that such opportunities are now only available for people going for their MS or Ph. D. degrees! This shouldn't be the case. This is the greater idea behind this project. Your funds will not only ensure the discovery of the origins of this Platanus individual and any possible gene flow between itself and native P. racemosa individuals, but that they support the idea that willing and able university graduates, who are unable to attend graduate school, whether by choice or hardship or both, can have the opportunity to apply their skills and add to human/public knowledge, instead of saying, "Do you want fries with that?" See the article below to understand this reference:

http://connect.everythingzoomer.com/profiles/blogs/you-can-make-everyday-a-mcdonald-s-day-with-a-bachelor-degree


What I Need & What You Get


I have itemized the expenses for this project below. I have rounded some of the figures, usually downward, to make perk calculations easier:

1. Molecular work (after DNA extraction) will be performed at the UCLA GENOSEQ lab: costs $1800 (actually $1820; see the link below for invoice). As you can see, ordering the labelled primers ($125 per primer pair) that were designed by Lang (2011) is the most expensive part of this entire project. These primers are essential, because without them, the lab cannot amplify (and ultimately detect) the polymorphic microsatellites via polymerase chain reaction (PCR).   

http://aleksibaznekian64.wix.com/botany#!page3/cee5

2. DNA extraction will be performed at Genome Advisors Inc. lab: cost $200 for 8 samples.

http://genomeadvisors.com/index_files/Page423.htm

3. Publication of the paper at an open access, peer reviewed journal: cost $200.

https://peerj.com/pricing/

4. I will pay out of my own pocket for shipping, field work and perk related costs, which would come out to about $200.


The Perks


The best perk is knowing that your contributions will lead to the addition of knowledge to the current body of scientific/botanical knowledge, and that you were a part of that journey and supported it. I will be collecting specimens from the tested individuals, process them, and deposit them in herbaria of the following universities: CSUN, UCLA and Harvard. However, I am big on credit, and I believe that if you contribute to this project, you deserve recognition! Consequently, I have set up the following perks:

Perk 1 (a contribution of $25): Your name will be mentioned in the published article, under the acknowledgment section, for the said dollar contribution. Since the article will be published in an open access web journal, you'll have access to a PDF version of the article at all times, for free. 

Perk 2 (a contribution of $100): Includes benefit mentioned in Perk 1, and I will personally ship a book bound (done by FedEx) copy of the article, in color, to anyone, who makes a contribution at this level. 

http://www.fedex.com/us/office/binding-finishing-laminating.html

Indiegogo wants me to "describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal." I can ASSURE you that this project will get done. Even if the goal is not met, I will raise other funds and invest as much of my own money that I possibly can to finish the project. I received my BA degree in biology from CSUN with a near 4.0 campus GPA (with two A- grades). For me failure is not an option, and the word is not in my vocabulary!  


Other Ways You Can Help


I know that in today's tough economy, it's not always easy to make a contribution. If this is you, then there is no one else who can better understand your situation than I! Nevertheless, you can do your part and get the word out, and share a link of this campaign with your family, friends and the greater community. This task is as equally important as making a contribution. 


Sincerely,


Aleksi Baznekian, F. L. S.

story:
I am currently tying up any loose ends of my undergraduate studies as I prepare to graduate this year with a degree in marine biology.

Ever since learning to talk my parents described me as being an ocean fanatic. More specifically, I had an extreme love and fascination with sharks. This love and fascination never faded, and led me to take two amazing adventures to South Africa where I volunteered with a white shark conservation and ecotourism program. This program allowed me to gain valuable experience that I'll need while pursuing a career in shark research and conservation. However, two self-funded volunteer trips and one undergrad degree later and you can only begin to imagine the debt I'm currently in.

My next adventure is taking me to Sint Maarten where I'll be volunteering my time at a local dive shop, and in exchange earn my dive master certification. This certification will further my diving skills and allow me to help others interact with the animals I love in their natural environment. I have started this campaign in order to raise money to help me pay for any living and added diving expenses while in Sint Maarten. My goal is to use my future dive master certification in combination with my degree in marine biology to conduct shark research and work towards improving the conservation efforts for these incredible and misunderstood animals.

story:
THE PROJECT

This July, Alexandra Simpson and Caroline Toal, two artists from Toronto are tackling an exciting new research project about the environment and community. They will be travelling to a Degrowth commune, Can Decreix, in Cebere, France to research a degrowth lifestyle as well as the larger global environmental crisis. The months after they will collectively create a documentary theatre piece involving interviews with degrowth  researchers and the surrounding community, their personal experiences logged through journals and the workshops they facilitated while at Can Decreix. 

Alexandra will be attending the Summer School on Degrowth and Environmental Justice from July 5 - 16, 2015. To find out more about what she'll be studying click here! On the 17th of July she will be joined at Can Decreix by Caroline Toal where they will complete the research process.


WHY DEGROWTH


A great number of economists, activists and environmentalists (as well as ourselves) recognize that a change needs to be made to the way the Global North values production and economic growth. Westerns unchallenged consumption and growth habits are adversely affecting our sense of local and global community. As a result, our ability and desire to participate in social movements that could facilitate necessary social changes dwindling and have been since the 70s. 
Can degrowth ideology compete with the consumer capitalism that plagues Western culture today? If we were to refocus our energy towards a "buen vivir " lifestyle, would we be happier? Would we be fairer to our international neighbours? By sourcing the personal stories of people who have already pledged to a value system that focuses on global equity and human well-being we will be able connect Western contemporary conscious to community and the importance of a strong human to non-human relationship relationship. The research begins here, but does not end here. It will be constant struggle to find the "trigger", the "switch", that will mobilize communities to action. We'd like Climate change to be seen as an opportunity to unite communities on a local and global scale in the fight for a environmental and human focused justice.


DEGROWTH DEFINITION


Sustainable degrowth is a downscaling of production and consumption that increases human well-being and enhances ecological conditions and equity on the planet. It calls for a future where societies live within their ecological means, with open, localized economies and resources more equally distributed through new forms of democratic institutions. Such societies will no longer have to “grow or die.” Material accumulation will no longer hold a prime position in the population’s cultural imaginary. The primacy of efficiency will be substituted by a focus on sufficiency, and innovation will no longer focus on technology for technology’s sake but will concentrate on new social and technical arrangements that will enable us to live convivially and frugally. Degrowth does not only challenge the centrality of GDP as an overarching policy objective but proposes a framework for transformation to a lower and sustainable level of production and consumption, a shrinking of the economic system to leave more space for human cooperation and ecosystems.


WHO WE ARE

Alexandra Simpson - Co-Producer/Co-Writer/Performer

Alexandra is graduate from the Performance Acting program at Ryerson Theatre School (BFA, 2013) and is currently doing her Masters in Documentary Media (MFA, 2016) with a research focus on environmental justice and how theatre can play a major role in facilitating social activism. She is an interdisciplinary artist with a background in music, voice, playwriting and physical theatre and is growing her skills as a video artist through her graduate studies. She has acted with local companies such as Mixed Company Theatre, Theatre Double Take and is currently acting in Fever/Dream with Seven Sibling Theatre. She has also produced her works including Hiatus (Ryerson New Voices, 2013), Surviving Speares (Fringe, 2013) and Pit Sublime (Alumnae Theatre, 2014). This will be her largest project to date. It is the work she has always dreamed of creating; one that combines her love of theatre and social activism. 

More on her work at alexandrawatt.ca

Caroline Toal - Co-Producer/Co-Writer/Performer

More on her work at carolinetoal.com

WHERE YOUR MONEY WILL GO

We believe immersive research will provide us with the best experience to understand the degrowth ideology and the limits of change within a developed country. The benefits to experience community first hand at Can Decreix will greatly inform the creative process and improve our ability to communicate our findings to the city of Toronto. This is why we have decided to campaign for a research trip we believe is worthy of support.

Budget Breakdown:

Plane flight for two to Spain: 1300 x 2 = $2600

Train tickets to get to Can Decreix in Cebere, France: 70 x 2 = $140

Accommodations per person per night at Can Decreix: $15 (per night) x 7 (one week) x 3 (three weeks) = 350 x 2 = $630

Food: 150 (cost for food per week per person): 150 x 3 = 450 x 2 = $900

Medical Insurance: 80 x 2 = $160

Equipment Insurance: $200 (video camera, zoom recorder, tripod)

Alexandra's course fee to attend Summer School for Degrowth and Environmental Justice: $120

Total research trip cost: $4750

PERKS 4 YOU!!!!

$5 and under: A shoutout on social media

$15: A a handwritten postcard from Caroline and Alex from Spain!

$70: A professionally made photo book of their time at Can Decreix accompanied by diary entries from Caroline and Alex.

$150: A professionally made photo book of their time at Can Decreix accompanied by diary entries from Caroline and Alex and a comp to their next show.

We appreciate any kind of support you can offer, verbal or monetary. We would be nothing without those who have been supporting our art since the very beginning and to those who are just joining us now.

We know you may want to help out but just don't have the funds... We get it! You can still help us by spreading awareness about our campaign and project through social media.


Are you a theatre artist or just want to learn or possibly get more involved with our project?

Email us at 21nightsindegrowth@gmail.com

Let us know what you have to offer!

Our current research and important environmental discussions can be found at: http://21nightsindegrowth.tumblr.com/

She has also produced her works including Hiatus (Ryerson New Voices, 2013), Surviving Speares (Fringe, 2013) and Pit Sublime (Alumnae Theatre, 2014). This will be her largest project to date. It is the work she has always dreamed of creating; one that combines her love of theatre and social activism. More on her work at alexandrawatt.caCaroline Toal - Co-Producer/Co-Writer/PerformerMore on her work at carolinetoal.comWHERE YOUR MONEY WILL GOWe believe immersive research will provide us with the best experience to understand the degrowth ideology and the limits of change within a developed country. The benefits to experience community first hand at Can Decreix will greatly inform the creative process and improve our ability to communicate our findings to the city of Toronto. This is why we have decided to campaign for a research trip we believe is worthy of support.Budget Breakdown:Plane flight for two to Spain: 1300 x 2 = $2600
Train tickets to get to Can Decreix in Cebere, France: 70 x 2 = $140
Accommodations per person per night at Can Decreix: $15 (per night) x 7 (one week) x 3 (three weeks) = 350 x 2 = $630
Food: 150 (cost for food per week per person): 150 x 3 = 450 x 2 = $900
Medical Insurance: 80 x 2 = $160
Equipment Insurance: $200 (video camera, zoom recorder, tripod)Alexandra's course fee to attend Summer School for Degrowth and Environmental Justice: $120Total research trip cost: $4750  PERKS 4 YOU!!!!$5 and under: A shoutout on social media$15: A a handwritten postcard from Caroline and Alex from Spain!$70: A professionally made photo book of their time at Can Decreix accompanied by diary entries from Caroline and Alex.$150: A professionally made photo book of their time at Can Decreix accompanied by diary entries from Caroline and Alex and a comp to their next show.We appreciate any kind of support you can offer, verbal or monetary. We would be nothing without those who have been supporting our art since the very beginning and to those who are just joining us now.We know you may want to help out but just don't have the funds... We get it! You can still help us by spreading awareness about our campaign and project through social media.Are you a theatre artist or just want to learn or possibly get more involved with our project?Email us at 21nightsindegrowth@gmail.comLet us know what you have to offer!
Our current research and important environmental discussions can be found at: http://21nightsindegrowth.tumblr.com/

story:
We 

Why We Are Doing This Ridiculous Trip?

We’re lucky enough and fortunate enough to be able to see the world. We enjoy a bit of masochism with our traveling. We like getting into conversations with people who can’t understand us. We cant wait to use grand hand gestures with loud, slow voices to try to be understood by the people who never will. To go to places like Iran, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, Russia and Mongolia.

And most importantly, to raise money for Bayasgalant and Cool Earth. This is where you come in.

Chartiy

Not only is the Mongol Rally an industrial dose of adventure, it’s also about Saving the World. The organizers ask every team to raise a minimum of £1000 for charity, of which at least £500 have to go to their official charity project Cool Earth. 

To date organizers have raised over £5.5 million for charity and, along with the teams on their other adventures, they'll be saving the world one rain forest. Where would we get lost if we didn't have jungles?

As we drive to Mongolia, we want to help an organisation which is acting there. We have chosen Bayasgalant as our second charity project.

100 % of the Money raised  with this homepage will go for charity!


What is Bayasgalant?

Bayasgalant is the Mongolian word for ”happy”. In the widest sense of the word, Bayasgalant Kinderhilfe Mongolei wants to make the kids who live in the outskirts of Ulaanbaatar happy. More specifically it means a lot of support for the children and families.

To reach this aim, Bayasgalant runs a day care centre for the poorest children in one of the poorest areas in the outskirts of Ulaanbaatar. In the day care centre they are educated, fed and it’s a place for them to play and relax.


Bayasgalant wants to improve the future of the children, giving them a perspective and also to support their families to help them to find a way out of the poverty spiral. The main focus is on help to self-help.

Your donation improves the life of the children in Mongolia. When you donate 5 Francs a child gets a hat, scarf and gloves which are necessary during the cold winter months. A school uniform costs 20 Francs, 50 Francs is the amount of food for one child during one month and 100 Francs pays University fees for a semester.Heating costs for the daycare centre are 200 Francs for 2 monthsand 500 Francs is the amount for several medical treatments.


What Is Cool Earth?

Cool Earth saves at-risk rainforest and shields millions of acres of neighbouring forest. They put local people back in control, giving them the resources they need to keep their forest intact.

How they do it

• They never have and never will buy land. Instead they help the local communities take legal control of their forest.
• By building better schools, better clinics and better incomes, they ensure rainforest protection goes hand in hand with better lives.
• They focus their efforts on rainforest that is most at-risk and which would otherwise be destroyed within the next 18 months.
• The protected forest forms a shield to make millions of acres of neighbouring forest inaccessible to loggers.
• They promise that more than 90p in every £1 you donate will go straight to their projects.


How to donate: Perks

In order to make the donations more funny and to add challenges to our trip, we set up a few perks (challenges) we will perform for your donation.
Please select the perks on the right side and make us suffer :-)

!!THANKS A LOT!!

story:
Education for Nature

Who we are

San Miguel is a beautiful Maya village in the Toledo District of southern Belize. Ten years ago, myself and other villagers formed a group focused on protecting the environment around our village – our rainforest, river and wildlife.

Our group is called C’ac’alenel Car Sa Nima (CCSN), which means “Riverfish Protectors” in Q’eqchi' Maya. We conserve forests along the upper Rio Grande River through traditional knowledge and contemporary activities with a vision that the Rio Grande forest corridor supports socio-economic, cultural and recreational activities that benefit the residents of San Miguel.

Above: The source of the Rio Grande river a few miles northwest of San Miguel.


CCSN has gained the support of farmers along the river not to cut trees within 66 feet of the river. We have created a nature trail through this forest corridor for villagers and visitors to enjoy. We have planted 2000 trees and taught hundreds of children and adults about environmental protection through traditional storytelling and documentary movie nights.

Our group is going from strength to strength and serving as a model for other villages. In 2014, CCSN received a license from the Department of Lands and Surveys to officially manage the river reserve. In May 2015, we collaborated with the village council to formally designate a community reserve for the prized rosewood tree. And we recently celebrated our first-ever environmental week, highlighting the successful community stewardship approach to watershed management.

Above: San Miguel primary school children joining in our reforestation efforts.


Our campaign

We believe that if we are to conserve and develop our natural resources sustainably, preserve our cultural identity and develop our nation meaningfully, we need conscious, educated citizens. That is the basis of CCSN’s decision to invest in our young villagers’ education through the CCSN Scholarship Fund.

Most families in San Miguel depend on subsistence farming – growing just the food they need and trading a little. We are rich in many ways but not in cash. The cost of high school textbooks and stationary – about $250 per year – is beyond the means of most families.

Last year, we started a textbook scholarship program. We managed to obtain funds for textbooks and school supplies for five first-year high school students (ages 11-12). The students have all performed well at school, and, in exchange for their scholarships, completed ten hours of community service, either doing conservation work or assisting elders in the community.

These five students have now passed on their books to another five first-formers, and we are seeking funds to purchase second year textbooks, as well as school supplies for our five second-year students and five new students.

We are asking you to donate to our cause so that these promising young people can continue their educations. Each child will receive $250 worth of books for the upcoming school year. We encourage our students to look after the books, and with any luck, they will help at least another 50 students over the coming years.

The students will continue to give back through 10 hours of community service per year, which is helping to mould them into responsible young individuals.

What we need

Five sets of textbooks x $250 per set = $1,250

Ten sets of stationary (exercise books, pens, etc.) x $25 per set = $250

Fulfillment of perks @ $200

Indiegogo fees @ $160

Total = $1,860.

If we are lucky enough to exceed our target, we will purchase third-year and fourth-year textbooks, enabling our students to complete high school.

Of course, there’s no guarantee we can continue to fund these scholarship places, but with our commitment to our cause and the generous support of people like you, we believe we can do it. We are also lucky to benefit from the support of a mentor organisation, the Toledo Institute for Development and Environment (www.tidebelize.org), who help us with fundraising and other technical support.

Our thanks

We, the students, their families and our community will be grateful for any contribution you can make. We will acknowledge your support by placing your name on a plaque at the San Miguel Resource Centre. Additionally, you will receive personal letters from the students or Maya handcrafts depending on the amount you donate.

Other ways you can help

Help us to spread the word. Post a link to this campaign on your social media pages (the Indiegogo share tools are useful for this).

And follow CCSN and TIDE on Facebook.

Thank you!

Isidro Cus, director of CCSN

story:
Short Summary

Justice, Aid, and Development (JAD) Foundation is a Chitral-KP Pakistan based registered local non-governmental organization that provides humanitarian, development and research services to the suffering humanity. JAD Foundation works with communities on disaster preparedness, prevention, mitigation and climate change adaptation with a network of over 1000 volunteers in Chitral.

The torrential rains have gripped Chitral for the last ten days. The flash flood destruction continues in different pockets/villages of Chitral. The 1st waves of torrential rains started on July 16, 2015 destroyed the Shoghor village 25km northwest of Chitral city. Since then, severe rains in different parts of the district have continued from time to time.

To date:

- 26 fatalities have so far been confirmed by PDMA; however, unofficial figures are much higher. The fatalities includes children, women and old age people.

- Access to health facilities is restricted due to blocked road communication. Death of patients unable to reach health facilities are estimated to be more than 50 including pregnant women, children and old age people.  

- Over 50,000 people are displaced and over 300,000 affected.

- According to a safe estimate over 800 houses have been destroyed, and 1000 have been damaged.

- Over 200 shops have completely washed away.

- 80 bridges including suspension bridges have destroyed.

- 40 main roads and over 100 link roads have destroyed.

- Over 20 religious centers including Masjid and Jamatkhanas have destroyed/damaged

- 60% drinking water supply lines have damaged

- Over 200 irrigation channels have destroyed/damaged

- Local bank branches, petrol pumps, hospital, schools also got destroyed/damaged

- Over 30 micro hydel unit got destroyed.

- 200 electricity distribution/transmission lines got damaged.

- Over 7000 animals have perished and are washed away by flood.

- According to the PDMA, 1200 acres standing crops have been damaged. Estimated damages to crops:

Maize: 5820 hectares cultivated. 102 hectares damaged. 2% loss

Potato: 1427 hectares are cultivated. 81% damaged.

Orchards: 358 hectares are cultivated. 60 hectares damaged.

Rice: 2093 hectares cultivated. 19 hectares damaged.

Tomato: 104 hectares are cultivated. 8 hectares damaged.

Okra: 20 hectares cultivated. 1 hectare damaged.

Pea: 154 hectares are cultivated. 11 hectares damaged.

- With non-availability of irrigation water, 70% crops will be destroyed.

- 6% livestock either perished in the flooding - PDMA

A detailed and multi-sectoral damage and needs assessment is required to ascertain complete destruction of flash flood damages.  Our professional team and volunteers with the experience of over 20 years in frontline disaster needs and damage assessments, response and recovery are readily available to coordinate and collaborate with the local government, national and international organization for undertaking detailed disaster damages and needs assessment of the recent flash flood damages in Chitral.

3000 tents, 6000 blankets, tarpaulins, bedding, food items, and medical aid is urgently required.

A comprehensive and integrated approach is required to coordinate with responding and humanitarian agencies to avoid duplication in response and recovery process. We have the expertise of over 20 years in local to national level disaster response and recovery.

WASH and health, hygiene facilities to affected people is urgently required.

Shelter for the displaced people urgently required before start of the winter.

To regularize market mechanism and to ensure availability of essential commodities of daily use, opening local roads within the villages and district is urgently required.

Most of the irrigation channels and water sources damaged during flooding require urgent repair and maintenance to avoid further damages to the crops owing to non-availability of water supply to crops, fruit bearing trees, fauna, flora and forestry.

Repair and construction of micro-hydel station to restore electricity.

What We Need & What You Get

Required urgent support to the suffering humanity.

The cost of destruction is in billions, however, for the immediate relief and recovery process our flash appeal is estimated to be USD One million. The donation will go to provision of emergency relief, detailed and multi-sectoral damage and needs assessment, 3000 tents, 6000 blankets, tarpaulins, bedding, food items, medical aid, coordinating with responding and humanitarian agencies to avoid duplication in response and recovery process, WASH and health, hygiene facilities to affected people, shelter for the displaced people before start of the winter, repair and construction of micro-hydel station to restore electricity, and restoration of water supply. 

To support the suffering humanity in this mountain region, we being the local organization having over two decades expertise are available to coordinate with your organization. We thank you for your loving, blessing, giving, helping, praying and caring generous heart, mind and spirit for the suffering humanity.

The scope of the project is based on the provision of donations. If the target goal is not met, the beneficiaries of the donation will lessen. The larger the fund, the more the beneficiaries and vice-versa. 

The Impact

Overall, the contribution will reduce the miseries of the affected communities; the most vulnerable segment being children, women, and disabled will benefit from the support. 

The first hand experience to emergency response at local and national level includes:

1. Flash flood and avalanche responses 2004, 2007, 2009, 2010, and 2013 in Chitral, Pakistan

2. Emergency rescue and response to 2005 earthquake in Kashmir and Mansehra Pakistan 

3. 2009 camping, shelter management and relief to Swat IDPs in Mardan, Pakistan

4. Flood 2010, 2011, 2012 in KPK and Sindh

Risks & Challenges

JAD Foundation has the expertise of over 15 years in damage and needs assessment, relief distribution and management, supply chain management, WASH, camp management, rehabilitation and recovery, including shelter construction, alternative livelihood, collaboration, coordination with relief agencies, state organization and international organization for sustainable recovery and reconstruction at local and national level. 

Being a local organization, born, grown and having learnt in the mountain region with the local culture, tradition, and values, we are very sure to cope with the existing challenges of accessibility, transparency, and accountability. We have very good working relationship with the communities and multi-stakeholders including the local, national, and provincial government to adjust our response and recovery plan with other stakeholders for an effective and efficient relief operation and management. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We not only need your kind donation but also your cooperation, guidance, leadership, partnership and recommendations to help those who are suffering for better and peaceful life in society. This includes, but not limited to, voluntary teaching local kids whose schools have been destroyed, sending cultural friendly in-kind goods. You can write to us at harir@jadfoundation.org.pk for such initiatives.

story:
Bref résumé

La Halte maraîchère est le résultat d'un rêve commun de retour à la terre, de se nourrir sainement et localement. Nous avons fait l'acquisition de notre première terre agricole à Lac-aux-sables dans le but de la cultiver en jardins bio-intensifs de petite surface. Nous désirons également aménager une parcelle de forêt comestible et mettre à l'avant plan la culture des champignons. 

Dans le but de minimiser notre impact sur l'environnement, nous avons pris la décision d'effectuer la majorité de nos travaux à la main et d'effectuer une culture écologique sans pesticides. Chez nous, les vers de terre et les micro-organismes du sol seront nos principaux alliés pour une culture saine et foisonnante.

Votre contribution financière est essentielle pour nous permettre de consacrer toute notre énergie à réaliser rapidement notre rêve d'autonomie alimentaire !


Ce dont nous avons besoin

Puisque c'est notre première année d'exploitation et que nous commençons presque à zéro.

-Outils de jardinerie : 500$

-Système d'irrigation : 500$

-Matériel pour la culture de champignon : 1000$

-Serres de culture : 1500$

-Rénover l'extérieur du bâtiment principal : 1500$


Qui sommes-nous?

Carl-André a complété un bac multidisciplinaire en entrepreneuriat, sociologie et management ainsi qu'une technique en génie mécanique. Après avoir géré différents projets et mentoré des jeunes entrepreneurs, il désire aujourd'hui appliquer ses connaissances et son expérience au profit de sa propre entreprise agricole. Passionné de l'alimentation saine, de permaculture et d'éco-construction depuis des années, il a choisi de s'éduquer lui-même en tentant des expériences potagères sur son balcon de ville et lisant de nombreuses publications.

Janie a fait des études collégiales en biologie et en éducation. Naturaliste depuis 3 ans, elle a exploré le monde agricole en vivant sur une terre pendant son enfance et en assistant une agronome dans son travail dans les vergers. Elle est sur le point de compléter un AEC en gestion et service de produits fins à travers lequel elle découvre le monde de la culture et du conditionnement des produits forestiers Québecois (champignons sauvages, plantes comestibles, plantes médicinales, etc.). Dans l'idée de cultiver sa propre terre sur les principes du maraîchage bio-intensif de petite surface, elle a suivi une formation avancée en maraîchage de petite surface au terrain même du jardinier qui a inspiré son rêve : Jean-Martin Fortier de la Grelinette. 


L'impact

Nous croyons que l'avenir de l'agriculture réside dans la culture locale et respectueuse de l'environnement. La Halte maraîchère veut suivre cette tendance et répondre au besoin grandissant de la population de connaître la provenance de leur nourriture et de manger sainement.

Nous souhaitons servir d'inspiration pour les jeunes de notre génération qui ressentent cette pulsion de retour à la terre. On aimerait faire la démonstration qu'il est possible de rentabiliser une petite surface agricole tout en respectant l'environnement et nos valeurs sociales. 


Les acquis

Nous avons acquis la terre agricole en juin 2015 et avons défriché les espaces réservés aux jardins. Les premiers sentiers parcourant la forêt comestible ont également été aménagés. Le plan d'affaire est en construction. 


D'autres façons d'aider

Nous acceptons l'aide sous toutes ses formes, que ce soit en argent, en temps ou en don de matériaux de construction usagés, Tout nous est utile à ce stade !

Si vous avez des idées folles, écrivez-nous et dites nous comment nous pourrions nous entre-aider !
story_txt:
Bref résumé
La Halte maraîchère est le résultat d'un rêve commun de retour à la terre, de se nourrir sainement et localement. Nous avons fait l'acquisition de notre première terre agricole à Lac-aux-sables dans le but de la cultiver en jardins bio-intensifs de petite surface. Nous désirons également aménager une parcelle de forêt comestible et mettre à l'avant plan la culture des champignons. 
Dans le but de minimiser notre impact sur l'environnement, nous avons pris la décision d'effectuer la majorité de nos travaux à la main et d'effectuer une culture écologique sans pesticides. Chez nous, les vers de terre et les micro-organismes du sol seront nos principaux alliés pour une culture saine et foisonnante.
Votre contribution financière est essentielle pour nous permettre de consacrer toute notre énergie à réaliser rapidement notre rêve d'autonomie alimentaire !


Ce dont nous avons besoin
Puisque c'est notre première année d'exploitation et que nous commençons presque à zéro.
-Outils de jardinerie : 500$
-Système d'irrigation : 500$
-Matériel pour la culture de champignon : 1000$
-Serres de culture : 1500$
-Rénover l'extérieur du bâtiment principal : 1500$


Qui sommes-nous?Carl-André a complété un bac multidisciplinaire en entrepreneuriat, sociologie et management ainsi qu'une technique en génie mécanique. Après avoir géré différents projets et mentoré des jeunes entrepreneurs, il désire aujourd'hui appliquer ses connaissances et son expérience au profit de sa propre entreprise agricole. Elle est sur le point de compléter un AEC en gestion et service de produits fins à travers lequel elle découvre le monde de la culture et du conditionnement des produits forestiers Québecois (champignons sauvages, plantes comestibles, plantes médicinales, etc.). Nous souhaitons servir d'inspiration pour les jeunes de notre génération qui ressentent cette pulsion de retour à la terre. On aimerait faire la démonstration qu'il est possible de rentabiliser une petite surface agricole tout en respectant l'environnement et nos valeurs sociales. 




Les acquis

D'autres façons d'aider

Nous acceptons l'aide sous toutes ses formes, que ce soit en argent, en temps ou en don de matériaux de construction usagés, Tout nous est utile à ce stade !
Si vous avez des idées folles, écrivez-nous et dites nous comment nous pourrions nous entre-aider !

story:
Read an article about Clime-IT on Treehugger.com

 

 

Planetary-wide catastrophic consequences are ahead of us if we don’t ACT NOW. We’re not just saying this; science proves it. Arguing the facts has become absurd.

World leaders acknowledge the crisis. Many of them are working on local and global initiatives (COP21 ) but their hands are too often tied by politics and greedy corporations.

Clean technologies are being developed all over the world, the problem is they lack visibility, have difficulty getting funded, or, if they are really promising, they simply get squashed because their success threatens Big Oil and fossil fuel companies.

 

We, The People, are getting quite sick of this and the crowd is uniting and getting involved. We’ve had enough of Big Money making (bad) choices for us and we are raising our voice.

It appears that in a moment of clarity, the government has realized its limitations and boldly handed us a tool that will allow us to choose our own future.

 

 

 

 

All of these new investments have to be done online through what are called “Equity Crowdfunding Platforms” — we call it “CrowdInvesting”. These platforms are heavily regulated by the SEC in order to avoid fraud. Clime-IT.com will be such a website specifically and exclusively for Climate Change Solutions.

 

We’re already getting requests from companies who have heard about us and wish to post their projects when we launch. Entrepreneurs are seeing the potential. We’re also on the “watch list” of some investors, and that’s really exciting too.

 

 

 

Those who are threatened by the shift of power made possible by the JOBS Act are trying to minimize what it can mean. These detractors are quick to point out its flaws and challenges. So this Breaking News hasn’t made the news. Go figure!

 

 

 

We profoundly believe this business model is part of the global solution and the excitement is contagious. Pretty much everyone with whom we’ve shared our idea sees the potential we see.

 

We’ve been busy building a team of scientists, academics, financial modelers, platform developers, a world-class marketing group, fired-up sustainability graduates, and a securities attorney who has specialized in the JOBS Act since its inception (Mark Roderick from Flaster/Greenberg PC). We are also creating strategic alliances with a number of organizations in the USA and Canada that will ensure access to quality projects to post on Clime-IT™. 

We’ve been bootstrapping this for 9 months and we’re now at a point where we need to grow our resources – it’s time for passionate people to join in and for an influx of money to power us forward.

Climate-related crises are multiplying, the Paris Summit (COP21) is coming up in December (leaders from 195 countries are meeting in order to create a global agreement), the UN has launched The Global Goals, an election is coming up: World-changing decisions are being made everyday.

We need to ramp this up.
Now is the time.

 

This is an extraordinary opportunity but it is also all new territory. Our plan is to build a solid structure using impeccable practices through a strategy of integrity. Our intention is to set the standards for this new world of investment.

Of course we expect bumps on the road, that’s part of being trailblazers. But with sufficient funding we can assemble the best legal team, attract the best business and strategic minds, invite the best marketing group, marshal the best sustainability experts and promote the disruptive technologies of tomorrow.

Yes… we’re aiming for the best and setting up for success.

 
This $100,000 is the first step towards launching in the spring of 2016.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Click here to find it on Amazon
                   Connect with Dan on Twitter: @TreeBanker
 

 

If you wish to include a link to the campaign in your own posts, you can use this short link: igg.me/at/clime-it

story:
“The production, use and disposal of synthetic plastic has become one of the most serious environmental and human health problems facing us today.”

Starting in November 2015, we’re travelling from Cairo to Capetown, tracking the world’s plastic footprint.  The key purpose of the trip is to find out more about how plastic gets into the world’s oceans and to reveal the real impacts it has on people’s lives and the environment.  We’ll also be looking at what effective measures can and should be taken to eliminate the problems we find. 

Why this project is important

One of the difficulties with responding to the problem of plastic waste lies in locating responsibility for its impacts. More research is needed to identify sources and locate areas where policy can have the greatest impact.

A major concern is that so much plastic waste ends up in every part of our marine environment, with dramatic concentrations being found in the five major ocean gyres. The vast majority of what’s found in the sea originates from the land - from sewage, storm drains, waterways, beach and coastal litter, as well as dumping, industrial activities and landfill sites.

Our Aims

We want to keep plastic out of our oceans and eliminate single-use plastics by 2030. To do this we will come up with long-term, practical solutions and raise international public awareness and support.

1. Identify the origins of plastic waste on land, in lakes, rivers and the sea.

2. Classify the types and quantities of the waste plastics we find.

3. Assess the impact of waste plastics on the environment, people and animals?

4. Investigate what current policies and waste facilities are in place?

How are we going to do this?

We will use visual data surveys, plastic density sampling and ethnographic studies, organised around: participant observation, semi-structured interviews, videos, photography and social media.

The collection of plastic data from Africa will allow us to come up with effective solutions to reduce plastic waste, review the effectiveness of existing legislation and compare approaches from different parts of the continent.

The Raw Team

Melinda Watson is team-leader and a sea lover, teacher, campaigner, designer, mother and activist, recently awarded an Earth Champion ‘Change Agent’ award. She is founder of RAW Foundation - a ground-breaking campaigning organisation targeting all types of disposable waste.

Laurence Hall has previously worked in Africa on the Great Primate Handshake project. He is an awesome filmmaker on the move!

Alexander Mourant studies at the Institute of Photography at Falmouth University in Cornwall.Shooting with traditional analog processes he photographs the ever complex relationship between mankind and nature.

Steve Newby from Oasis Overland Ltd, which are UK based experts in expedition logistics, covering trips in Africa, South America, Central Asia and Europe.

JOIN OUR STORY

This journey will allow the team - myself, a photographer and a filmmaker, to collect scientific data, powerful photographic imagery and personal stories along the way for an accessible book, images, videos, an exhibition and more!

Our job is simply to honor this journey as it reveals itself to us, and deliver it to a global audience with the best quality storytelling, photography and film-making that we can create for you to share.
Please join our story - every contribution helps, however small!
Thank you

~ with big smiles from Melinda Watson and the Raw Team


Follow the story here: http://rawfoundation.org/making-waves/news/

Please share, spread the word and be part of the story:

FB: https://www.facebook.com/rawfoundation.org

Twitter: https://twitter.com/RawfoundationUK

Instagram: https://instagram.com/rawfoundationuk/

Pinterest: https://uk.pinterest.com/rawfoundation/

YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVSs70jtxnpeZDgl5CPICyg

Join the conversation and make a noise about our Making Waves campaign: #RawinAfrica  #makingwaves  #plastic #pollution #ecocide  #gotthebottle #bepartofthesolution


Recent Projects

Plastic-Free Festival Guide

Raw Foundation launched and published their first Plastic-Free Festival Guide in partnership with Kambe Events, a sustainable event management consultancy. The guide, showcased at the Green Events and Innovations Conference 2014 has been adopted by Glastonbury Festival, Shambala Festival and others following suit.

Glastonbury Festival 2014/15 – a reduction in single-use plastics, by providing re-usable 100% stainless steel water bottles and free water refill kiosks on site in collaboration with Glastonbury Festival and WaterAid.

Plastic-free Festival-Goer Guide and City, Beach, Lifestyle and Sector Guides – for Bristol 2015, the National Trust ‘Coast Campaign’ 2015, eXXpedition, CitytoSea, Go Green, Bristol and Kas, in Turkey in collaboration with WWF, Turkey towards a ‘Sustainable Tourism’ plan.


The Problems

Quantity

Plastic waste has become one of the fastest growing hazardous waste streams on the planet. 80% of marine plastic waste comes from the land [1] and there are six times more plastic particles than plankton in some parts of our oceans.[2] In the North Pacific Gyre this has risen to a staggering 36:1 in a decade.[3]

Toxic Risk

Plastic contains hundreds of highly toxic persistent chemicals, damaging to both human health and the environment. In water, plastic breaks down into micro-plastic particles that act like a sponge. These accumulate other toxins to them to extreme levels that pass up the food chain to contaminate entire ecosystems and the food we are eating.

Disposability

Explosive sales in single-use plastics encourage waste on a vast scale. At the heart of the problem is one of plastic’s most valued properties - its durability. Plastics can take a minimum of 500 years to degrade. Ironically, when combined with a throwaway culture, this means that we are using materials that are designed to last, for short-term use.

Recyclability

Most recycled plastics are 'downcycled' or exported, often illegally, from Europe to Africa and Asia where burning waste in the open air is commonplace. Confusion and malpractice are not keeping pace with the sheer quantity or mixture of plastic produced, releasing toxic emissions or dust into the air and soil.

[1] OSPAR., UNEP., Marine Litter: Preventing a Sea of Plastic, 2009.

[2] Moore, C.J., Lattin, G. L. and Zellers, A. F. (2005) Density of plastic particles found in zooplankton trawls from coastal waters of California to the North Paci­fic Central Gyre.

[3]Alagita Foundation (2015) Plastic debris delivers triple toxic whammy

story:
Is Artificial Turf Safe? Let's find out!

South Hadley is about to build an Artificial Turf field at our High School. I want to be sure our kids will be safe by providing independent 3rd party testing of the Crumb Rubber Infill materials we'll be using.

But why stop here? Let's test your town's turf fields also, just to be safe!

So what exactly is this stuff?
Crumb Rubber products are made of Used Tires...which are not just rubber, but nearly 1/2 petroleum by-products, industrial chemicals & road waste!!!  

They can contain metal wire, textile fibers, toxic glues & solvents, and Carbon Black, a material similar to coal dust or diesel soot, and used produce paint & inks. Used tires are often coated with road chemicals like lead, cadmium, mercury, arsenic, zinc and copper, along with phthalates, poly-cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and other volatile organic compounds (VOC's). Plus there's the fertilizers, pesticides, garbage effluents, construction materials and human wastes that are regularly transported along our roads and highways! Totally Gross!!! You and I would never consider putting these toxins in our mouths, right? Why in the world would we let children handle or even breath their fumes? 

These are dangerous chemicals similar to those found in cigarettes, and they're being thrown into playgrounds and sports fields, potentially predisposing our children to harm and risk of death.

We haul and dispose of nearly all our recycle-able mercury light-bulb-and-battery-laden-garbage, processed municipal sewer sludge and septic & porta-potty wastes, by road! Often in leaky vehicles dripping oil, gas & anti-freeze to boot! Yummy!

Of the 254 million cars, trucks and motorcycles on our roads, what's the chance that some of these vehicles might pick up some of that "crap" and pass it on through the supply chain to our fields & playgrounds? Pretty high...statistically. 

So, How can you help?  

By contributing to our campaign, we'll be able to purchase Lead, Heavy Metal & Chemical Toxicity Testing Kits and begin collecting & processing Crumb Rubber samples from around the country!!! We'll post and map our results online for everyone to see. When we discover a potential safety violation we'll notify State & Local Board of Health Officials, EPA Regulators, the Media and YOU! 

Real Grassroots, Crowd Sourced Environmental Monitoring and Reporting!!! 
Something "We the People..." established our government for in the first place!

What We Need From You & What You Get...

For just $35 and a little volunteer leg-work, you can help us begin the pre-screening process! You'll receive a package in the mail containing:

  • (6) Sample Collection Containers
  • (2) Pairs of Nitrile Gloves (for you and a friend)
  • A return-addressed, postage paid mailer
  • Detailed instructions on how we'd like you to collect samples
  • A link to our live database entry form 
  • News & updates on sampling efforts from around the nation
  • A copy of our forthcoming  newsletter entitled "Where the Rubber Meets the Road: Crumb Rubber Infill  and It's Potential Risks, Hazards and Alternatives." 
  • Recognition on our Contributors Page, and our sincere thanks and appreciation for helping us determine the truth about Artificial Turf Crumb Rubber Infill

Check out our list of additional Perks along the side of our project description!


As children, we would have never been allowed to play on used car & truck tires piling up in our local landfills and junkyards. Even 40 years ago they were considered unsafe! Sure, our neighborhood had a tire-swing or two...but we never spent more than a few hours each week swinging on them. We were out playing sports on grass fields and yards!!! And when we swung, as you probably remember, we got pretty dirty and smelled like...well, tires!



Publicly available 3rd party research continues to suggest that many of our standardized testing models present overly optimistic low estimates of daily exposure from interaction & ingestion of Crumb Rubber by children   

The EPA even admits that, "given the very limited nature of this study (i.e., limited number of components monitored, samples sites, and samples taken at each site) and the wide diversity of tire crumb material, it is not possible to extend the results beyond the four study sites or to reach any more comprehensive conclusions without the consideration of additional data."[1] 

So whether it's four sites or forty, out of more than 11,000+ Crumb Rubber fields & playgrounds, it still seems pretty sketchy! 

Today, Crumb & Chunk Rubber Infill is seeing increasing use in parks, playgrounds, sports fields and homes around the country, despite mounting concerns from parent groups and community health officials. Nearly every day stories are aired on the news and the internet, repeating the same question: Is it safe?


So why make a fuss? I make medical device prototypes for a living, so I understand some of the health stakes & liability risks. I also make toys. The Consumer Product Safety Commission limits lead on surface coatings in toys to no more than 90 parts per million.[2] That's less than a quarter of the concentrations the EPA allows in lead contaminated soil.[3] Yet almost every day I see toddlers and kids crawling on and handling Chunk Rubber infill at our local playground! And, they almost never wash their hands before picking their noses or sucking their thumbs. Believe me, I have two kids of my own...I've seen it all!

There's absolutely NO WAY the Consumer Product Safety Commission or the Toy Industry Association, would ever allow choke-able Chunk & Crumb Rubber, laced with toxic metals, wires, fibers and road chemicals to be used as toys, right? So why are toddlers allowed to play on it, or in it or with it? And If it's unsafe for toddlers, it's just as likely to be equally unsafe for older children too!

Regardless of what "industry officials" might say, we need to begin providing 3rd party monitoring of Artificial Turf  Crumb-Rubber installations throughout our nation immediately! Our health and that of our children absolutely depends upon it!

The Impact...

By helping to fund this Campaign, we can extend screening to hundreds, even thousands of communities throughout our nation with similar concerns.

I've been a vocal opponent of Artificial Turf from the beginning because it seems common sense to me (and many others), that using Ground-up Car Tires as playground material may present a real health hazard to our children. Despite our many concerns and questions, Turf Industry Officials, hired Inspectors and Federal & State regulators continue to tout only the benefits of Crumb & Chunk rubber products, a strategy vaguely reminiscent to that of the tobacco industry. 

Other than a few often quoted reports, no conclusive documentation has been provided proving once and for all that every installation of this material is safe for children to play on. 

Each day more and more recycled materials are turned into widely used consumer products, often sourced from nations with far greater environmental challenges than we have here in the US. 

It's nearly impossible to test everything that we import unless we work together. 

When considering the massive environmental cleanup needs of places like China, Africa, South America and the war torn Middle East, we need to ensure that recycled rubber products that our children play on aren't tainted with unregulated chemicals and toxic materials. 

By taking this first step to identify where the hazards may exist, ordinary people like you and I can make an incredible difference.

If we're successful together in assuming this challenge, perhaps someday soon we can apply similar methods with the help of others in nations where impoverished communities struggle everyday to cope with issues of pollution, sanitation, lack of healthy foods & clean water. Please help.

Risks & Challenges
I expect that this project will involve an enormous amount of time and legal & scientific challenges, many no doubt posed by more well funded and influential industry representatives. But, we only need to find a few bad tires in the soccer field to get things cooking, right? So, I'm up for the challenge if you are!
And, while community based volunteer pre-screening of collected Crumb Rubber materials with 3rd party testing may still not provide enough evidence of largess to pose a challenge to the industry, there's no reason not to try. Right?

Even though this effort may ultimately require far greater funding and experience than an International Crowd Sourced Environmental Campaign on Indiegogo can raise, if we're successful in finding even one instance of Crumb Rubber Toxicity... we'll be vindicated many times over by the lives we save! 
Imagine how that might feel!

My background:  My name is Steve Longpre and I'm the Founder of Barnstorm Studio, a small Education Research & Product Development Company, located in South Hadley, Massachusetts. I have a B.S. in Geology/Geochemistry from the UMASS, Amherst, where I studied among other things, Groundwater Hydrology, Physics, Engineering, Remote Environmental Sensing and Social Responsibility. While pursuing my education, I gained valuable Entrepreneurial experience by starting a weekend Sports Entertainment company, to put myself through college. That makes me "in" the industry, and a critic!

I own & operate our areas first thermoplastics 3D Printing company, where I work everyday with professionals from area businesses, colleges and hospitals to bring Additive Manufacturing to our region's schools and healthcare industries. To provide workforce development for my industry, I also work part-time as a Technologies Instructor and Substitute Teacher at middle & high schools in our surrounding towns.

So If that doesn't convince you, here's what should: 

You're the one who's read this far! So you must agree with something I've said. If so, then we can do this if we work together as a team, and have fun while doing it!

Other Ways You Can Help

We need help contacting people who can locate turf installations around the country. If you're unable to contribute financially, please help spread the word about this project within your neighboring communities.
Act now! Everyday we wait, new playgrounds, sports fields and neighbors are installing Crumb Rubber materials in our communities with little to no 3rd party testing and certification. We need to change that, and potentially affect the lives of thousands of people for the better!

[1] State of California-Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment (OEHHA), Contractor’s Report to the Board. Evaluation of Health Effects of Recycled Waste Tires in Playground and Track Products. January 2007. http://www.calrecycle.ca.gov/publications/Documents/Tires%5C62206013.pdf Accessed September 5, 2012.

[2] Toy Industry Association, Inc. Update on Changes to ASTM F963 - The U.S. Toy Safety Standard, Al Kaufman, presentation pdf. February 12, 2013 Accessed September 5, 2012.

[3] US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Fact Sheet-The Use of Recycled Tire Materials on Playgrounds & Artificial Turf Fields.http://www.epa.gov/nerl/download_files/documents/fs_tire_crumbs.pdf Accessed September 5, 2012.

Related Articles:

Depleted Uranium: The New Agent Orange, By Aliaume Leroy
https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2014/12/08/depleted-uranium-the-new-agent-orange/ December 8, 2014

Assessment of Environmental "hot spots" In Iraq, Vol. 832, Military Scrap Metal Industry, Iraq. United Nations Environment Program, https://books.google.com/books. 2005.

Artificial Turf Regulation Based on Industry Supplied Data, By Monica Luhar
http://www.kcet.org/news/agenda/public-information/artificial-turf-regulation-based-on-industry-supplied-data-alleges-group.html, May 7, 2015

Las Vegans blame hotel fire on lack of regulations for fake trees, by Maria Santos
http://redalertpolitics.com/2015/07/28/las-vegans-blame-hotel-fire-lack-regulations-fake-trees/ , July 28, 2015

Example of publicly available Material Safety Data Sheet for Crumb Rubber, http://edge.rit.edu/edge/P11413/public/Crumb%20...

Red Barns and White Barns: Why rural crime skyrocketed in the late 1800s, by Kevin Drum, Santoshttp://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2015/02/red-barns-and-white-barns-why-rural-crime-skyrocketed-late-1800s , Feb. 24, 2015

Our Children at Risk, Natural Resources Defence Council, http://www.nrdc.org/health/kids/ocar/chap3.asp , Accessed July 8, 2015

Wheel weight updated: Mnnesota bans use of lead and mercury balance weights,
http://www.moderntiredealer.com/channel/retailing/article/story/2014/06/wheel-weight-update.aspx#postComment , June 27, 2014

Is Artificial Turf Safe? Let's find out!
South Hadley is about to build an Artificial Turf field at our High School. I want to be sure our kids will be safe by providing independent 3rd party testing of the Crumb Rubber Infill materials we'll be using. But why stop here? Let's test your town's turf fields also, just to be safe!


So what exactly is this stuff?
Crumb Rubber products are made of Used Tires...which are not just rubber, but nearly 1/2 petroleum by-products, industrial chemicals & road waste!!!  
They can contain metal wire, textile fibers, toxic glues & solvents, and Carbon Black, a material similar to coal dust or diesel soot, and used produce paint & inks. Used tires are often coated with road chemicals like lead, cadmium, mercury, arsenic, zinc and copper, along with phthalates, poly-cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and other volatile organic compounds (VOC's). Plus there's the fertilizers, pesticides, garbage effluents, construction materials and human wastes that are regularly transported along our roads and highways! Totally Gross!!! You and I would never consider putting these toxins in our mouths, right? Why in the world would we let children handle or even breath their fumes? These are dangerous chemicals similar to those found in cigarettes, and they're being thrown into playgrounds and sports fields, potentially predisposing our children to harm and risk of death.We haul and dispose of nearly all our recycle-able mercury light-bulb-and-battery-laden-garbage, processed municipal sewer sludge and septic & porta-potty wastes, by road!
