story:
A Revolution... is required

What the heck can we do about "Styrofoam"? (expanded polystyrene or "EPS") Many recycling experts have tried to solve this problem and FAILED because EPS is costly to ship and much of it is food-contaminated.  When they do recycle EPS, it ends up as low-grade plastic (polystyrene).  Because that material has little value, it doesn't make economic sense to ship EPS to recycling facilities (which are few and far between).  Even though EPS is technically recyclable, most of it ends up in landfills, if not our streets, rivers, and even the ocean.

Let's just BAN it, right?    Well... it turns out that banning EPS doesn't help the environment, it arguably makes things worse.  EPS replacements cost a lot more, require far more water and energy to make, and many/most of them are not recyclable or compostable. We need a radically different approach.

By processing EPS and paper into composites using local, low-tech methods, all the EPS from your neighborhood can be turned into highly useful products. So the world is cleaner, we save energy and landfill space, and the money saved can be spent on better things.

Who is Dave Pennington anyway?

I am an eco-artist/inventor (some say alchemist) currently living in Dallas TX. Trained at the University of the Virgin Islands as an aquaponic systems designer, I currently work as an aquaponic farmer and in the process of optimizing that concept I developed several eco-inventions, mostly focused on energy management. I needed insulated tilapia tanks, so I came up with an "EPIC" invention. As with aquaponics, the future was waiting... in the past. I figured out how to combine EPS (invented in the 1950's) with "papercrete" (invented in the 1920's) and the results have been AMAZING. Now instead of $3/gallon, large format insulated tanks only cost 30 cents per gallon, which is an order of magnitude less expensive. The same material can be used to build tornado resistant buildings for less than $10/sq ft.

With your help I will be able to spread this eco-technology far and wide, and build more solutions to the world's pressing ecological problems. The first order of business will be to start producing a line of simple and affordable machines for grinding and bagging EPS. At the same time a multi-lingual DVD showing how to make EPIC will be produced for mass distribution. Finally a learning portal needs to be created where people from all over the world can learn how to build food systems, house their families, and even solve the climate crisis using EPIC and other inventions. We can make all this happen.

I am currently working with a bunch of very sharp people who are doing some seriously interesting projects which unfortunately I can't talk  about yet. They have seen EPIC and other advances I have made, and they want to put me to work solving more problems, all related to the health of humanity and our planet. I have some ideas how to put their expertise to work. Think floating islands for coral reef restoration...!?!

Please chip in a bit and help the project along, we are working as hard as we can because there is a great need for solutions, and luckily some great innovations are being developed which can solve many of the problems we face. Your contribution will get you a little chunk of EPIC (and the recipe to make more). I believe it may even help our planet, and our kids who will see the future we are making.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to:

Create multi-lingual high quality training materials (DVDs, books, etc) so that everyone can start making EPIC in their own towns, and convert tons of waste EPS and paper into useful stuff

Develop and produce low cost EPS grinding equipment for small scale EPIC production at the local level.

Have professional engineering tests done on various EPIC mixes to see what the exact properties are. This is the first step towards getting EPIC approved for use in metropolitan areas with stringent building codes.

What you'll get:
  • The basic formula for EPIC - This "formula" is actually more of a philosophy, with reasoning and "rules" which guide you to a happier outcome. And like any good philosophy it shows you why, not just how to make EPIC, as different applications require different approaches.
  • Sample block of EPIC (doubles as a snazzy drink coaster) Available in sets!
  • A complete kit with all the materials you need to make EPIC (just add drill!)
  • Grinding machinery for making EPS into beads
  • Training sessions and technical support for your project

If we don't reach our goal, we will use the funds donated to create MORE stuff like EPIC

The Impact

EPIC is a revolutionary new material. How it gets used is up to you! I can think of many ways to use it but the sky's the limit. Super efficient and affordable housing, off-grid commercial aquaponic systems, raised bed gardens, furniture, the possibilities are nearly endless. The domes we have built so far have been torture tested with sledgehammers and propane torches, termites and freeze/thaw cycles. All tests passed with flying colors. Buildings have been cut up with chain saws, moved, and reassembled again! EPIC joins to EPIC perfectly... using EPIC for the "glue".

EPIC is a ZERO WASTE product. Everything you make with it, and all the scraps, can be ground up and mixed into more EPIC.  You can build your project and NOTHING needs to go in the trash. When an EPIC creation outlives its usefulness, just grind it up and make it into something new!

Risks & Challenges

The risk to our planet is all that concerns me. I have already developed the technology you see here, so sending you the samples, the instructions, the consulting materials, that will happen unless I get hit by a bus. The challenge as I see it is how do we get this technology applied fast enough to make a real difference. I have a lot of ideas how to do that, and as you may have noticed my ideas tend to be a little bit outside the box. To heck with the box.

NOTE: EPIC is a new construction material. If you want to build a house out of EPIC and you live in an area where building codes require specific materials, you may need to move to an area with greater architectural freedom.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Nobody can change the past, but everyone can change the future. And that's all there is to it. THANKS!

story:
We are a small farm located in the mountainous high desert of northern New Mexico. Our farm is also a wildlife sanctuary and sustainability skills school. A healthy and sustainable future relies on the health of wild nature. We help farmers, gardeners, and ranchers transition from chemical use (including those certified for use in “organic” agriculture) into virtually input-free “wildfarm” systems.

On our farm we create and teach others how to build habitat for various wild species (birds, bats, bees, other beneficial insects, etc. Please see our website: www.wildhoodfarm.com for more information on our wildlife habitat). In addition, some of the other “sustainability skills” we teach include: rainwater catchment, wild food collection and preparation, long-term food preservation (electricity-free), brain-tanning, butchering, cob building, beekeeping, seed saving, home health, permaculture and more.

The current state of our global ecosystem is quite worrisome. Thousands of species (that we know of…)—from every niche of classification—are threatened, endangered, or already extinct. I’m sure this is not new to most of you, having already heard something about “disappearing monarchs,” “dying bees,” “habitat loss,” and/or “disrupted migrations.” That is why it is so important to take action NOW.

The thing is, we are starting from raw land. Currently, there is no place to live on our farm. Though we closed on the property almost two years ago, it is becoming quite apparent to us that we will never really be able to get it up and going as long as we are forced to maintain off-farm jobs. Simply meeting the costs of mortgage payments, living expenses, commuting, and well drilling does not leave us any time to get the farm started. That is why we are asking for help. Anyone who believes in the importance of healthy wildlife populations, the true sustainability of modern local food systems, and those who simply want to support two young people following their dreams and passions, please lend us a hand.

We figure that it will take about ***$28,000*** to fully meet all of our goals (house, barn, livestock, greenhouse, initial purchase of all crops and seedlings, etc.) but we are asking for $3,000. This should be enough to allow us to take 1-2 months off from our other jobs, and focus exclusively on building a small casita. Our building costs will be extremely low as we are mostly using our own labor and salvaged materials. Once we can get a place to live built, we will hopefully be able to focus solely on the farm. This will undoubtedly happen slowly, as we wean ourselves off of outside employment, gradually replacing it with what we are able to produce and sell from the farm. By helping us, you will be helping wildlife and the continuity of small, self-sufficient rural communities in northern New Mexico. Thank you, from the bottom of our hearts.
story_txt: We are a small farm located in the mountainous high desert of northern New Mexico. Our farm is also a wildlife sanctuary and sustainability skills school. A healthy and sustainable future relies on the health of wild nature. We help farmers, gardeners, and ranchers transition from chemical use (including those certified for use in “organic” agriculture) into virtually input-free “wildfarm” systems.  On our farm we create and teach others how to build habitat for various wild species (birds, bats, bees, other beneficial insects, etc. Please see our website: www.wildhoodfarm.com for more information on our wildlife habitat). In addition, some of the other “sustainability skills” we teach include: rainwater catchment, wild food collection and preparation, long-term food preservation (electricity-free), brain-tanning, butchering, cob building, beekeeping, seed saving, home health, permaculture and more.  The current state of our global ecosystem is quite worrisome. Thousands of species (that we know of…)—from every niche of classification—are threatened, endangered, or already extinct. I’m sure this is not new to most of you, having already heard something about “disappearing monarchs,” “dying bees,” “habitat loss,” and/or “disrupted migrations.” That is why it is so important to take action NOW.The thing is, we are starting from raw land. Currently, there is no place to live on our farm. Though we closed on the property almost two years ago, it is becoming quite apparent to us that we will never really be able to get it up and going as long as we are forced to maintain off-farm jobs. Simply meeting the costs of mortgage payments, living expenses, commuting, and well drilling does not leave us any time to get the farm started. That is why we are asking for help. Anyone who believes in the importance of healthy wildlife populations, the true sustainability of modern local food systems, and those who simply want to support two young people following their dreams and passions, please lend us a hand.We figure that it will take about ***$28,000*** to fully meet all of our goals (house, barn, livestock, greenhouse, initial purchase of all crops and seedlings, etc.) but we are asking for $3,000. This should be enough to allow us to take 1-2 months off from our other jobs, and focus exclusively on building a small casita. Our building costs will be extremely low as we are mostly using our own labor and salvaged materials. Once we can get a place to live built, we will hopefully be able to focus solely on the farm. This will undoubtedly happen slowly, as we wean ourselves off of outside employment, gradually replacing it with what we are able to produce and sell from the farm. By helping us, you will be helping wildlife and the continuity of small, self-sufficient rural communities in northern New Mexico. Thank you, from the bottom of our hearts.

story:
What Is Aquatica?

Aquatica is a collective performance for Rainbow Serpent Festival 2016 - one of Australia's largest culture and lifestyle festivals, with around 20,000 tickets sold each year. 

Aquatica will be a spectacular combination of art installation, costumes, performance, music, and visual projections. In our performance we aim to connect the audience to our deep oceanic heart and to raise awareness regarding the plight of our oceans and the rich and complex life they hold. 

Aquatica speaks of the harmonious cycle of water: from ocean, to sky, to ground, and back to ocean - running through all life on Earth. Our bodies are made up of 65% water. Connecting the viewer to the ocean, Aquatica tells an evolutionary story of Life on Earth: Life that exists in perfect delicate balance.

Our oceans and the life in them are not just threatened, but already damaged by pollution. The oceans are the source of up to 80% of breathable oxygen. 

Aquatica promotes preservation of the oceans by supporting The Beach Patrol with 10% of the money generated by this Indiegogo campaign.

Aquatica is a stunning show choreographed and performed by acclaimed burlesque troupe Eclectica. Designed and created by our team of architects and visual artists, Aquatica is a giant sea life installation that features unique, colourful, and exotic costumes created specially for this event from recycled materials. features unique, colourful, and exotic costumed created specially for this event from recycled materials.

For details of the project and a sneak peak of the performance check out our video. 

The call to action has been made. Join us in our answer and offering. 

What Do We Need? 

We aim to raise $5500 to cover the cost of materials  
With your help we will bring an unforgettable experience, as a collective of artistic expressions, that inspire people to connect and care for our ocean.
The key elements of the event are installations representing a jellyfish, giant clam, and other sea creatures.

$2500    Bamboo aerial rig to hang our amazing Jellyfish installation

$1500    Metal for the internal structures of the installations 

$500      Fabric to cover the installations 

$500      Transporting costs 

$500      Creation and painting of body suits

You can also contact us if you would like to donate materials that can be used in the construction of the event. Contact us on Facebook.

10% of the funds raised will be donated to The Beach Patrol.

If we don't achieve the full funding required, the money we receive will go towards the priority articles first.

Our team is rich in experience. The installations we are building are huge and have proved to be a challenge to our engineer' design and fabrication skills. The team thrives on solving problems and finding practical solutions and we have designs that will more than suit the occasion. 

What Do You Get?

The satisfaction of helping us promote awareness towards the plight of the ocean.
Even if you not able to witness Aquatica at Rainbow Serpent, there are many other creative rewards available, depending on the size of the donation. See the "Perks" section.

Spread the word to EVERYONE. Use the Indiegogo share tools, Facebook, and any social media you're connected with, get the word out and make some noise. Like the page, ask your friends to like the page and tell your networks about this awesome project.

Ask to volunteer. We have many fun creation days from now until 18 January 2016. You can contact us on our Facebook page.

Thank you for taking the time to look at our campaign, and sparing a thought for our oceans.

story:
Toyze Pets: Truly awesome 3D printed dogs!

Toyze is one of the pioneers in personalized 3D printing. We are currently focused on 3D printing personalized game characters like Om Nom from the Cut the Rope franchise, Talking Tom and Pou but we can 3D print almost anything! So we thought, what if we offered a whole line of customisable and printable 3D models of some of the most awesome dog breeds?

We are really big fans of the English Bulldog breed, so we decided to kick off our campaign with these absolutely adorable dogs. If we hit our funding goals we will expand to include the Yorkshire Terrier, Husky, Pomeranian and Dachshund!

Super fun fact: Bulldogs are among the top 5 most popular dog breeds worldwide with constant appearances in mainstream media dealing with fashion, music, movies and much more! Here is a great example of 3D printed english bulldogs:



You can choose from one of several awesome poses and apply some great accessories to customize your model. You can also write a name on the models baseplate.

To kick things off, we will offer multicolor plaster-based 3D printed models in matt or gloss finish. Once we get rolling, we will expand the offer to different materials including resin, stainless steel, or for the more bling-conscious: silver, gold and platinum!

By donating from as little as 10 USD you’ll help us achieve our goal of creating something truly unique and totally cute!

Our funding goal is 30 000 USD which would help us to develop the Toyze Pets App for Apple and Android devices and to create customizable 3D models for more How cool is that?

We truly believe that dogs are man’s best friends and we want to use 3D printing technology to deliver a new and amazing experience! 

More about Toyze below:

story:
Our children are staying indoors watching TV and playing video games more often these days. Can you blame them? Sometimes there is more nature on TV than in their own backyards, schoolyards and parks. 

The standard outdoor play space for kids is a plastic play structure surrounded by wood chips or gravel. 

The Kittitas Environmental Education Network recognizes that kids need more - they need to connect with nature in order to expand their confidence, create unique play experiences, and they need to get outside and move!

Our goal for this campaign is to raise $5,000 to create the Nature Explorers Playground at the Yakima Canyon Interpretive Center .

Coupled with donations from local suppliers and fueled by volunteers, this project will be a fantastic addition to the natural outdoor experience for kids.  Logs for climbing, willow huts to explore, nature music to create, water features to splash in, and a safe place to run and make new friends, the Nature Explorers Playground will Connect our Community to Nature.

Join us on this journey and by Spring 2016 our kids will have a great place to play!

story:
(Field visit with Prof Dr. Keshab Shrestha at Naulakot, Bhadrapur, Dadeldhura)

Farwest Nepal is unique and rich in traditions (indigenous systems and medicines) but the knowledge and resources of that area are eroding in accelerating ways because of socio-cultural transformations, degradation, and over-exploitation as well as climate change.

(Listening to the eldest individual of the village at Chipur, Dadeldhura) (The elder person often speaks in parables, the young has to listen closely, An old lie is often more popular than a new truth, German proverb)

When an old man die, a library burns to the ground, when an old woman dies, a school burns to the ground and when a child dies all burnt down to the ground). 

The knowledge erosion is apparent between grandparents and grandchildren. The grandchild neither knows the vernacular names and dialects nor their uses of indigenous plants. The indigenous culture is diminishing and the resources are declining at a rapid pace.  At present condition, the incorporation of non-indigenous resources into the natural environment is increasing.  Here we consider this process as a strategy to combat the diminishing condition of indigenous resources and a product of institutionalization.  However, the institutionalization of non-indigenous resources is contentious, and still needs to be studied.  

(Ex-Situ interview with traditional healer (Baidhya))

The participatory conservation of indigenous resources (species, habitat, and knowledge) has been started.  With your help, the completion and sharing this documentary will inform many others and its placement on youtube and other social media platforms will facilitate our reach to interested parties everywhere.   This will aid in connecting students to our elder community which are at the heart of the indigenous resource.  In turn, we will gain credibility allowing for better management of these indigenous resources. 


Our estimates for producing the documentary.


Some of my publications:

Kunwar, R. M., Mahat, L., Acharya, R. P., & Bussmann, R. W. (2013). Medicinal plants, traditional medicine, markets and management in far-west Nepal. Journal of ethnobiology and ethnomedicine, 9(1), 1.

Kunwar, R. M., Nepal, B. K., Kshhetri, H. B., Rai, S. K., & Bussmann, R. W. (2006). Ethnomedicine in Himalaya: a case study from Dolpa, Humla, Jumla and Mustang districts of Nepal. Journal of Ethnobiology and Ethnomedicine,2(1), 1.

Kunwar, R. M., Shrestha, K. P., & Bussmann, R. W. (2010). Traditional herbal medicine in Far-west Nepal: a pharmacological appraisal. Journal of Ethnobiology and Ethnomedicine, 6(1), 1.

Kunwar, R. M., Uprety, Y., Burlakoti, C., Chowdhary, C. L., & Bussmann, R. W. (2009). Indigenous use and ethnopharmacology of medicinal plants in Far-west Nepal.

Kunwar, R.M., Acharya, R.P., Chowdhary C.L. & Bussmann, R.W. (2015). Medicinal plant dynamics in Indigenous medicines in farwest Nepal. Journal of Ethnopharmacology, 163, 210-219.

story:
Contribute today & join the movement of ocean lovers working to start 3 NEW monthly beach cleanups!


PROPOSED NEW LOCATIONS:

SEAL BEACH, CALIFORNIA

SAN CLEMENTE, CALIFORNIA

OAHU, HAWAII


OUR PROGRESS SINCE 2010:

BEACH CLEANUPS: 68

TRASH REMOVED: 11,261lbs

NEXT BEACH CLEANUP: 07.09.2016

LEARN MORE ABOUT COASTAL PLAYGROUND



INTRODUCTION

Hello everyone!  My name is Andrew Sneddon and I am the proud owner and founder of Coastal Playground®. Over the past 5 years I have been developing a business model that I think you'll really dig, especially for you beach lovers out there.  We've been told we're the TOM's Shoes of the surf industry. 

You see, over years of surfing Southern California waters, one thing has become painfully obvious. POLLUTION is everywhere!! In the line-up, on the sand, in our harbors, you almost can't take a trip to the beach anymore without coming across a handful of garbage marring the beautiful scenery we've come to love and enjoy. 

Not sure about all of you, but I am tired of it, and instead of complaining, I decided to roll up my sleeves and go to work. 

And with that, Coastal Playground 50/50® was born; With every product you purchase, 50% of the proceeds will go towards beach cleanups. 

I have two daughters and there was no way I was going to let this continue. I couldn't imagine having to tell them one day, "Sorry hun, the pollution is just too bad today, we can't go surf tomorrow morning." It seriously kills me just thinking about it. Who wants to play helicopter parent in fear of the dangers that could be lurking in the sand? Not me! 

WHAT WE NEED

  • Our Goal = $7500
  • Indiegogo Percentage = %5 *plus tax & PayPal fees
  • Backers Needed = 150 @ an $81 average 

Removing this amount of trash month after month takes a serious amount of supplies, especially when the volunteer count is consistently growing. Our goal with this campaign is to raise the money necessary to purchase all the equipment needed to start 3 more monthly beach cleanups.  And, also provide additional supplies to our Huntington Beach and New York cleanups to ensure they keep operating smoothly for years to come.  Currently in our shop we donate 50% of the proceeds to our 50/50 partners.  With this campaign 100% of the earnings will go towards jump starting the expansion of our beach cleanup project and really help us increase our impact with these additional monthly cleanups.

  • 1 Ez-Up = $350 
  • Table = $25
  • Gloves = $30
  • Trash Pickers = $85
  • Reusable Bags = $32
  • 1 Fish Scale = $15
  • Total Cost = $537 x 3 NEW Monthly Beach Cleanups = $1611 (After cost of production, shipping, & fees for the perks, we will have around $1750.00 remaining)

The first of the three new monthly beach cleanups will start June or July in Seal Beach, CA.  Then the next month South Orange County.  And finally, the third will begin in Oahu, Hawaii in the month of August or September.  This will give us plenty of time to train new coordinators, secure partnerships with non-profits operating in the community, and obtain connections needed for a good volunteer base.  

Our current goal would provide us with enough money to fulfill all of the perks and the funds necessary to purchase supplies for 3 new monthly beach cleanups. If for any reason we do not hit our goal we will use the funds to start as many cleanups as possible with the money raised. If we surpass our goal, or receive a large percentage of donations we will use the additional funds to start a 4th monthly cleanup. 

PERKS

All of the perks we will be providing are made in the USA and printed locally in Los Angeles, CA. We use organic cottons, eco-friendly printing processes, and deliver a quality products that will not only help us make a huge impact but will also help you reduce your footprint in style. 

Limited Edition Perk: Hazmat Surfer Cell Phone Case

Limited Edition Perk: Waves Organic Cotton Tee

Perk #1: Organic Cotton Tee



Perk #2: Coffee MugPerk #3: Ocean Art Tote 



Perk #4: 12x16 Ocean Art Poster

Final images, designs, & sizes will be requested by the Coastal Playground Team the week before our campaign is complete in order to fulfill our perks in a timely fashion. All you will need to do is complete a quick survey via e-mail to gather all the information necessary to fulfill your perk. To view our full selection of Ocean Art, Clothing, & Accessories that you can choose from please feel free to visit our website and browse our shop - www.coastalplayground.com

THE IMPACT

Now, this is where the project really shines.  Year to Date, Coastal Playground has held 67 monthly beach cleanups in both Huntington Beach, CA & Long Island, New York via our 50/50® program.  In that time we have achieved some amazing results. If our campaign is successful and those results are multiplied several times over, we would be making a serious dent in the amount of pollution on local beaches.  

At Coastal Playground®, transparency is our middle name.  We provide all of our results on our website as if each individual purchasing a product is an investor in the company. We want you to know how much we're making, how much we're donating and what impact we are having in your community.  For a detailed record please visit our website where we provide a downloadable pdf with all of our results.

With over 10,997 lbs of trash removed & 12,000+ volunteers educated on the issues of coastal pollution our customers are helping us create an army of ocean protectors. According to independentsector.org the average cost of a volunteer hour is around $23's.  With over 23,000+ hours of volunteer hours clocked since our inception, we have essentially saved the cities we operate in hundreds of thousands of dollars. 

  • 67 Beach Cleanups (Huntington Beach, CA & New York)
  • 10,997 pounds of trash removed
  • 12,123 volunteers educated
  • 24,246 hours of volunteer hours
  • $574,630.25 saved in labor expenses

  • 330 Beach Cleanups (HB, NY, Seal Beach, South Orange County, Oahu)
  • 52,610 pounds of trash removed
  • 58,115 volunteers educated
  • 116,230 volunteer hours
  • $2,681,426.10 saved in labor expenses

THE TEAM

Ryan Frazzetta - Seal Beach Cleanup Coordinator
Shane Lono - Oahu Cleanup Coordinator
Michael Ambrose - South Orange County Cleanup Coordinator
Russ LaScala - New York Cleanup Coordinator
Kevin Oliphant - Ocean Art Director

RISKS & CHALLENGES

Obviously expanding a project to this level does not come without it's challenges; finding a location, securing a non-profit partner, & creating a base of consistent volunteer is no easy task.  But, after personally running 66 monthly beach cleanups in a row I am confident that I have the knowledge and skills necessary to train our next crop of cleanup coordinators.  Once our goal is funded we will be holding several training sessions to bring the new team up to speed and give them the tools needed to run a successful beach cleanup. 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Now for those of you who cannot necessarily contribute with a purchase, we get it. As a husband & father of two I totally understand that it's not always possible to shell out your hard earned dough even though you may really want to help out. 

That's why we have provided you with all the tools necessary to help without spending a dime. In the top left hand side of our Story Page there are links to our campaign, website, and e-mail newsletter.  Sharing these on your social media and telling your family what we're up to can really help us reach more of the people like you that would love to see us hit our goal.  Click away and help us start building an army of ocean protectors today!


Thank you for your support everyone, together we will make a difference!

Removing this amount of trash month after month takes a serious amount of supplies, especially when the volunteer count is consistently growing. Our goal with this campaign is to raise the money necessary to purchase all the equipment needed to start 3 more monthly beach cleanups.  And, also provide additional supplies to our Huntington Beach and New York cleanups to ensure they keep operating smoothly for years to come.  Currently in our shop we donate 50% of the proceeds to our 50/50 partners.  With this campaign 100% of the earnings will go towards jump starting the expansion of our beach cleanup project and really help us increase our impact with these additional monthly cleanups.
1 Ez-Up = $350 
Table = $25
Gloves = $30
Trash Pickers = $85
Reusable Bags = $32
1 Fish Scale = $15
Total Cost = $537 x 3 NEW Monthly Beach Cleanups = $1611 (After cost of production, shipping, & fees for the perks, we will have around $1750.00 remaining)
The first of the three new monthly beach cleanups will start June or July in Seal Beach, CA.  Then the next month South Orange County.  And finally, the third will begin in Oahu, Hawaii in the month of August or September.  This will give us plenty of time to train new coordinators, secure partnerships with non-profits operating in the community, and obtain connections needed for a good volunteer base.  Our current goal would provide us with enough money to fulfill all of the perks and the funds necessary to purchase supplies for 3 new monthly beach cleanups. If for any reason we do not hit our goal we will use the funds to start as many cleanups as possible with the money raised. If we surpass our goal, or receive a large percentage of donations we will use the additional funds to start a 4th monthly cleanup. PERKSAll of the perks we will be providing are made in the USA and printed locally in Los Angeles, CA. We use organic cottons, eco-friendly printing processes, and deliver a quality products that will not only help us make a huge impact but will also help you reduce your footprint in style. 
Limited Edition Perk: Hazmat Surfer Cell Phone Case


Limited Edition Perk: Waves Organic Cotton Tee
Perk #1: Organic Cotton Tee

Perk #2: Coffee MugPerk #3: Ocean Art Tote 

Perk #4: 12x16 Ocean Art Poster
Final images, designs, & sizes will be requested by the Coastal Playground Team the week before our campaign is complete in order to fulfill our perks in a timely fashion. All you will need to do is complete a quick survey via e-mail to gather all the information necessary to fulfill your perk. To view our full selection of Ocean Art, Clothing, & Accessories that you can choose from please feel free to visit our website and browse our shop - www.coastalplayground.com
THE IMPACT

Now, this is where the project really shines.  Year to Date, Coastal Playground has held 67 monthly beach cleanups in both Huntington Beach, CA & Long Island, New York via our 50/50® program.  In that time we have achieved some amazing results. If our campaign is successful and those results are multiplied several times over, we would be making a serious dent in the amount of pollution on local beaches.  


At Coastal Playground®, transparency is our middle name.  We provide all of our results on our website as if each individual purchasing a product is an investor in the company. We want you to know how much we're making, how much we're donating and what impact we are having in your community.  For a detailed record please visit our website where we provide a downloadable pdf with all of our results.


With over 10,997 lbs of trash removed & 12,000+ volunteers educated on the issues of coastal pollution our customers are helping us create an army of ocean protectors. According to independentsector.org the average cost of a volunteer hour is around $23's.  With over 23,000+ hours of volunteer hours clocked since our inception, we have essentially saved the cities we operate in hundreds of thousands of dollars. 

67 Beach Cleanups (Huntington Beach, CA & New York)
10,997 pounds of trash removed
12,123 volunteers educated
24,246 hours of volunteer hours
$574,630.25 saved in labor expenses


330 Beach Cleanups (HB, NY, Seal Beach, South Orange County, Oahu)
52,610 pounds of trash removed
58,115 volunteers educated
116,230 volunteer hours
$2,681,426.10 saved in labor expenses


THE TEAM

Ryan Frazzetta - Seal Beach Cleanup CoordinatorShane Lono - Oahu Cleanup CoordinatorMichael Ambrose - South Orange County Cleanup CoordinatorRuss LaScala - New York Cleanup CoordinatorKevin Oliphant - Ocean Art Director
RISKS & CHALLENGES
Obviously expanding a project to this level does not come
without it's challenges; finding a location, securing a non-profit partner,
& creating a base of consistent volunteer is no easy task.  But, after personally
running 66 monthly beach cleanups in a row I am confident that I have the knowledge and skills necessary to train our next crop of
cleanup coordinators.  Once our goal is funded we will be holding several
training sessions to bring the new team up to speed and give them the tools
needed to run a successful beach cleanup. 
OTHER WAYS TO HELP
Now for those of you who cannot necessarily contribute with
a purchase, we get it. As a husband & father of two I totally understand
that it's not always possible to shell out your hard earned dough even though
you may really want to help out. 
That's why we have provided you with all the tools necessary
to help without spending a dime. In the top left hand side of our Story Page there are links to our campaign, website, and
e-mail newsletter.  Sharing these on your social media and telling your
family what we're up to can really help us reach more of the people like you
that would love to see us hit our goal.  Click away and help us start
building an army of ocean protectors today!

Thank you for your support everyone, together we will make a difference!

story:
Currently, 23-46% of the CO2 produced by today's cars comes from the manufacturing process. That's outrageous! It could be half that if cars weren't made from metal, fiberglass, carbon fiber and petroleum plastics. We're on a mission to drastically reduce that figure, and are ready to start producing the very first Sports Car made in America with a body made from carbon negative hemp.

This innovation, may well be just as important to the environment as the advent of electric cars. And we need your help.

We don't have the hundreds of millions of dollars that the big car companies have for advertising, but we do have people like you that want greener and greener cars. Our "marketing" plan is to bring the car to the people...to Green Festivals, Hemp Festivals, Car shows and maybe even to car companies to show them as well, how to make what Henry Ford called "Cars Grown from The Soil."

Your contribution toward this nationwide tour could help change the automobile industry forever, and maybe other industries as well as they too discover that their products can be made from carbon negative hemp instead of oil, metal and petro-plastic.

Would you like to help us bring the car to a city near you, where you'll be invited to sit behind the wheel of  America's very first Hemp Sports Car and take a selfie? You can, by making a contribution to help fund the tour.

Or would you like to reserve your own Renew... or even own the very first car off the line, car number 00001? Rare car collectors...don't miss this opportunity! See the perks for details.

story:
The Green Ark Campaign

All of human life depends on plants.  They provide us with food, medicines and even the oxygen we breathe. 

My name is Bruce Labey and I am a Kew-trained botanical horticulturist. I am part of a small but dedicated group based in Jersey, the most southerly of the British Isles, and our plan is to turn this amazing island into a Green Ark to rescue endangered plants from other islands around the world and to grow and propagate  them.


Global warming and habitat destruction mean that many more plant species are moving closer to extinction every year.  Island species are under the greatest pressure of all.  These unique plants are absolutely vital to our future and there is a so much we could be doing here - Jersey really is an amazing place to grow plants. 

We need your help to make the most of the huge potential of our Island's fabulous microclimates. Our mission is to create a world class botanic garden to specialise in the conservation of island plant species. 

We have found the perfect site for our first garden, nestled in a beautiful south facing corner, sheltered from the wind and overlooking a stunning bay.  This is a truly glorious location and the park, when completed will hold a world heritage plant collection.   We want you to be a part of this, as custodians of these plants for the future.  


This is a truly inclusive project; it's for everyone, everywhere. As well as saving some of the rarest plants in the world, the Botanic Garden of Jersey will be doing everything it can to educate everyone about plants, organic horticulture, sustainability, biodiversity and the crucial importance of all of these to the survival of our own species. 

How you can help

We need to raise £25,000 to start the ball rolling, but obviously the more we can raise the better!

 As mentioned above, we have a site in mind and are working with local politicians to secure a 99 year lease for a local park.   We have worked hard in the background to quietly move this project to this point but now we need to move to the next level and start to deliver.  

We are very close to making this dream a reality.  we have a great deal of local support to get this moving but we now need money!  

How will the money be spent : 

  • to fund a survey of the site to help us with the design process;
  • to carry out an ecological survey of the plants and wildlife already on site;
  • for drawing up plans in order to get planning permission;
  • to launch our local educational and communication programmes;  
  • to engage with colleagues at Kew Gardens to plan future planting
  • to negotiate and secure the lease to the park

We have a huge list of to do's but this will give you an idea of where we need to start!

story:
Support Green Initiatives in raising funds to create a platform which will engage you with Andy Couturier, the author of The Abundance of Less. Together, let’s cultivate a critical understanding of todays increasing consumption patterns by which we use to compensate for our discontent with modern civilization and urban alienation. 

This campaign will support a three-week tour with Andy Couturtier during the late spring of 2018 in major Chinese cities including Shanghai, Hangzhou, and Beijing. We will discuss the life and teachings of ten Japanese individuals, whose ways of life points humanity in a direction of greater sustainability and satisfaction. Couturier inspires with the message to seek an abundance in well-being and self-sufficiency to grow away from the loop of materialism in our industrial economies.

Listen to Couturier speak at the Commonwealth Club here. 

The Mission

The campaign's mission is to facilitate a dialogue about sustainable modes of living and to foster an understanding of how each one of us can reduce the negative impact upon this planet. We need to recognize our common home and open our consciousness to the very plain fact, that it is only through collaboration and cooperation we will be able to resolve the challenges ahead - whether it is between China and the US, Europe and India, them and us, or between you and me.

We want to avoid mistakes which have already been made by other economies who have been on their journey of modernization for much longer. We want to grow a global dialogue beyond political and economic borders, share best practices, and align our efforts in creating a safe and sound future for all our children, wherever they are born.

We must learn from each other and with each other.

________________________________________________________________

"Certainly, there is something fundamentally modern in being able to choose different aspects of a way of life and put them together in a manner that makes sense to you. But what gets people in our society paralyzed sometimes is that there are so many options available, and we don’t have the internal fiber to make choices on a consistent and strongly held set of principles and values. We must learn how to meet more of our needs (which, after all, is the purpose of an economy) without relying on the inequalities and destructiveness of the current world order. Can we make the process of thinking and experimenting our way out of our dilemma an opportunity, a chance to build our values and characters? We could then use our minds to create a library of techniques that will make life better for ourselves, and for everyone. But whatever form it takes, it does require change." 

-

Andy Couturier

________________________________________________________________

The Project

Couturier will tour with Green Initiatives in the late spring of 2018 for three weeks Shanghai, Hangzhou, Beijing and other major Chinese cities, where we will host moderated book readings and podium discussions in cooperation with resident environmental activists.

The aim is to create a dialogue in China on the future of humanity as parallel to Couturier’s message in the Abundance of Less. Couturier’s book catalyzes a critical understanding of the increasing consumption behaviors found today which we use to compensate for our discontent with modern civilization and urban alienation.​

Will we continue to concentrate on consumption driven urban agglomerations or will rural and decentralized self-sufficiency turn out to be a genuine alternative?

The entire campaign will be documented with a photo and video blog, which we make available to a global online audience. We believe that there is considerable interest in how Chinese consumers think about the future of our planet and what they want to do about the environmental degradation which is currently most prevalent in their own country. At the end of the campaign, a campaign summary will be produced. 

________________________________________________________________

"We need to take a pause, a significant pause, to create a strategy and plan for the change to a slower, richer life. When we are maxed out, we slide into the way the system is already structured, the easiest way to do things. "

-

Andy Couturier

________________________________________________________________

The Budget

The single biggest risk to this project is financing it. 

We have calculated a required budget of approximately $15,000 USD (or ¥100,700 CNY) for travel expenses, accommodation, translation, and event organization for the total duration of 25 days.

You can also contribute using local China-based payments incl. WeChat, AliPay, and Union Pay through Yoopay - please scan QR code below. 

 

As of February 26, 2018, ¥2,250 has been raised on Yoopay!

This is a nonprofit campaign and we will provide complete transparency of all project income and expenses on our website, including a weekly fundraising summary.

The Team

Andy, Cynthia, Nitin, Knut

Andy is an essayist, poet and writing teacher. He lived in Japan for 4 years, where he taught, was a journalist, and worked on environmental causes. His first book is Writing Open the Mind and he has written for The Japan Times, Adbusters, The North American Review, Kyoto Journal, and The Oakland Tribune. He is the director of The Opening, a center for courses in writing.

Cynthia is the chief editor for The Abundance of Less. As the Couturier's partner, she consulted all aspects of the design, story development, photo selection, translation decision, interviews, and was an utterly reliable source of wise counsel over the thousands of decisions it takes to create a book. Cynthia will continue to coach Couturier before, during and after each of the planned book readings on the China tour.

Nitin is the founder and director of Green Initiatives, a Shanghai based nonprofit which collects and shares solutions for sustainable models of growth and consumption to trigger action and change behavior. Green Initiatives has a crowd of several thousand followers on our social media channels and have built a reputation for high end awareness events, action campaigns and impact projects. In his day-job he works as an architect for GIGA, an architecture firm which has developed RESET, a building standard for measuring healthy work environments.

Knut helps executive management with organizational development challenges in a Far East Asian context and supports key individuals to unfold their potential with Telos Pi. He lives since 17 years on and off in China, since 2009 with his wife and two children in Shanghai. Whenever he has time and something to say, he writes on his blogs about China, the future of work and dark matter.

The Background

Japan, for centuries, has copied China’s culture and commerce, was the most fervent disciple of Western modernization, emulating British industry, the German legal system and French bureaucratic centralization. Although Japan's industrial revolution started during the Meiji Restoration more than a century after Western Europe, it overtook the West latest in the 1990s, when its national financial crisis preceded the GFC by more than a decade.

It is against this backdrop of breakneck social transformation, the abandonment of its own culture and an urbanization rate exceeding 90% that Couturier found a few Japanese individuals who have decided to wrest authority over their lives away from a global market and a national government back into their own hands.

Couturier’s friends live in the Japanese countryside. There, they grow their own food and pursue what they are really interested in, whether it may be writing, playing music or working as artisans. Their lives are simple and one would say deprived of material affluence. But, by the emerging consensus on truly sustainable living, they are pioneers, showing the rest of us how to redefine wealth by being truly rich in social capital and abundant in creativity.

They are models that we can follow. Couturier's profiles inspire us to leave behind the clockwork of our industrial economies. He gives these philosophers who put their thinking into action a platform to teach an important lecture humanity should collectively listen; and we will provide a platform to engage with and learn from him directly.

Shanghai : a Symbol of China's Stellar Rise

The importance of reconnecting with oneself is and pursuing self-sufficiency for the greater community is evident. Within the last four decades, China has transformed into the single largest economy in terms of purchasing power - shaping the modern world like nothing ever before. It is not only the largest greenhouse gas emitter since 2007, but its growing class of affluent urban consumers exceeds already the total population of the US. The Chinese economy has been accelerating the exploitation of natural resources and the environmental degradation at an alarming rate. 

By recognizing our ability to be free from the trap of materialism through the pursuit of less, we can alleviate the heavy air pollution with smog carpeting the vast area between Beijing, Shanghai and Wuhan. China Water Risk reports that 57% of shallow ground water and 50% of deep ground water are severely polluted and not suitable for human contact let alone drinking. China’s soil pollution receives least attention, but is the most serious cause for concern.

 

________________________________________________________________

"So much discussion about “becoming more green” seems to promise us that if we only make lifestyle tweaks, drive more efficient cars and install more and better solar panels, we can feel good about ourselves, keep our cushiness, and call it “sustainability.” But in the back of our minds, I think we know those tiny adaptations are not going to make the difference that we need. […] I think (the nuclear crisis in) Fukushima has given us an opportunity to deeply consider whether the changes we need to make are simply reorienting consumerism, or more fundamental, like asking “What kind of world do I want to be living in, and what kind of life do I want to have for my children?”  

-

Andy Couturier

________________________________________________________________

The Call for Systemic Change 

We have identified Couturier’s book as one of the top sustainability reads of this decade, en par with if not more important than E.F. Schumacher’s Small is Beautiful. It does not remain to be postindustrial theory, but shows with real life examples how we can deal with the scarecrows of economic recession, unemployment and lack of intrinsic motivation.

Leading environmentalist Bill McKibben, who wrote the foreword to the new edition of Schumacher’s classic, says about The Abundance of Less: We are in an overheated world--physically and spiritually. It is extremely powerful to read of people who have managed to escape that world, not by traveling to outer space but by heading toward reality. This is subversive in the best possible way.

Our work is based on the conviction that an economic transformation towards sustainable models of growth must happen above all in China, which has in so many regards already taken over control of this spaceship, our earth. We believe that talking to Chinese in China about Couturier’s book will catalyze a critical understanding of the present-day consumption behavior, which is most dramatically reflected in the stellar rise of Chinese Single’s Day, the world’s largest offline and online shopping day. It is increased consumption by which we compensate for our discontent with modern civilization and urban alienation.

It is not our intention to criticize China, but to avoid or aggravate mistakes which have already been made by other economies which have been on their journey of modernization for much longer. We want to facilitate a global dialogue beyond political and economic borders, share best practices and align our efforts in creating a safe and sound future for all our children, wherever they are born. 

Our economies, whether those many 19th and 20th century national economies we are part of, or this one global economy which has come into existence during the last few decades, are like giant ocean vessels: the larger they are the more difficult they are to manoeuvre, the longer it takes to change their course.

Scientists tell us that this course is one of environmental and ultimately self-destruction, and many agree that we have about 20 years left to change direction before we reach a tipping point of no return; a point when climate change causes sea levels to rise, precipitation cycles to quicken, precipitation volumes and storm frequency to drastically increase.

ALICE BOWS-LARKIN on climate change

Despite this overwhelming scientific evidence and despite a growing number of people being aware that we are heading in the wrong direction, the vast majority of humankind fears an economic recession, because it is associated with unemployment on a massive scale, explosive inflation, increasing poverty and ultimately war. Keeping inflation low has become the magic trick of conservative post WWII central bankers who know how to read their respective societies’ financial, but fail to understand or ignore the social indicators.

We have been brainwashed for generations by Keynes and his disciples that economic growth is the only formula to wealth and well-being. We have adapted all our institutions and corporations to the dogma that size matters, and we have overheard the gospel of post-industrial economists like E.F. Schumacher who said already in the early 1970s that small is beautiful and that we need to value the irreplaceable capital which man has not made, but simply found, i.e. the earth’s natural resources.

Postindustrial thinking has produced the ideas of a resource based or circular economy, i.e. an alternative to an industrial, linear and ultimately destructive system of production. Yet, this body of thought has not managed to resolve the recession stigma, which by sheer terminology implies less than before.

ELLEN MCARTHUR on the circular economy

While most of the Western world is in the grip of fear of losing its material wealth, the industrial revolution and globalization have spread Western models of growth like an epidemic: breakneck urbanization, heavy capital investments, mass production, centralized development planning and advanced technology are elements of economic policy which all developing nations apply; in recent years camouflaged as a global rat race amongst knowledge economies.

It is above all India and China, the globe’s most populous nations, each of them inhabited by about three times more people than the EU and five times more than the US, which bring new urgency to a need for economic transformation. But it is exactly these two continent-like and relatively young nation states which are driven by the humiliation through the European scientific revolution to design their economic systems despite their avert dissatisfaction with Western hegemony in the same model.

In particular China has embarked on an unprecedented modernization trajectory. Urbanization rates have surpassed 50% in 2013 and all social structures including the labor markets are on a fast forward reorganization which is only comparable to what started in Europe during the second industrial revolution at the beginning of the 20th century, i.e. when electricity swept over businesses like a thunderstorm leaving no brick on another.

________________________________________________________________

"Many problems in the world cannot be solved by personal choice alone. In this book, it was important to me to emphasize all the social action that people in Japan are taking, locally and nationally. The culture of individualism in the West encourages us to blame ourselves for problems that are created by our society and economic system. I wouldn’t want this book to reinforce that way of thinking. If you are rushed, hectic, disconnected, driving too much, is that all your personal fault? I don’t think so. "

-

Andy Couturier

________________________________________________________________

If each national economic system were a giant clockwork and each one of us a tiny cogwheel in that machine, it would be impossible to reduce revolution let alone change direction. We are all part of larger social transformations, which demand to a certain degree being part of urbanized consumer societies. How can we regain our own momentum and build up torque?

A recession in national economies and the global industrial economy does not necessarily mean that humanity ends up in poverty. A recession in the industrial economy needs to be understood as a reduction of material wealth and profit to a minimum necessity. A reduction in material affluence must be embraced as the only possibility for a wealth in general well-being, that includes all of humanity and the Earth as a living ecosystem.

The German philosopher David Reinhard Precht tells us that the focus of modern societies on material wealth blocks spiritual well-being. It is in particular the exponential modernization of Chinese public transportation, which exemplifies how technocratic capitalism can accelerate a society's material progress. Many notice though that a progress in hardware must be balanced with an upgraded software. High tech infrastructure must be matched with a corresponding, moral (or if you prefer spiritual) value system. China gains rapidly ground in the first, but an increasing number of people feel emptiness in the latter.

TECHINSIDER VIDEO on China's high speed rail

As this spiritual void opens up ever wider, president Xi Jinping has launched in 2013 the socialist core value campaign, which tries to revive traditional Chinese religions, in particular Confucianism, Taoism and Buddhism, as a counter measure. Ian Johnson writes in his book The Souls of China, that religion provides a morality and frames of reference for universal aspirations—like justice, fairness, and decency—that are higher than any government’s agenda. Out of this is coming a China that is more than the hyper-mercantilist, fragile superpower that we know. It is a country engaging in a global conversation that affects all of us: how to restore solidarity and values to societies that have made economics the basis of most decisions. Perhaps because Chinese traditions were so savagely attacked over the past decades, and then replaced with such a naked form of capitalism, China might actually be at the forefront of this worldwide search for values.

A campaign which focuses on the resurrection of an ancient value system without changing the overlying economic system makes it almost impossible to truly harvest the promised changes: individual lives continue to be subjected to socialist capitalism and thus consumerism; they remain tiny sprockets in a giant clockwork which drives the largest economic flywheel humanity has ever seen.

Alternative models of lifestyle are therefore fervently sought after and have generated in China during the last decade a self-help market in similar size to the US, but like the government ordained renewal of traditional Chinese values, all these teachings remain to be subject to a linear industrial economy.  Aeon Magazine recently published a beautiful video about a few Chinese millennials who have chosen a different path of seeking satisfaction beyond money in the simplicity of rural China. An increasing number of young Western people leave urban areas and move to the countryside for farming and Andy provides the blueprint for why they do it by translating the wisdom of his sage-like Japanese friends into an empathy for all human and non-human life. The Abundance of Less can help us understand their underlying motivations.

________________________________________________________________

"What is the good life? To many it’s a code word for high-end design, gourmet food, and a red convertible. And so on. To others it’s narrowly defined as total rural food self-sufficiency. For Cynthia and me, it’s an everyday negotiation with the world as it is, a negotiation that must include a continual returning to our values, and a reexamination of whether we are holding to them as strongly as we are able to. It’s also about how we relate to others, both in our daily life but also to others in faraway parts of the planet who suffer from the waste churned out by the affluence of the industrialized world." 

-

Andy Couturier

________________________________________________________________

Additional Readings
