story_txt:
Support Green Initiatives in raising funds to create a platform which will engage you with Andy Couturier, the author of The Abundance of Less. Together, let’s cultivate a critical understanding of todays increasing consumption patterns by which we use to compensate for our discontent with modern civilization and urban alienation. This campaign will support a three-week tour with Andy Couturtier during the late spring of 2018 in major Chinese cities including Shanghai, Hangzhou, and Beijing. We will discuss the life and teachings of ten Japanese individuals, whose ways of life points humanity in a direction of greater sustainability and satisfaction. Couturier inspires with the message to seek an abundance in well-being and self-sufficiency to grow away from the loop of materialism in our industrial economies. Listen to Couturier speak at the Commonwealth Club here. The MissionThe campaign's mission is to facilitate a dialogue about sustainable modes of living and to foster an understanding of how each one of us can reduce the negative impact upon this planet. We need to recognize our common home and open our consciousness to the very plain fact, that it is only through collaboration and cooperation we will be able to resolve the challenges ahead - whether it is between China and the US, Europe and India, them and us, or between you and me.We want to avoid mistakes which have already been made by other economies who have been on their journey of modernization for much longer. We want to grow a global dialogue beyond political and economic borders, share best practices, and align our efforts in creating a safe and sound future for all our children, wherever they are born.We must learn from each other and with each other.________________________________________________________________"Certainly, there is something fundamentally modern in being able to choose different aspects of a way of life and put them together in a manner that makes sense to you. But what gets people in our society paralyzed sometimes is that there are so many options available, and we don’t have the internal fiber to make choices on a consistent and strongly held set of principles and values. We must learn how to meet more of our needs (which, after all, is the purpose of an economy) without relying on the inequalities and destructiveness of the current world order. Can we make the process of thinking and experimenting our way out of our dilemma an opportunity, a chance to build our values and characters? We could then use our minds to create a library of techniques that will make life better for ourselves, and for everyone. But whatever form it takes, it does require change." -Andy Couturier________________________________________________________________The ProjectCouturier will tour with Green Initiatives in the late spring of 2018 for three weeks Shanghai, Hangzhou, Beijing and other major Chinese cities, where we will host moderated book readings and podium discussions in cooperation with resident environmental activists.The aim is to create a dialogue in China on the future of humanity as parallel to Couturier’s message in the Abundance of Less. Couturier’s book catalyzes a critical understanding of the increasing consumption behaviors found today which we use to compensate for our discontent with modern civilization and urban alienation.​Will we continue to concentrate on consumption driven urban agglomerations or will rural and decentralized self-sufficiency turn out to be a genuine alternative?The entire campaign will be documented with a photo and video blog, which we make available to a global online audience. We believe that there is considerable interest in how Chinese consumers think about the future of our planet and what they want to do about the environmental degradation which is currently most prevalent in their own country. At the end of the campaign, a campaign summary will be produced. ________________________________________________________________"We need to take a pause, a significant pause, to create a strategy and plan for the change to a slower, richer life. When we are maxed out, we slide into the way the system is already structured, the easiest way to do things. "-Andy Couturier________________________________________________________________The BudgetThe single biggest risk to this project is financing it. We have calculated a required budget of approximately $15,000 USD (or ¥100,700 CNY) for travel expenses, accommodation, translation, and event organization for the total duration of 25 days.You can also contribute using local China-based payments incl. WeChat, AliPay, and Union Pay through Yoopay - please scan QR code below.  As of February 26, 2018, ¥2,250 has been raised on Yoopay!This is a nonprofit campaign and we will provide complete transparency of all project income and expenses on our website, including a weekly fundraising summary.The TeamAndy, Cynthia, Nitin, KnutAndy is an essayist, poet and writing teacher. He lived in Japan for 4 years, where he taught, was a journalist, and worked on environmental causes. His first book is Writing Open the Mind and he has written for The Japan Times, Adbusters, The North American Review, Kyoto Journal, and The Oakland Tribune. He is the director of The Opening, a center for courses in writing.Cynthia is the chief editor for The Abundance of Less. As the Couturier's partner, she consulted all aspects of the design, story development, photo selection, translation decision, interviews, and was an utterly reliable source of wise counsel over the thousands of decisions it takes to create a book. Cynthia will continue to coach Couturier before, during and after each of the planned book readings on the China tour.Nitin is the founder and director of Green Initiatives, a Shanghai based nonprofit which collects and shares solutions for sustainable models of growth and consumption to trigger action and change behavior. Green Initiatives has a crowd of several thousand followers on our social media channels and have built a reputation for high end awareness events, action campaigns and impact projects. In his day-job he works as an architect for GIGA, an architecture firm which has developed RESET, a building standard for measuring healthy work environments.Knut helps executive management with organizational development challenges in a Far East Asian context and supports key individuals to unfold their potential with Telos Pi. He lives since 17 years on and off in China, since 2009 with his wife and two children in Shanghai. Whenever he has time and something to say, he writes on his blogs about China, the future of work and dark matter.The BackgroundJapan, for centuries, has copied China’s culture and commerce, was the most fervent disciple of Western modernization, emulating British industry, the German legal system and French bureaucratic centralization. Although Japan's industrial revolution started during the Meiji Restoration more than a century after Western Europe, it overtook the West latest in the 1990s, when its national financial crisis preceded the GFC by more than a decade.It is against this backdrop of breakneck social transformation, the abandonment of its own culture and an urbanization rate exceeding 90% that Couturier found a few Japanese individuals who have decided to wrest authority over their lives away from a global market and a national government back into their own hands.Couturier’s friends live in the Japanese countryside. There, they grow their own food and pursue what they are really interested in, whether it may be writing, playing music or working as artisans. Their lives are simple and one would say deprived of material affluence. But, by the emerging consensus on truly sustainable living, they are pioneers, showing the rest of us how to redefine wealth by being truly rich in social capital and abundant in creativity.They are models that we can follow. Couturier's profiles inspire us to leave behind the clockwork of our industrial economies. He gives these philosophers who put their thinking into action a platform to teach an important lecture humanity should collectively listen; and we will provide a platform to engage with and learn from him directly.Shanghai : a Symbol of China's Stellar RiseThe importance of reconnecting with oneself is and pursuing self-sufficiency for the greater community is evident. Within the last four decades, China has transformed into the single largest economy in terms of purchasing power - shaping the modern world like nothing ever before. It is not only the largest greenhouse gas emitter since 2007, but its growing class of affluent urban consumers exceeds already the total population of the US. The Chinese economy has been accelerating the exploitation of natural resources and the environmental degradation at an alarming rate. By recognizing our ability to be free from the trap of materialism through the pursuit of less, we can alleviate the heavy air pollution with smog carpeting the vast area between Beijing, Shanghai and Wuhan. China Water Risk reports that 57% of shallow ground water and 50% of deep ground water are severely polluted and not suitable for human contact let alone drinking. China’s soil pollution receives least attention, but is the most serious cause for concern. ________________________________________________________________"So much discussion about “becoming more green” seems to promise us that if we only make lifestyle tweaks, drive more efficient cars and install more and better solar panels, we can feel good about ourselves, keep our cushiness, and call it “sustainability.” But in the back of our minds, I think we know those tiny adaptations are not going to make the difference that we need. […] I think (the nuclear crisis in) Fukushima has given us an opportunity to deeply consider whether the changes we need to make are simply reorienting consumerism, or more fundamental, like asking “What kind of world do I want to be living in, and what kind of life do I want to have for my children?”  - Andy Couturier________________________________________________________________The Call for Systemic Change We have identified Couturier’s book as one of the top sustainability reads of this decade, en par with if not more important than E.F. Schumacher’s Small is Beautiful. It does not remain to be postindustrial theory, but shows with real life examples how we can deal with the scarecrows of economic recession, unemployment and lack of intrinsic motivation.Leading environmentalist Bill McKibben, who wrote the foreword to the new edition of Schumacher’s classic, says about The Abundance of Less: We are in an overheated world--physically and spiritually. It is extremely powerful to read of people who have managed to escape that world, not by traveling to outer space but by heading toward reality. This is subversive in the best possible way. Our work is based on the conviction that an economic transformation towards sustainable models of growth must happen above all in China, which has in so many regards already taken over control of this spaceship, our earth. We believe that talking to Chinese in China about Couturier’s book will catalyze a critical understanding of the present-day consumption behavior, which is most dramatically reflected in the stellar rise of Chinese Single’s Day, the world’s largest offline and online shopping day. It is increased consumption by which we compensate for our discontent with modern civilization and urban alienation.It is not our intention to criticize China, but to avoid or aggravate mistakes which have already been made by other economies which have been on their journey of modernization for much longer. We want to facilitate a global dialogue beyond political and economic borders, share best practices and align our efforts in creating a safe and sound future for all our children, wherever they are born. Our economies, whether those many 19th and 20th century national economies we are part of, or this one global economy which has come into existence during the last few decades, are like giant ocean vessels: the larger they are the more difficult they are to manoeuvre, the longer it takes to change their course.Scientists tell us that this course is one of environmental and ultimately self-destruction, and many agree that we have about 20 years left to change direction before we reach a tipping point of no return; a point when climate change causes sea levels to rise, precipitation cycles to quicken, precipitation volumes and storm frequency to drastically increase.ALICE BOWS-LARKIN on climate changeDespite this overwhelming scientific evidence and despite a growing number of people being aware that we are heading in the wrong direction, the vast majority of humankind fears an economic recession, because it is associated with unemployment on a massive scale, explosive inflation, increasing poverty and ultimately war. Keeping inflation low has become the magic trick of conservative post WWII central bankers who know how to read their respective societies’ financial, but fail to understand or ignore the social indicators.We have been brainwashed for generations by Keynes and his disciples that economic growth is the only formula to wealth and well-being. We have adapted all our institutions and corporations to the dogma that size matters, and we have overheard the gospel of post-industrial economists like E.F. Schumacher who said already in the early 1970s that small is beautiful and that we need to value the irreplaceable capital which man has not made, but simply found, i.e. the earth’s natural resources.Postindustrial thinking has produced the ideas of a resource based or circular economy, i.e. an alternative to an industrial, linear and ultimately destructive system of production. Yet, this body of thought has not managed to resolve the recession stigma, which by sheer terminology implies less than before.ELLEN MCARTHUR on the circular economyWhile most of the Western world is in the grip of fear of losing its material wealth, the industrial revolution and globalization have spread Western models of growth like an epidemic: breakneck urbanization, heavy capital investments, mass production, centralized development planning and advanced technology are elements of economic policy which all developing nations apply; in recent years camouflaged as a global rat race amongst knowledge economies.It is above all India and China, the globe’s most populous nations, each of them inhabited by about three times more people than the EU and five times more than the US, which bring new urgency to a need for economic transformation. But it is exactly these two continent-like and relatively young nation states which are driven by the humiliation through the European scientific revolution to design their economic systems despite their avert dissatisfaction with Western hegemony in the same model.In particular China has embarked on an unprecedented modernization trajectory. Urbanization rates have surpassed 50% in 2013 and all social structures including the labor markets are on a fast forward reorganization which is only comparable to what started in Europe during the second industrial revolution at the beginning of the 20th century, i.e. when electricity swept over businesses like a thunderstorm leaving no brick on another.________________________________________________________________"Many problems in the world cannot be solved by personal choice alone. In this book, it was important to me to emphasize all the social action that people in Japan are taking, locally and nationally. The culture of individualism in the West encourages us to blame ourselves for problems that are created by our society and economic system. I wouldn’t want this book to reinforce that way of thinking. If you are rushed, hectic, disconnected, driving too much, is that all your personal fault? I don’t think so. "- Andy Couturier________________________________________________________________If each national economic system were a giant clockwork and each one of us a tiny cogwheel in that machine, it would be impossible to reduce revolution let alone change direction. We are all part of larger social transformations, which demand to a certain degree being part of urbanized consumer societies. How can we regain our own momentum and build up torque?A recession in national economies and the global industrial economy does not necessarily mean that humanity ends up in poverty. A recession in the industrial economy needs to be understood as a reduction of material wealth and profit to a minimum necessity. A reduction in material affluence must be embraced as the only possibility for a wealth in general well-being, that includes all of humanity and the Earth as a living ecosystem.The German philosopher David Reinhard Precht tells us that the focus of modern societies on material wealth blocks spiritual well-being. It is in particular the exponential modernization of Chinese public transportation, which exemplifies how technocratic capitalism can accelerate a society's material progress. Many notice though that a progress in hardware must be balanced with an upgraded software. High tech infrastructure must be matched with a corresponding, moral (or if you prefer spiritual) value system. China gains rapidly ground in the first, but an increasing number of people feel emptiness in the latter.TECHINSIDER VIDEO on China's high speed railAs this spiritual void opens up ever wider, president Xi Jinping has launched in 2013 the socialist core value campaign, which tries to revive traditional Chinese religions, in particular Confucianism, Taoism and Buddhism, as a counter measure. Ian Johnson writes in his book The Souls of China, that religion provides a morality and frames of reference for universal aspirations—like justice, fairness, and decency—that are higher than any government’s agenda. Out of this is coming a China that is more than the hyper-mercantilist, fragile superpower that we know. It is a country engaging in a global conversation that affects all of us: how to restore solidarity and values to societies that have made economics the basis of most decisions. Perhaps because Chinese traditions were so savagely attacked over the past decades, and then replaced with such a naked form of capitalism, China might actually be at the forefront of this worldwide search for values.A campaign which focuses on the resurrection of an ancient value system without changing the overlying economic system makes it almost impossible to truly harvest the promised changes: individual lives continue to be subjected to socialist capitalism and thus consumerism; they remain tiny sprockets in a giant clockwork which drives the largest economic flywheel humanity has ever seen.Alternative models of lifestyle are therefore fervently sought after and have generated in China during the last decade a self-help market in similar size to the US, but like the government ordained renewal of traditional Chinese values, all these teachings remain to be subject to a linear industrial economy.  Aeon Magazine recently published a beautiful video about a few Chinese millennials who have chosen a different path of seeking satisfaction beyond money in the simplicity of rural China. An increasing number of young Western people leave urban areas and move to the countryside for farming and Andy provides the blueprint for why they do it by translating the wisdom of his sage-like Japanese friends into an empathy for all human and non-human life. The Abundance of Less can help us understand their underlying motivations.________________________________________________________________"What is the good life? To many it’s a code word for high-end design, gourmet food, and a red convertible. And so on. To others it’s narrowly defined as total rural food self-sufficiency. For Cynthia and me, it’s an everyday negotiation with the world as it is, a negotiation that must include a continual returning to our values, and a reexamination of whether we are holding to them as strongly as we are able to. It’s also about how we relate to others, both in our daily life but also to others in faraway parts of the planet who suffer from the waste churned out by the affluence of the industrialized world." -Andy Couturier________________________________________________________________Additional Readings

 Andy Couturier

story:
Hola, soy Emilio Lovera. Quiénes realmente me conocen, saben que desde niño he tenido como pasión el paisaje natural venezolano y toda su biodiversidad. Aunque no lo crean, mi primera opción para convertirme en profesional fue buscando trabajo como Guarda Parques en el sistema de Parques Nacionales de Venezuela, pero por diferentes razones nunca se cumplió ese sueño. Luego de todos estos años estoy decidido a realizarlo. Ha surgido una oportunidad para trabajar en pro de la defensa y conservación de nuestra asombrosa naturaleza. Recientemente mi hijo Tomás, quien comparte esta misma inquietud y yo, nos unimos al equipo de la Fundación para la Conservación de Biodiversidad: PROBIODIVERSA, quienes vienen desarrollando proyectos interesantes acerca de nuestra diversidad biológica, a través de producciones audiovisuales de calidad para darle promoción a uno de nuestros mayores atributos como país: su Megadiversidad. 

 

 ¿Sabían ustedes que Venezuela es uno de los 17 países con mayor Biodiversidad de todo el Planeta, y son llamados MEGADIVERSOS?

 

La Cordillera de Los Andes de Mérida en Venezuela, pertenece a la Ecorregión de Los Andes Tropicales, y es el ecosistema con la mayor biodiversidad de todo el planeta tierra.  Éste Estado forma parte de la cadena montañosa más extensa del mundo, la cual nos aporta gran parte del agua que consumimos así como del oxígeno limpio que respiramos. Uno de los problemas ambientales que ha suscitado mayor interés mundial en esta década es la pérdida de biodiversidad como consecuencia de las actividades humanas, ya sea de manera directa o indirecta, y nuestros andes venezolanos no escapan de esta realidad a cualquier escala ecológica.

 

 

Queremos compartir con los venezolanos y con todo aquel consciente de la importancia de la conservación, una historia que fortalecerá el sentimiento de pertenencia por nuestro país a través de su naturaleza. Renny Ottolina sabiamente dijo: ¿Cómo se ama al país si no se le respeta?, ¿Cómo se le respeta si no se le admira? Y ¿Cómo se le admira si no se le conoce?

 

 

Como persona ligada a los medios por tantos años, conozco y estoy convencido, que las artes visuales son una potente estrategia para la sensibilización y educación de la sociedad en cualquier tema. Es por ello que a través de piezas audiovisuales y otras acciones, generaremos un mensaje de consciencia para la conservación del ambiente. En este caso específico, acerca de una especie endémica y desconocida en nuestro país que está en peligro crítico de extinción.

Se trata de:  El Venado de Cola Blanca de Páramo llamado científicamente Odocoileus lasiotis, habita de forma exclusiva en ambientes abiertos de páramo del Estado Mérida por encima de 3.000 metros de altura sobre el nivel del mar (ver mapa de distribución debajo).

 

 

¿Sabían que este Venado solamente se encuentra en  algunos páramos del estado Mérida?

 

Es la historia de una especie de Venado de Cola Blanca que evolucionó al menos unos 400 mil años separada de cualquier otra población de venados de cola blanca debido al aislamiento geográfico que tuvieron por el crecimiento de la cadena montañosa de los Andes, quedando confinados exclusivamente a los ambientes de páramo del estado Mérida por encima de los 3.000 m.s.n.m. Este venado es de tamaño mediano, mide entre 90 cm y 1,5 m de longitud, tiene un peso que varía desde los 50Kg hasta los 70 Kg. A diferencia de otros venados, el Venado de Cola Blanca de Páramo posee el pelaje mucho más denso y largo, una inconfundible coloración gris oscura, con tonos pardos en casi todo el cuerpo y presenta el típico manchado blanco en la parte central y posterior del vientre que continúa hasta los glúteos y la parte inferior de la cola. Un estudio realizado hace casi 20 años, arrojó datos preliminares sobre su población: alrededor de 240 ejemplares en vida silvestre. Hoy en día no se tienen datos censuales ni de distribución pero se teme una reducción importante del número de ejemplares.

 

En estas dos fotografías se pueden observar algunas de las notables diferencias físicas de dos especies de venado de cola blanca de Venezuela (a la izquierda, la especie de Venado de Cola Blanca de Páramo Odocoileus lasiotis y a la derecha, la especie de Venado de Cola Blanca de las tierras bajas Odocoileus virginanus)

 

Los dos principales problemas que han llevado a este venado al borde de la extinción son: la depredación por parte de perros cimarrones (perros domésticos abandonados que se convierten en hábiles depredadores semisalvajes, pudiendo cazar más de 20 venados al año) seguida de la cacería furtiva que todavía se realiza sobre sus reducidas poblaciones. En este ambiente de páramo sobre los 3.000 m.s.n.m. también habitan depredadores naturales como lo son: el Puma o León de Montaña y el Oso Frontino o de Anteojos  pero ninguno de los dos son culpables de una disminución alarmante del numero de venados, al contrario, son controladores de los ejemplares enfermos y heridos manteniendo sanas las poblaciones. 

 

¿Quieres disfrutar e impresionarte con una muestra de los audiovisuales de PROBIODIVERSA?

 

VISITA  WWW.PROBIODIVERSA.ORG Y NUESTRO CANAL EN  YOUTUBE: “PROBIODIVERSA CANAL”.

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d39pa6axgXw

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=phDFfeoCjkQ

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CwasJWme2zQ

 

OBJETIVOS Y METAS A CUMPLIR:

  •  El propósito de esta campaña es colectar recursos que nos permitan filmar un documental de 24 min en calidad Full HD junto a otra serie de acciones  en pro de la conservación de este hermoso Venado.  Queremos contarles una verdadera historia de supervivencia, acerca de una especie que se ha adaptado por miles de años a un ecosistema de condiciones extremas, y que actualmente a causa del ser humano, está en peligro crítico de extinción, a punto de desaparecer. Este material será transmitido por algunos canales de TV tanto regional como nacional. También será proyectado y entregado en comunidades, escuelas e instituciones educativas.

La realización completa del documental constará de 7 semanas (5 de producción y 2 de post-producción)

  •  Haremos también un resumen de 12 minutos de la pieza original para ser transmitida en las principales cadenas de cine del país, previo a las películas (un espacio que actualmente está vigente para transmitir producciones nacionales independientes).
  •  Editaremos algunos micros audiovisuales de 1 minuto de duración como campaña de divulgación y concientización de la situación del venado a través de medios de comunicación digital y redes sociales.
  •  Se grabarán micros de radio sobre el venado, para su posterior difusión.
  •  Usaremos los resultados obtenidos como incentivo para activar un plan formal de conservación y promoción de esta especie como emblema del Estado Mérida.
  • Haremos visitas a escuelas y otras instituciones educativas en las comunidades adyacentes al área de páramo donde pudiera ubicarse el venado, para dar charlas y proyectar el documental como estrategia de sensibilización y conservación de la especie y el medio ambiente.
  • Durante estas visitas a las comunidades abordaremos el tema de la crianza, manejo y control de los perros como mascotas para evitar que siga aumentando la población de perros salvajes.
  • Promoveremos la redacción de una ley en el Consejo Legislativo de la ciudad de Mérida para la conservación del Venado.
  • Realizaremos el diseño de una valla informativa que promueva la conservación del Venado de Cola Blanca de Páramo que será colocada a orillas de la carretera del sector de Mucubají.
  • Realizaremos expediciones científicas dentro de la posible área de distribución del Venado (observar mapa inferior), que nos permitan determinar nuevos registros de la especie.

En la imagen de abajo pueden observar la posible distribución que debería tener el Venado dentro del Estado Mérida (polígono de color amarillo), pero es sólo en un par de lugares es donde realmente se pueden observar éstos Venados en estado silvestre (símbolos color azul turquesa) En el resto de su posible distribución (símbolos de interrogación color rojo), los Venados han dejado de verse en estado silvestre, o simplemente nunca se han realizado expediciones científicas para determinar su presencia.


 

 

A pesar de la situación social y económica que vivimos los venezolanos, el cuidado y la preservación del ambiente no deben ser olvidados! Cada día los atropellos a la naturaleza son más numerosos y es necesario generar consciencia en nuestra sociedad.

 

 

Ayúdanos a dar comienzo a esta serie de acciones para la conservación y recuperación de este hermoso animal. Evitemos que se convierta en el primer mamífero extinto para nuestro país.

 

RIESGOS  Y DESAFÍOS:

Para minimizar el riesgo involucrado en la ejecución del proyecto y poder lograr los objetivos planteados, la Fundación PROBIODIVERSA lleva invirtiendo más de 12 meses en salidas de pre-producción hacia lugares donde se pueden observar algunos de estos escasos venados, así como reuniones con las diferentes instituciones que deben avalar nuestras actividades. También ha realizado visitas para crear buenas relaciones con comunidades aisladas que conviven dentro del hábitat del venado.

Ya hemos conformado un equipo humano perfectamente capacitado para los requerimientos de este proyecto. PROBIODIVERSA tiene su origen y sede en el estado Mérida y todo el contexto alrededor del proyecto es algo familiar para el equipo.

 

Los recursos solicitados serán destinados para cumplir los  objetivos y se usarán de la siguiente manera:

 

  • Impuestos para el ingreso y filmación en áreas protegidas como Parques Nacionales.
  • Guías Locales para la incursión en áreas retiradas y de difícil acceso.
  • Catering para el equipo de producción.
  • Honorarios profesionales del equipo humano contratado para el proyecto (Director, Editor, Música Original, Camarógrafos, Productor ejecutivo, Biólogo de campo, Asistentes de campo, Guías locales, Guionista, Diseñador gráfico, Contador, Operador de Drone).
  • Transporte del equipo de producción.
  • Hospedaje durante la producción.
  • Alquiler de algunos equipos de producción.
  • Alquiler de 2 caballos para el transporte de los equipos materiales en áreas de difícil acceso.
  • Adquisición de 1 Disco duro externo.
  • Adquisición de 4 baterías adicionales para las cámaras de video.
  • Adquisición de 4 tarjetas de memoria para las cámaras de video.
  • Adquisición de Bombonas de Gas de excursión para las cocinas.
  • Adquisición de baterías AA, AAA y taco D, para todos los aparatos electrónicos (GPS, Linternas, microfonía y cámaras de sensores remotos)

Este proyecto en INDIEGOGO estará en el formato INDEMAND, el cual, una vez se acabe el tiempo establecido de la campaña (60 días), pueda seguir recibiendo aportes de personas que se sumen a creer en esta iniciativa.

 

¿Cómo nos puedes ayudar?

 

  • Adquiere alguna de las atractivas recompensas que tendremos disponibles.
  • Ayúdanos a difundir el mensaje por todos los medios digitales.
  • Síguenos en las Redes Sociales.

 

Invita a tus amigos y a todas las personas que puedas a que adquieran alguna de nuestras recompensas que van desde

1$ en adelante.

 

“Nota: Todas las fotos utilizadas en esta presentación de campaña pertenecen a los Archivos de PROBIODIVERSA”

 

 

 

 

Con tu ayuda y la de aliados comprometidos, realizaremos este proyecto que no tiene precedentes  en el país.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 Nota Especial: a todas las personas (natural como jurídica) que vivan en el extranjero, si aún mantienen alguna empresa o actividad económica dentro del país, se les puede hacer entrega de una factura de la Fundación, la cual está certificada y brinda beneficios contables sobre los Impuestos Sobre la Renta.
story_txt:
Hola, soy Emilio Lovera. Quiénes realmente me conocen, saben que desde niño he tenido como pasión el paisaje natural venezolano y toda su biodiversidad. Aunque no lo crean, mi primera opción para convertirme en profesional fue buscando trabajo como Guarda Parques en el sistema de Parques Nacionales de Venezuela, pero por diferentes razones nunca se cumplió ese sueño. Luego de todos estos años estoy decidido a realizarlo. Ha surgido una oportunidad para trabajar en pro de la defensa y conservación de nuestra asombrosa naturaleza. Recientemente mi hijo Tomás, quien comparte esta misma inquietud y yo, nos unimos al equipo de la Fundación para la Conservación de Biodiversidad: PROBIODIVERSA, quienes vienen desarrollando proyectos interesantes acerca de nuestra diversidad biológica, a través de producciones audiovisuales de calidad para darle promoción a uno de nuestros mayores atributos como país: su Megadiversidad.   ¿Sabían ustedes que Venezuela es uno de los 17 países con mayor Biodiversidad de todo el Planeta, y son llamados MEGADIVERSOS? La Cordillera de Los Andes de Mérida en Venezuela, pertenece a la Ecorregión de Los Andes Tropicales, y es el ecosistema con la mayor biodiversidad de todo el planeta tierra.  Éste Estado forma parte de la cadena montañosa más extensa del mundo, la cual nos aporta gran parte del agua que consumimos así como del oxígeno limpio que respiramos. Uno de los problemas ambientales que ha suscitado mayor interés mundial en esta década es la pérdida de biodiversidad como consecuencia de las actividades humanas, ya sea de manera directa o indirecta, y nuestros andes venezolanos no escapan de esta realidad a cualquier escala ecológica.  Queremos compartir con los venezolanos y con todo aquel consciente de la importancia de la conservación, una historia que fortalecerá el sentimiento de pertenencia por nuestro país a través de su naturaleza. Renny Ottolina sabiamente dijo: ¿Cómo se ama al país si no se le respeta?, ¿Cómo se le respeta si no se le admira? Y ¿Cómo se le admira si no se le conoce?  Como persona ligada a los medios por tantos años, conozco y estoy convencido, que las artes visuales son una potente estrategia para la sensibilización y educación de la sociedad en cualquier tema. Es por ello que a través de piezas audiovisuales y otras acciones, generaremos un mensaje de consciencia para la conservación del ambiente. En este caso específico, acerca de una especie endémica y desconocida en nuestro país que está en peligro crítico de extinción.Se trata de:  El Venado de Cola Blanca de Páramo llamado científicamente Odocoileus lasiotis, habita de forma exclusiva en ambientes abiertos de páramo del Estado Mérida por encima de 3.000 metros de altura sobre el nivel del mar (ver mapa de distribución debajo).  ¿Sabían que este Venado solamente se encuentra en  algunos páramos del estado Mérida? Es la historia de una especie de Venado de Cola Blanca que evolucionó al menos unos 400 mil años separada de cualquier otra población de venados de cola blanca debido al aislamiento geográfico que tuvieron por el crecimiento de la cadena montañosa de los Andes, quedando confinados exclusivamente a los ambientes de páramo del estado Mérida por encima de los 3.000 m.s.n.m. Este venado es de tamaño mediano, mide entre 90 cm y 1,5 m de longitud, tiene un peso que varía desde los 50Kg hasta los 70 Kg. A diferencia de otros venados, el Venado de Cola Blanca de Páramo posee el pelaje mucho más denso y largo, una inconfundible coloración gris oscura, con tonos pardos en casi todo el cuerpo y presenta el típico manchado blanco en la parte central y posterior del vientre que continúa hasta los glúteos y la parte inferior de la cola. Un estudio realizado hace casi 20 años, arrojó datos preliminares sobre su población: alrededor de 240 ejemplares en vida silvestre. Hoy en día no se tienen datos censuales ni de distribución pero se teme una reducción importante del número de ejemplares. En estas dos fotografías se pueden observar algunas de las notables diferencias físicas de dos especies de venado de cola blanca de Venezuela (a la izquierda, la especie de Venado de Cola Blanca de Páramo Odocoileus lasiotis y a la derecha, la especie de Venado de Cola Blanca de las tierras bajas Odocoileus virginanus) Los dos principales problemas que han llevado a este venado al borde de la extinción son: la depredación por parte de perros cimarrones (perros domésticos abandonados que se convierten en hábiles depredadores semisalvajes, pudiendo cazar más de 20 venados al año) seguida de la cacería furtiva que todavía se realiza sobre sus reducidas poblaciones. En este ambiente de páramo sobre los 3.000 m.s.n.m. también habitan depredadores naturales como lo son: el Puma o León de Montaña y el Oso Frontino o de Anteojos  pero ninguno de los dos son culpables de una disminución alarmante del numero de venados, al contrario, son controladores de los ejemplares enfermos y heridos manteniendo sanas las poblaciones.  ¿Quieres disfrutar e impresionarte con una muestra de los audiovisuales de PROBIODIVERSA? VISITA  WWW.PROBIODIVERSA.ORG Y NUESTRO CANAL EN  YOUTUBE: “PROBIODIVERSA CANAL”.
 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d39pa6axgXwhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=phDFfeoCjkQhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CwasJWme2zQ OBJETIVOS Y METAS A CUMPLIR: El propósito de esta campaña es colectar recursos que nos permitan filmar un documental de 24 min en calidad Full HD junto a otra serie de acciones  en pro de la conservación de este hermoso Venado.  Queremos contarles una verdadera historia de supervivencia, acerca de una especie que se ha adaptado por miles de años a un ecosistema de condiciones extremas, y que actualmente a causa del ser humano, está en peligro crítico de extinción, a punto de desaparecer. Este material será transmitido por algunos canales de TV tanto regional como nacional. También será proyectado y entregado en comunidades, escuelas e instituciones educativas.La realización completa del documental constará de 7 semanas (5 de producción y 2 de post-producción) Haremos también un resumen de 12 minutos de la pieza original para ser transmitida en las principales cadenas de cine del país, previo a las películas (un espacio que actualmente está vigente para transmitir producciones nacionales independientes).
 Editaremos algunos micros audiovisuales de 1 minuto de duración como campaña de divulgación y concientización de la situación del venado a través de medios de comunicación digital y redes sociales.
 Se grabarán micros de radio sobre el venado, para su posterior difusión.
 Usaremos los resultados obtenidos como incentivo para activar un plan formal de conservación y promoción de esta especie como emblema del Estado Mérida.
Haremos visitas a escuelas y otras instituciones educativas en las comunidades adyacentes al área de páramo donde pudiera ubicarse el venado, para dar charlas y proyectar el documental como estrategia de sensibilización y conservación de la especie y el medio ambiente.
Durante estas visitas a las comunidades abordaremos el tema de la crianza, manejo y control de los perros como mascotas para evitar que siga aumentando la población de perros salvajes.
Promoveremos la redacción de una ley en el Consejo Legislativo de la ciudad de Mérida para la conservación del Venado.
Realizaremos el diseño de una valla informativa que promueva la conservación del Venado de Cola Blanca de Páramo que será colocada a orillas de la carretera del sector de Mucubají.
Realizaremos expediciones científicas dentro de la posible área de distribución del Venado (observar mapa inferior), que nos permitan determinar nuevos registros de la especie.
En la imagen de abajo pueden observar la posible distribución que debería tener el Venado dentro del Estado Mérida (polígono de color amarillo), pero es sólo en un par de lugares es donde realmente se pueden observar éstos Venados en estado silvestre (símbolos color azul turquesa) En el resto de su posible distribución (símbolos de interrogación color rojo), los Venados han dejado de verse en estado silvestre, o simplemente nunca se han realizado expediciones científicas para determinar su presencia.  A pesar de la situación social y económica que vivimos los venezolanos, el cuidado y la preservación del ambiente no deben ser olvidados! Cada día los atropellos a la naturaleza son más numerosos y es necesario generar consciencia en nuestra sociedad.  
Ayúdanos a dar comienzo a esta serie de acciones para la conservación y recuperación de este hermoso animal. Evitemos que se convierta en el primer mamífero extinto para nuestro país.
 
RIESGOS  Y DESAFÍOS:
Para minimizar el riesgo involucrado en la ejecución del proyecto y poder lograr los objetivos planteados, la Fundación PROBIODIVERSA lleva invirtiendo más de 12 meses en salidas de pre-producción hacia lugares donde se pueden observar algunos de estos escasos venados, así como reuniones con las diferentes instituciones que deben avalar nuestras actividades. También ha realizado visitas para crear buenas relaciones con comunidades aisladas que conviven dentro del hábitat del venado.
Ya hemos conformado un equipo humano perfectamente capacitado para los requerimientos de este proyecto. PROBIODIVERSA tiene su origen y sede en el estado Mérida y todo el contexto alrededor del proyecto es algo familiar para el equipo.
 
Los recursos solicitados serán destinados para cumplir los  objetivos y se usarán de la siguiente manera:
 

Impuestos para el ingreso y filmación en áreas protegidas como Parques Nacionales.
Guías Locales para la incursión en áreas retiradas y de difícil acceso.
Catering para el equipo de producción.
Honorarios profesionales del equipo humano contratado para el proyecto (Director, Editor, Música Original, Camarógrafos, Productor ejecutivo, Biólogo de campo, Asistentes de campo, Guías locales, Guionista, Diseñador gráfico, Contador, Operador de Drone).
Transporte del equipo de producción.
Hospedaje durante la producción.
Alquiler de algunos equipos de producción.
Alquiler de 2 caballos para el transporte de los equipos materiales en áreas de difícil acceso.
Adquisición de 1 Disco duro externo.
Adquisición de 4 baterías adicionales para las cámaras de video.
Adquisición de 4 tarjetas de memoria para las cámaras de video.
Adquisición de Bombonas de Gas de excursión para las cocinas.
Adquisición de baterías AA, AAA y taco D, para todos los aparatos electrónicos (GPS, Linternas, microfonía y cámaras de sensores remotos)

Este proyecto en INDIEGOGO estará en el formato INDEMAND, el cual, una vez se acabe el tiempo establecido de la campaña (60 días), pueda seguir recibiendo aportes de personas que se sumen a creer en esta iniciativa.
 
¿Cómo nos puedes ayudar? 
Adquiere alguna de las atractivas recompensas que tendremos disponibles.
Ayúdanos a difundir el mensaje por todos los medios digitales.
Síguenos en las Redes Sociales.
 Invita a tus amigos y a todas las personas que puedas a que adquieran alguna de nuestras recompensas que van desde1$ en adelante.
 “Nota: Todas las fotos utilizadas en esta presentación de campaña pertenecen a los Archivos de PROBIODIVERSA”    Con tu ayuda y la de aliados comprometidos, realizaremos este proyecto que no tiene precedentes  en el país.       Nota Especial: a todas las personas (natural como jurídica) que vivan en el extranjero, si aún mantienen alguna empresa o actividad económica dentro del país, se les puede hacer entrega de una factura de la Fundación, la cual está certificada y brinda beneficios contables sobre los Impuestos Sobre la Renta.

story:
Project Summary

We are ready to build the first refuge; our elephants are waiting, we have the property and we have a great team.  Now we need you to help us make the first place in Nepal that elephants will run free during the day and rest in their corrals at night; swim in the river, be with their babies and learn to be elephants again.

About Us

This year Direct Aid built the first chain free corrals for private elephants in Sauraha Chitwan Nepal. Chain free corrals allow captive elephants to be free from their bondage of chains while they are home and not working.  We also retired our first elephants from working conditions.  A baby bull elephant, Samrat Gaj and in conjunction with Association Moey, 60 year old Lucky Kali.  Lucky Kali had spent her life in the logging industry and then in the tourist industry. Now we are ready to expand our operation to retire several more elephants.  We have 3 elephants who are partially retired but we need your support to transition them to full retirement. 

When we retire elephants we also revitalize their caregivers (Mahouts).  We give them honor and respect in a difficult profession.  When we care for the caretakers with kindness they treat the elephants with kindness.  

We have a perfect location with a beautiful river running through it.  Water is a precious resource here which will now be protected by the foundation to be used by the elephants, the local children, and fishermen in permanent trust.  

Our goals are multifaceted. Legally acquire our current elephants living at Sapana which is a complex task but we have commitments already in place.  Legally obtain our land and have it placed in perpetual trust, and our team stands waiting! 

Donna Marshall Founder of Direct Aid Nepal has just finished building corrals for the elephants of Sapana which will serve as the first refuge site for the elephants who reside here. We have built toys in the corrals, created a watering system for the elephants, new showers for the caretakers of the elephants, painted rooms, the buildings and a general clean up of the property that the elephants will call home until we finish the new refuge.  Ms. Marshall has been an advocate of elephants in the United States and in Nepal. This year Direct Aid Nepal provided the support to retire the first residents of the refuge, the foundation also sponsored the first foot care program at Sapana by Carol Buckley. Direct Aid Nepal will be the umbrella organization for this initial startup.  Located in the United States it is fully registered Non-Profit 501 3 c.

Dhruba Giri the owner of Sapana Lodge is a forward-thinking Nepalese man with humble beginnings who has come full circle from being an elephant owner for profit to a man with a vision where he sees the overall benefit from retiring elephants from the tourist industry.  He is donating over 10 acres of his property needed for the refuge; he is the face of change in Nepal.  He works tirelessly to promote education, mobile health clinics, a city-wide recycling project and now an elephant refuge.  With the generous land donation we will only need to purchase the remaining property in the area to ensure the land is only to be used for the refuge. 

Lena Quenard founder of Assocation Moey has been working with elephants for many years in Thailand and in Nepal; she has trained with Carol Buckley in foot care and welfare care. She was the driving force behind the rescue of Lucky Kali one of our residents at Sapana.  Lucky Kali a 60+ old elephant is the first retired private elephant in Nepal.   It has been a journey for Lucky, Mrs. Quenard and her mahouts.   Mrs. Quenard has agreed to be our first Elephant Welfare Manager at our Refuge.  She is also an amazing photographer, capturing many images that helped us with our video.    

What We Need 

It will cost us $400,000 to legally secure the elephants and pay for their care in full, hiring our staff and upgrading all current elephant systems in place for the first year and to prepare the property for elephants.  It will cost us $700,000 to obtain the full property we require and to build a corral system that will be strong enough to withstand wild elephants and rhinos from entering the premises.  Baby bulls will require strong corrals and we will have them.  Next year we will plant 500 trees to give the property flavor for the elephants; providing necessary shade and food.

The Impact

We will hire Local! Nepal’s youth suffers from unemployment; we need 15 to 20 people year one to come on board with us.  By year 3 we should be hiring 50 people.  As we grow the tourist industry in the area which has collapsed will start to recover.  

Our jobs will have a just wage; health insurance and above all respect and dignity.  

We will provide two scholarships each year to local youths who wish to pursue a career in Animal Care at our local college.

We will save the precious water here.  We will have a river warden to test and analyze the water of the river not only in our area but the entire river; monitoring usage and helping to change any behavior that is harmful to the water source.

We will become the center of training for mahouts; elephant caregivers in Nepal.  Here we will teach humane training. We will continue to have foot care clinics.  

More elephants; we will continue to evaluate the 108 private elephants in Nepal and our board will determine at least once per year which elephants should be retired from the community and then we will negotiate their retirement with the private owner with the stipulation that the elephant cannot be replaced.  We already have a list of 6 elephants that desperately need our help. Desperate is not an exaggerated word here.

The Perks and Rewards

We have several vacation packages suited for all levels!  We hope you find one that works for you!  Please contact us with any questions, we are able to make adjustments if needed.  Trips need to be completed by 18 months from the day the campaign is completed.  If you're not up for travel we also have options for donations.  You may also qualify for tax deductions.  Please note that our trips start in Nepal and do not include any International travel that may be required.  Please make sure you are eligible for travel to Nepal prior to selecting a package.

Trip Costs include: All transportation within Nepal,  Lodging including breakfast.  Local guide service.  All listed activities.  

Not included in Trip Costs:  International travel to Nepal.  Trip insurance (we recommend this while purchasing your flight to Nepal).  Visa fees.  Lunch and Dinner during the trip (unless otherwise noted i.e. All Inclusive).  

Chitwan Adventure $1495 for 2 ($995 for 1)!

​All inclusive 4 day 3 night Stay at Sapana Village.

Day 1: Morning flight from Kathmandu to Chitwan.  Spend the day with our Elephants learning about care, feeding, bathing and playing!

Day 2:  Jungle Walk! Venture into the jungle to see the local wildlife including rhinoceros, tigers, bears and more!  Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 

Day 3: Rest and Relax Day! Catch up on some needed R&R at the Spa, participate in our Meditation and Yoga program.  Meet the women of our Skill Center and have some items made to commemorate your trip. 

Day 4:  Fly back to Kathmandu and prepare for your next Journey.

The Voyager Package $1895 for 1!

8 Day Complete Tour of Nepal for 1 Person.  All the highlights of Nepal!  Everest, Chitwan Jungle and Kathmandu!

Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area, dine and shop.

Days 2:  Kathmandu! Your guide will bring you to the beautiful world heritage sites around the city, including the famed Buddhist Stupa and Hindu Temples in a private car.   

Day 3: Travel Day!  Fly to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person.  Spend the day with the elephants learn about care, feeding, bathing and playing. Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 

Day 4: Jungle day!  Morning canoe trip down the river where you will see amazing wildlife and many crocodiles! Afternoon take a jeep safari deep into the jungle to see Rhinoceros, Tigers, Bears, Deer and serene scenery.  

Day 5: Rest and Relax Day! Catch up on some needed R&R at the Spa, participate in our Meditation and Yoga program.  Meet the women of our Skill Center and have some items made to commemorate your trip. Visit the Tharu village where you will have dinner and dance with the local people, experiencing the culture.

Day 6: Travel by private car towards Kathmandu. Spend the night in Daman with panoramic views of Everest!  

Day 7: Continue the journey to Kathmandu to prepare for your journey home.  Shop the town, pick up last-minute gifts for friends and family!   

Day 8:  See you soon!  Private car to the airport.  

The Enlightenment Package $4295 for 2 ($2495 for 1)!

12 Day Tour of Nepal through the Local People.  Stay in Monasteries and Eco Organic Resorts while hiking through villages and experiencing the authentic Nepali life.

Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area.

Days 2: Kathmandu! Your guide will bring you to the beautiful world heritage sites around the city, including the famed Buddhist Stupa and Hindu Temples.

Day 3: Travel to Dhulikhel and Hike to Namo Buddha.  Trek through the country side and up 1982 meter hike.  Overnight stay at the Monastery.  

Day 4: Hike to Panauti Village and tour Bhaktapur.  Experience medieval town and art culture.

Day 5: Travel to Bandipur Near Cultural Village.  Visit with the local people.

Day 6: Travel to Pokhara.  Experience stunning panoramic views of the Himalayas.  End the day with boating trip on Phewa Lake.

Day 7: Hike Dhampus Hill.  Experience the Nepalese country side and observe the daily life of the local people.

Day 8: Hike to Australian Camp.  See Annapurna South and many other majestic peaks.

Day 9: Fly from Pokhara to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person.  Spend the day with the elephants learn about care, feeding, bathing and playing. Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 

Day 10: Jungle day!  Morning canoe trip down the river where you will see amazing wildlife and many crocodiles! Afternoon take a jeep safari deep into the jungle to see Rhinoceros, Tigers, Bears, Deer and serene scenery.  

Day 11:  Fly back to Kathmandu in the morning and prepare for your journey home.  

The Trailblazer Package $4295 for 2!

7 Day Trek and Tour for 2 people.

Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area, dine and shop.

Day 2: Everest!  Wake early for the flight of a lifetime, “Everest Experience”. After the flight return to the hotel for lunch and an afternoon of tour the world heritage sites of the city.    

Day 3:  Travel by private car towards Chitwan.  Stop at Hugdi to start your trek at Chepang Hills. Spend the evening in the local village.

Day 4:  Finish the trek down to Shiktikhor passing through Hattibang, Siraichuli and Chaukidanda.  Meet our driver to bring you for the final leg of your journey to Sapana Village.  Evening Spa and Dinner with our Elephant experts.  

Day 5: Morning canoe trip and jungle walk. Return early afternoon for lunch and spend the rest of the day with the elephants.  

Day 6:  Fly back to Kathmandu and prepare for your journey home.  Shop the town, pick up last-minute gifts for friends and family!  Stay overnight in Kathmandu.  

Day 7:  See you soon!  Private car back to the airport.

Hiking Serenity Package $5995 for 2!

8 Days for 2 People Hiking through the Cultural UNESCO Heritage Sites Tour, Himalaya's views, walking through many different environments.  Visit Buddhist Pilgrimage sites and finally end your trip with a flight to Chitwan to meet the elephants!

Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area, dine and shop.

Day 2:  Start the day at the Changunarayan Temple, one of the oldest world heritage sites!  From there hike to the panoramic Himalayan views and a once in a lifetime sunset.

Day 3: Enjoy the early morning sunrise over the Himalayas.  Hike to Dhulikhel and experience dense forests and snow capped peaks mixed within traditional housing and various temples and buddhist stupas.  

Day 4:  Continue the hike to Namobuddha and experience the local culture of hillside terraced farms and panoramic mountain views.  Drive back to Kathmandu in the evening.

Days 5:  Kathmandu! Your guide will bring you to the beautiful world heritage sites around the city, including the famed Buddhist Stupa and Hindu Temples in a private car.   

Day 6: Fly to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person.  Spend the day with the elephants learn about care, feeding, bathing and playing. Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 

Day 7: Jungle day!  Morning canoe trip down the river where you will see amazing wildlife and many crocodiles! Afternoon take a jeep safari deep into the jungle to see Rhinoceros, Tigers, Bears, Deer and serene scenery.  

Day 8:  Fly back to Kathmandu in the morning and prepare for your journey home.  

The Adventurer Package $8995 for 2!

8 Day Tour of Nepal for 2 People.  All the highlights of Nepal!  Everest, Sunsets, Jungle!

Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring you to your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area, dine and shop.

Day 2: Everest!  Wake early for the flight of a lifetime, “Everest Experience”. After the flight return to the hotel for lunch and an afternoon of tour the world heritage sites of the city.    

Day 3: Travel Day!  Fly to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person.  Spend the day with the elephants learn about care, feeding, bathing and playing. Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 

Day 4: Jungle day!  Morning canoe trip down the river where you will see amazing wildlife and many crocodiles! Down the river be picked up by a jeep safari which will take you deep into the jungle to see Rhinoceros, Tigers, Bears, Deer and serene scenery.  

Day 5: Rest and Relax Day! Catch up on some needed R&R at the Spa, participate in our Meditation and Yoga program.  Meet the women of our Skill Center and have some items made to commemorate your trip. Visit the Tharu village where you will have dinner and dance with the local people, experiencing the culture.

Day 6: Travel by private car towards Kathmandu. Spend the night at the Daman Hotel with panoramic views of Everest!  

Day 7: Continue the journey to Kathmandu to prepare for your journey home.  Shop the town, pick up last-minute gifts for friends and family!  Stay overnight in the heart of the city! 

Day 8:  See you soon!  Private car to the airport.  

Tour Like a Local $9995 for 2!

A 14 Day Tour of Nepal or 2 People.  See all the Highlights of Nepal from to Ground!  UNESCO Heritage Sites Tour, Jungle safari, Sunrise & sunset view major Eastern & Western Himalayas, Visit Newari Village-Bandipur, Wildlife Safari, Boating/Hiking to World Peace Pagoda, City tour, Rickshaw ride, Trek Dhampus-Australian Camp, Nepali dinner & cultural show and visit our Elephants for R & R.  

Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring you to your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area, dine and shop.

Days 2: Kathmandu!  Your guide will bring you to the beautiful world heritage sites around the city, including the famed Buddhist Stupa and Hindu Temples.  

Day 3:  Drive to Bandipur!  Enjoy a heavy mix of history, architecture and breathtaking views!  

Day 4:  Travel to Pokhara!  Panoramic views of the Himalayas and serene lake settings.

Day 5, 6 and 7:  A bit of Trekking!  Dhampus Hill and Australian Camp.  Overnight stay in local resorts along the way!

Day 8 and 9:  Travel to Lumbini!  Travel to the birth place of Lord Buddha, the Founder of Buddhism.  Explore the many gardens, monasteries, museums and Peace Pagoda.

Day 10: Travel Day!  Drive to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person.  Spend the day with the elephants learn about care, feeding, bathing and playing. Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 

Day 11: Jungle day!  Morning canoe trip down the river where you will see amazing wildlife and many crocodiles! Down the river be picked up by a jeep safari which will take you deep into the jungle to see Rhinoceros, Tigers, Bears, Deer and serene scenery.  

Day 12: Rest and Relax Day! Catch up on some needed R&R at the Spa, participate in our Meditation and Yoga program.  Meet the women of our Skill Center and have some items made to commemorate your trip. Visit the Tharu village where you will have dinner and dance with the local people, experiencing the culture.

Day 13: Fly back to Kathmandu to prepare for your journey home.  Shop the town, pick up last-minute gifts for friends and family!  Stay overnight in the heart of the city! 

Day 14:  See you soon!  Private car to the airport.  

The Explorer Package $15000 for 2!

11 Day Complete Tour of Nepal for 2 People.  All the highlights of Nepal!  Everest, Chitwan, Pokhara, Kathmandu!

Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring you to your hotel in the heart of the city.  

Days 2: Kathmandu!  Your guide will bring you to the beautiful world heritage sites around the city, including the famed Buddhist Stupa and Hindu Temples.  

Day 3: Everest!  Wake early for the flight of a lifetime, “Everest Experience”. After the flight return to the hotel for lunch and an afternoon of shopping or additional sightseeing.    

Day 4: Travel Day!  Fly to Bhuratpur where you will be greeted by one of our Elephant experts!  Travel to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person.  Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 

Day 5: Elephant day!  Spend the day with our Elephants learning about care, feeding, bathing and playing!

Day 6: Jungle day!  Morning canoe trip down the river where you will see amazing wildlife and many crocodiles!  Down the river be picked up by a jeep safari which will take you deep into the jungle to see Rhinoceros, Tigers, Bears, Deer and serene scenery.  

Day 7: Rest and Relax Day! Catch up on some needed R&R at the Spa, participate in our Meditation and Yoga program.  Meet the women of our Skill Center and have some items made to commemorate your trip. Visit the Tharu village where you will have dinner and dance with the local people, experiencing the culture.

Day 8: Travel Day:  Depart for airport and fly to Pokhara where our guide will meet you for the last leg of your adventure!  Tour of the mountains, lakes and waterfalls where you can enjoy many outdoor activities including day hikes and swims.  

Day 9:  Saragkot Sunrise!  Enjoy the early morning sunrise from Saragkot and if you’re up for the adventure, a paragliding trip!  Afternoon site seeing tour of Pokhara.  

Day 10: Travel Day!  Head back to Kathmandu to prepare for your journey home. Shop the town, pick up last-minute gifts for friends and family!

Day 11: See you soon!  Private car to the airport.  

The Finest of Nepal $25000 for 2!

12 Day Luxury Accomodation Tour for 2 People.  Highlights include Private Helicopter Tour to Base Camp and Private Helicopter Trip to Chitwan.

Day 1:  Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring you to your hotel in the heart of the city.  

Days 2:  Kathmandu! Your guide will bring you to the beautiful world heritage sites around the city, including the famed Buddhist Stupa and Hindu Temples in a private car.  

Day 3:  Everest!  See and feel the natural beauty of Nepal and the Himalayas on a 3-hour private helicopter trip to the Everest Base Camp.  Breakfast at the Everest View Hotel.  Return to Kathmandu.  

Day 4:  Travel Day!  Helicopter to Bhuratpur where you will be greeted by one of our Elephant experts! Travel to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person. Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals.

Day 5: Elephant day!  Spend the day with our Elephants learning about care, feeding, bathing and playing!

Day 6: Jungle Safari!  Full day open jeep safari of the majestic Chitwan National Park. Travel deep into the jungle to see the local wildlife including rhinoceros, tigers, bears and more!

Day 7: Rest and Relax Day! Catch up on some needed R&R at the Spa, participate in our Meditation and Yoga program.  Meet the women of our Skill Center and have some items made to commemorate your trip. Visit the Tharu village where you will have dinner and dance with the local people, experiencing the culture.

Day 8: Short Flight to Pokhara!  Private car to the beautiful Waterfront Resort.  Enjoy a early evening tour of the city and Phewa Lake.

Day 9:  Saragkot Sunrise!  Enjoy the early morning sunrise from Saragkot and if you’re up for the adventure, a paragliding trip!  Afternoon site seeing tour of Pokhara.  

Day 10 and 11: Travel day!  Flight back to Kathmandu where you will be whisked away for 2 nights at Club Himalaya!

Day 12:  Last day! Travel back to Kathmandu, private car to the airport.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute it doesn't mean you can't help!  Please help by sharing our campaign to your friends, family and workplace.  The elephants and our team need your support!

Thank you so much for your attention!
story_txt:
Project Summary
We are ready to build the first refuge; our elephants are waiting, we have the property and we have a great team.  Now we need you to help us make the first place in Nepal that elephants will run free during the day and rest in their corrals at night; swim in the river, be with their babies and learn to be elephants again.
About Us
This year Direct Aid built the first chain free corrals for private elephants in Sauraha Chitwan Nepal. Chain free corrals allow captive elephants to be free from their bondage of chains while they are home and not working.  We also retired our first elephants from working conditions.  A baby bull elephant, Samrat Gaj and in conjunction with Association Moey, 60 year old Lucky Kali.  Lucky Kali had spent her life in the logging industry and then in the tourist industry. Now we are ready to expand our operation to retire several more elephants.  We have 3 elephants who are partially retired but we need your support to transition them to full retirement. 
When we retire elephants we also revitalize their caregivers (Mahouts).  We give them honor and respect in a difficult profession.  When we care for the caretakers with kindness they treat the elephants with kindness.  
We have a perfect location with a beautiful river running through it.  Water is a precious resource here which will now be protected by the foundation to be used by the elephants, the local children, and fishermen in permanent trust.  
Our goals are multifaceted. Legally acquire our current elephants living at Sapana which is a complex task but we have commitments already in place.  Legally obtain our land and have it placed in perpetual trust, and our team stands waiting! 
Donna Marshall Founder of Direct Aid Nepal has just finished building corrals for the elephants of Sapana which will serve as the first refuge site for the elephants who reside here. We have built toys in the corrals, created a watering system for the elephants, new showers for the caretakers of the elephants, painted rooms, the buildings and a general clean up of the property that the elephants will call home until we finish the new refuge.  Ms. Marshall has been an advocate of elephants in the United States and in Nepal. This year Direct Aid Nepal provided the support to retire the first residents of the refuge, the foundation also sponsored the first foot care program at Sapana by Carol Buckley. Direct Aid Nepal will be the umbrella organization for this initial startup.  Located in the United States it is fully registered Non-Profit 501 3 c.
Dhruba Giri the owner of Sapana Lodge is a forward-thinking Nepalese man with humble beginnings who has come full circle from being an elephant owner for profit to a man with a vision where he sees the overall benefit from retiring elephants from the tourist industry.  He is donating over 10 acres of his property needed for the refuge; he is the face of change in Nepal.  He works tirelessly to promote education, mobile health clinics, a city-wide recycling project and now an elephant refuge.  With the generous land donation we will only need to purchase the remaining property in the area to ensure the land is only to be used for the refuge. 
Lena Quenard founder of Assocation Moey has been working with elephants for many years in Thailand and in Nepal; she has trained with Carol Buckley in foot care and welfare care. She was the driving force behind the rescue of Lucky Kali one of our residents at Sapana.  Lucky Kali a 60+ old elephant is the first retired private elephant in Nepal.   It has been a journey for Lucky, Mrs. Quenard and her mahouts.   Mrs. Quenard has agreed to be our first Elephant Welfare Manager at our Refuge.  She is also an amazing photographer, capturing many images that helped us with our video.    

What We Need 
It will cost us $400,000 to legally secure the elephants and pay for their care in full, hiring our staff and upgrading all current elephant systems in place for the first year and to prepare the property for elephants.  It will cost us $700,000 to obtain the full property we require and to build a corral system that will be strong enough to withstand wild elephants and rhinos from entering the premises.  Baby bulls will require strong corrals and we will have them.  Next year we will plant 500 trees to give the property flavor for the elephants; providing necessary shade and food.

The Impact
We will hire Local! Nepal’s youth suffers from unemployment; we need 15 to 20 people year one to come on board with us.  By year 3 we should be hiring 50 people.  As we grow the tourist industry in the area which has collapsed will start to recover.  
Our jobs will have a just wage; health insurance and above all respect and dignity.  
We will provide two scholarships each year to local youths who wish to pursue a career in Animal Care at our local college.
We will save the precious water here.  We will have a river warden to test and analyze the water of the river not only in our area but the entire river; monitoring usage and helping to change any behavior that is harmful to the water source.
We will become the center of training for mahouts; elephant caregivers in Nepal.  Here we will teach humane training. We will continue to have foot care clinics.  
More elephants; we will continue to evaluate the 108 private elephants in Nepal and our board will determine at least once per year which elephants should be retired from the community and then we will negotiate their retirement with the private owner with the stipulation that the elephant cannot be replaced.  We already have a list of 6 elephants that desperately need our help. Desperate is not an exaggerated word here.

The Perks and Rewards
We have several vacation packages suited for all levels!  We hope you find one that works for you!  Please contact us with any questions, we are able to make adjustments if needed.  Trips need to be completed by 18 months from the day the campaign is completed.  If you're not up for travel we also have options for donations.  You may also qualify for tax deductions.  Please note that our trips start in Nepal and do not include any International travel that may be required.  Please make sure you are eligible for travel to Nepal prior to selecting a package.
Trip Costs include: All transportation within Nepal,  Lodging including breakfast.  Local guide service.  All listed activities.  
Not included in Trip Costs:  International travel to Nepal.  Trip insurance (we recommend this while purchasing your flight to Nepal).  Visa fees.  Lunch and Dinner during the trip (unless otherwise noted i.e. All Inclusive).  
Chitwan Adventure $1495 for 2 ($995 for 1)!

​All inclusive 4 day 3 night Stay at Sapana Village.
Day 1: Morning flight from Kathmandu to Chitwan.  Spend the day with our Elephants learning about care, feeding, bathing and playing!
Day 2:  Jungle Walk! Venture into the jungle to see the local wildlife including rhinoceros, tigers, bears and more!  Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 
Day 3: Rest and Relax Day! Catch up on some needed R&R at the Spa, participate in our Meditation and Yoga program.  Meet the women of our Skill Center and have some items made to commemorate your trip. 
Day 4:  Fly back to Kathmandu and prepare for your next Journey.
The Voyager Package $1895 for 1!

8 Day Complete Tour of Nepal for 1 Person.  All the highlights of Nepal!  Everest, Chitwan Jungle and Kathmandu!
Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area, dine and shop.
Days 2:  Kathmandu! Your guide will bring you to the beautiful world heritage sites around the city, including the famed Buddhist Stupa and Hindu Temples in a private car.   
Day 3: Travel Day!  Fly to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person.  Spend the day with the elephants learn about care, feeding, bathing and playing. Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 
Day 4: Jungle day!  Morning canoe trip down the river where you will see amazing wildlife and many crocodiles! Afternoon take a jeep safari deep into the jungle to see Rhinoceros, Tigers, Bears, Deer and serene scenery.  
Day 5: Rest and Relax Day! Catch up on some needed R&R at the Spa, participate in our Meditation and Yoga program.  Meet the women of our Skill Center and have some items made to commemorate your trip. Visit the Tharu village where you will have dinner and dance with the local people, experiencing the culture.
Day 6: Travel by private car towards Kathmandu. Spend the night in Daman with panoramic views of Everest!  
Day 7: Continue the journey to Kathmandu to prepare for your journey home.  Shop the town, pick up last-minute gifts for friends and family!   
Day 8:  See you soon!  Private car to the airport.  
The Enlightenment Package $4295 for 2 ($2495 for 1)!

12 Day Tour of Nepal through the Local People.  Stay in Monasteries and Eco Organic Resorts while hiking through villages and experiencing the authentic Nepali life.
Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area.
Days 2: Kathmandu! Your guide will bring you to the beautiful world heritage sites around the city, including the famed Buddhist Stupa and Hindu Temples.
Day 3: Travel to Dhulikhel and Hike to Namo Buddha.  Trek through the country side and up 1982 meter hike.  Overnight stay at the Monastery.  
Day 4: Hike to Panauti Village and tour Bhaktapur.  Experience medieval town and art culture.
Day 5: Travel to Bandipur Near Cultural Village.  Visit with the local people.
Day 6: Travel to Pokhara.  Experience stunning panoramic views of the Himalayas.  End the day with boating trip on Phewa Lake.
Day 7: Hike Dhampus Hill.  Experience the Nepalese country side and observe the daily life of the local people.
Day 8: Hike to Australian Camp.  See Annapurna South and many other majestic peaks.
Day 9: Fly from Pokhara to Chitwan National Park where you will stay at Sapana Village Lodge and see our Elephants in person.  Spend the day with the elephants learn about care, feeding, bathing and playing. Have dinner with our Elephant experts and learn about our plans for the future and how you’ve helped these majestic animals. 
Day 10: Jungle day!  Morning canoe trip down the river where you will see amazing wildlife and many crocodiles! Afternoon take a jeep safari deep into the jungle to see Rhinoceros, Tigers, Bears, Deer and serene scenery.  
Day 11:  Fly back to Kathmandu in the morning and prepare for your journey home.  
The Trailblazer Package $4295 for 2!

7 Day Trek and Tour for 2 people.
Day 1: Start your trip in Kathmandu where your guide will greet you at the airport and bring your hotel in the heart of the city.  Get settled tour the local area, dine and shop.
Day 2: Everest!  Wake early for the flight of a lifetime, “Everest Experience”. After the flight return to the hotel for lunch and an afternoon of tour the world heritage sites of the city.    
Day 3:  Travel by private car towards Chitwan.  Stop at Hugdi to start your trek at Chepang Hills. Spend the evening in the local village.
Day 4:  Finish the trek down to Shiktikhor passing through Hattibang, Siraichuli and Chaukidanda.  Meet our driver to bring you for the final leg of your journey to Sapana Village.  Evening Spa and Dinner with our Elephant experts.  
Day 5: Morning canoe trip and jungle walk. Return early afternoon for lunch and spend the rest of the day with the elephants.  
Day 6:  Fly back to Kathmandu and prepare for your journey home.  Shop the town, pick up last-minute gifts for friends and family!  Stay overnight in Kathmandu.  
Day 7:  See you soon!  Private car back to the airport.
Hiking Serenity Package $5995 for 2!
